DIV1.P: THE ANTIQUITIES OF BERKSHIRE.
By ELIAS ASHMOLE, Es{que}
VOL. III.
LONDON: Printed for E. Curll in Fleetstreet. M.DCC.XIX.

DIV4.HEAD: BRAY,
DIV4.P:
IS a Vicaridge in the Hundred of Bray, of which it is the only Parish; Patron the Bi∣shop of Oxford; Incumbent the Reverend Mr. Browne. Camden says, the Bibroci inhabited these Parts, who submitted themselves to Julius
Caesar, upon his crossing the Thames not far from hence, and this he partly dedu∣ces from the Name Bibracte in France, now contracted into Bray, and seems to think no Place corresponds so exactly to the Situation of the Bibroci as this. I have not indeed heard of any Remains of Roman Antiquity found here, but in all the adjacent Parts they have occurred, so that these Parts might in all probability be not unknown to the Romans.

Against the North Wall of the Chancel, towards the East, is a large Monument, containing the Busto of a Man in a Gown, leaning his Hands on a Scull: By him his Wife, holding a Book in her Hands; and this Inscription under them.

Q.L: If what I was thou seekest to know,
These Lynes my Character shall shew,
Those Benefits that God me lent,
With Thankes I tooke, and freely spent;
I scorned what Plainess could not gett,
And next to Treason hated Debt;
I loved not those that stirr'd up Strife,
True to my Friend, and to my Wife;
The latter here by me I have,
We had one Bed, and have one Grave.
My Honesty was such, that I
When Death came, feared not to dye.

DIV4.P: In the said North Wall is another Mo∣nument, in which are the Figures of a Man and his Wife, kneeling at a Desk, engraven on Brass Plates, with the fol∣lowing Inscription.

Q.L: When Oxford gave thee two Degrees in Art,
A Love possessed thee Master of my Heart.
Thy Colledge Fellowship thou left'st for myne,
And nought but Death could sep'rate thee from thyne.
Thirty Five Yeares we lived in wedlock Bands,
Conjoyned in our Hearts as well as Hands.
But Death the Bodies of best Friends divides,
And in the Earth's close Womb their Reliques hides;
Yet here they are not lost, but sowne, that they
May rise more Glorious at the Judgment Day.

DIV4.P: Under the South Wall, near the East End of the South Ile, lies a Marble Grave-stone with the following Inscription on it.
DIV4.Q:
MEMORIAE SACRUM Viri Honoratissimi Domini THOMAE STEWKELEY, de Marsh, in Comitatu Somerset, Militis. Qui natus 4° die Aprilis, Anno Dni. 1569. fidelis, et dilectus, Gratiae plenus, et dierum,
faeliciter expiravit. Ipso Redemptionis nostrae die 12 Aprilis, Anno Dni. 1639. Aetatis suae 70. Sit Deo Gloria.
DIV4.P: On another Grave-stone, on a Brass Plate, are the Figures of a Man in a long Robe, standing on a Cushion, a Cap on his Head, and his Wife by him drest in the Habit of her Times, and this Inscrip∣tion underneath their Feet.
DIV4.Q: Hic jacet Willielmus Laken, Miles, nuper unus Iusticiariorum de Banco Dni. Regis, filius quon∣dam Ricardi Laken, Militis: qui quidem Willielmus obiit 6 Die Men. Octobris, An° Dui. 1475. Et Dna. Sybella Vxor ejus, filia et una here∣dum Johannis Syterwalt, quondam Dni. de Cleaver. Duorum animabus propictetur Deus. Amen.
DIV4.P: On another Grave-stone, near the for∣mer, is the Figure of a Man in Armour, between his two Wives, his Feet resting upon a Tree, with this Inscription under∣neath them.
DIV4.Q: Hic jacet Thomas Foxley, Armiger, qui obiit secundo Die Novemb. An. Dni. 1436. et Margeria ac Theobalda Vxores ejus. Duorum animabus propicietur Deus. Amen.
DIV4.P: On another Marble Grave-stone, lying near the former, is this Inscription.
I. N. R. I.

Q.P: Crux Christi # Christiana gloria, sub hoc vexillo Fidei Catholicae, Et Resurrectionis beatae spe, Ecce Monumentum Dominae Honorabilis vereque nobilis ANNAE SANDYS de Foxleys, in Parochia Bragae.

Diu hic versata fuit nobiscum, vitae sanctae innocentiâ, in sacra munificentia, in proximos liberalitate, assiduis in egenos Eleemosynis, Nec uno solum angulo, sed ubique illius praeluxit celebritas, Armorum denique et almae famae statura, dictis votivis precibus, et in Deum devote fusis, evolavit in requiem aeternam Die 21 Januarii,
Anno Dni. 1639. Aetatisque suae 84°.

DIV4.P: Upon another Marble Grave-stone, ly∣ing farther in the South Ile, is a Repre∣sentation of Sir John Foxley lying between his two Wives, and this Inscription un∣der them.
DIV4.Q: ... jacet Dnus. Johannes de Novembris, Anno Domini, Milli∣mo Cujus anime propicietur Deus. Amen.
DIV4.P: On a Grave-stone in the middle of the South Ile, on a Brass Plate, is this In∣scription.
DIV4.Q: Hic jacet GULIELMUS SMITHE, Ar∣miger, quondam Sereniss. Regi∣ne Elizabethae, ad Arma, et scutel∣las serviens, que officia prius ha∣buit ex dono Mariae Regine, qui postquam digna laude vite sue cursum in fideli servitio Princi∣pum transegisset, obiit 28° Die Octobris, Anno Dni. 1594. Eta∣tis autem sue 84°.
DIV4.P: Upon another Grave-stone, in the South Ile, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Here lyeth the Body of BARTHOLO∣MEW SMITH, Gen. who dyed the 15th of June, 1638. aged 78.
DIV4.P: Upon a Grave-stone, lying at the Foot of the former, under the Figures of a Man and his Wife in their usual Habits, on Brass, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Pray for the Soules of John Fouler, and... hys Wyfe; in which John decessyd the 24 Day of August, in the Yere of our Lord 1479.
DIV4.P: On whose Soules Ihesu have Mercy.
Under this are the Figures of his two Daughters.
On another Grave-stone, in the said Ile, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q:
Here lieth buried the Body of Mrs. ELIZABETH PARRY, Wife to HUGH PARRY, of New Windsor,
Gentleman, Daughter to JOHN PAGE, Es{que} of this Parish. She dyed the 29 of May, in the Yeare 1659.
DIV4.P: On the South Side of a great Pillar, erected between the South and middle Ile, is fixed a Brass Plate, bearing the Effigies of a Man and his Wife praying at a Desk, and under them is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Neere unto this Place lyeth buried the Bodies of ARTHUR PAGE, of Walter Okeley, in the Parish of Bray, and County of Berks, Gent. who had to Wife SESSELY BROWNESOPP, Daugh∣ter of WILLIAM BROWNESOPP, Es{que} They had Yssue one Son, EDWARD PAGE. The said Arthur deceased the 23 Day of Decemb. An°. 1610. and the said Sessely dyed the 12th Day of March, An°. 1598.
DIV4.P: On a Brass Plate fixed to a Grave-stone, under the Communion Table, is this In∣scription.
DIV4.Q:
Hic jacet Magister Willielmus Dyer, quondam Vicarius Ecclesie
de Bray, qui obiit ultimo Die Ja∣nuarij, An°. Dni. 1440. Cujus anime propicietur Deus. Amen.
DIV4.P: Lower, on the same Grave-stone, on a Brass Plate, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Orate pro anima Dni. Thome atte Lude, Capellani. Cujus anime propicietur Deus. Amen.
DIV4.P: Not far from the Entrance into the Chancel, is a Grave-stone bearing the following Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Here lyeth the Body of ELIZABETH MOSSE, Widdow of FRANCIS MOSSE, Citizen and Scrivener of London, who departed this Lyfe the 4th of March, in the 67th Year of her Age, Anno Domini, 1662.
DIV4.P: On a Grave-stone, lying on the North Side of the Chancel, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q:
Under this Marble resteth JAMES HUCKELL, Es{que} who was Servant to Three Princes, Queen Elizabeth,
King James, and King Charles; in office Groome, Yeoman, and Serjeant of the Larder to the said Princes 49 Yeares. He lived in holy Wedlock with KATHARINE BROWNE, of Sur∣rey, 48 Yeares and halfe, with much Comfort and Happiness, and dyed in the Faith of Christ, Nov. 13. 1641. aged 81.
Loe, here a Freind enclosed, now at rest,
Whose Soule, no doubt, is placed by the best.
His Purse was open both to Rich and Poore,
To Friend and Foe, so likewise was his Doore.
He aym'd at Peace in all his Course of Lyfe,
He hated Difference and avoyded Strife.
From whence it may be said he is in Bliss,
Which Christ affoards to none but those are His.
He hath a Conquest, being gone before,
Our Combatts are to come, our Sorrowes more. Lastly, his Office found his Livery, sued now, bearing date 1641. Nov. 13. To whose Memory KATHERINE his Wife, as a Memoriall of her Affection to her deceased Husband, imposed this Stone.
DIV4.P: On a Marble Grave-stone, Eastward of the former, is the following Inscrip∣tion.
DIV4.Q: Here under lyeth the Body of JOHN RIXMAN, Gent. who deceased at his House at Maydenhead, An°. Dni. 1620. and of his Age 66. for whome, MARY, his only Wife, caused this Stone to be layd, and erected this Monument in the Wall, 1620.
DIV4.P: This mentioned Monument is set in the North wall of the Chancel.

Under the East Window of the North Ile is a large Brass Plate fastened in the Wall, whereon is engraved the Figure of William NoRRIS is Armour (sometime Usher of the Black Rod to the most No∣ble Order of Garter) over which is his Mantle, having St. George's Arms in an Escotcheon incircled with the Garter thereon. Behind him are Figures of his six Sons; before him kneels his Wife, and behind her six Daughters. Beneath this Plate, in the Wall, is also a Black Marble bearing the following Inscription.

Q.P:
WILLIAM NORREYS, of Fifeild, in Bray, Esquire, who was Usher of the Parliament House, and of the Noble Order of the Garter, a Gentleman Pen∣cioner, Controller of the Workes of
Windsor-Castle, and Parkes there, and Keeper of Folli-John Parke, which Offices he had by the Guift of Queene Mary, and enjoyed them during Lyfe, most faithfully serving his noble Sove∣raigne Queene Elizabeth; a Justice of the Peace of Berkshire; ever of honest Behaviour and good Reputation, favouring the verteous, pleasuring many, hurting none, dyed at his House of Fyfeild, 16 Aprilis, 1591. at the Age of 68 Yeares, after he had been married 43 Yeares, and had Yssue 6 Sons and 6 Daughters, and is inter∣red by his Ancestors, under the Stone graven with his Armes here before lying.

Innocuus vixi, si me post funera laedas, Caelesti Domino facta (sceleste) lues! MARIA ex Fortescuorum familia adhuc superstes, Vidua relicta supra dicti Willielmi Norreys, hic Monumentum, suis expensis, optimo suo Marito defuncto curavit fieri 9 Augusti, 1592.

DIV4.P: Directly under the last mentioned In∣scription lyes a Black Marble bearing this Inscription.
DIV4.Q:
RELICTA NON AMISS A. Under here lyeth the Body of ANNE CLERKE, late Wife to
HERCULES GLERKE, Esquire, who if God so please, meaneth to be buried nigh this Stone. She dyed the 3d Day of July, 1641. aged 46. A little before her Death She used these Words, Lord Jesus Christ for thy Mercies sake, come quickly, Lord Jesus come quickly, even so be it. SIC DONEC.
DIV4.P: North of this Stone is a Grey Marble Grave-stone, on which, on a Brass Plate, is the Figure of a Woman in her usual Habit, and under her Feet is this In∣scription.
DIV4.Q: Here Iyeth Ursula Androwes, the Daughter of Richard Androwes, of the County of Southampton, E∣squire, and late Wife of Henry Norres, Gent. which Ursula decea∣sed the 18th Day of June, An. Dni. 1560. Whose Soule God pardon.
DIV4.P: On a small Black Marble Grave-stone, lying near the North Wall, is this In∣scription.
DIV4.Q: Here lyeth the Body of JUDITH, the eldest Daughter of RICHARD BARNES, and HANNAH his Wife. She departed this Lyfe the 6 of August, 1651. Aged five Yeares and foure Moneths.
DIV4.P: On a lesser Grey Marble Grave-stone, adjoyning to the last, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: MARY BARNES, the Daughter of RICHARD BARNES, of this Parish, Gentleman, died the 18th of Decemb. 1650.
DIV4.P: Lower in the North Ile lyes a Grave-stone, with the following Inscription on a Brass Plate.

Q.P: Anno Dom. 1567. Elizabethae Re∣gine 10 Mense Nov. 17°.
Nomine parvus eras, net nomina sperne Litille: Ingenii, atque animi pondere magnus exas. Major eras pietate, tamen nunc dotibus auctus, Omnibus ethereo maximus orbe sedes.
D. THOMAE LITILLO viro Ar∣migero, et Pio JO. SAR. posuit.

DIV4.P: On another Plate, lower than the for∣mer, is this Inscription.

Q.L: Although thou called were but Littill by thy Name,
In Pitt thy Mind and Godlyness, full great yet was in fame 3
Yet where thou wast before but greate, throogh Der∣teue sewre,
Thou greater now, doest rest in Heaven, for ever to indure.

DIV4.P: On another Brass Plate, fixed in a Stone somewhat Westward of the former, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Here, under this Marble Stone, lyeth buried the Body of CLEMENT KEIKE, Gent. who had to Wife ELIZ. Daugh∣ter to Alderman BECHER, he was borne at Bristow, and was a Citizen of London, a Merchant Venterer, and Free of the Haberdashers, being of the Age of 70 Yeares, deceased this 24th of Sept. An°. Dni. 1593.
DIV4.P: In a Brass Plate fixed to a Grave-stone, near the West End of the North Ile, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Here lyeth buried the Body of THOMAS LAWRENCE, of Bray, in the County of Berks, who dyed the 28th of October, 1603.
DIV4.P: On a Brass Plate fixed to a Grave-stone, in the Body of the Church, are the Figures of a Man and his Wife, and under them this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Orate pro animabus Roberti Fow∣ler, et Agnetis Vxoris ejus, ac omni∣um fidelium defunctorum: qui quidem Robertus, obiit.... Die Mensis...... Anno Dni. Millo CCCC....... Quorum animabus propicietur Deus. Amen.
DIV4.P: Under this Epitaph are the Figures of five Sons and five Daughters.
On a Grave-stone, lying in the Body of the Church, is this inscription.
DIV4.Q:
It was assign'd by God above,
Two Brethren which did dearely love,
Both of them at one Tyme should dye,
And both within one Grave do lye.
ROBERT and RICHARD WINCH they hight,
To Heaven their Soules have made their flight;
What greater Joy can bee than this,
From Earth to Heaven, from Bale to Bliss?
To Rich ne Poore they shut no Dore, but open handed still,
Nor envious Rage in all their Age, could ever work his will.
This I dare say, well seated Bray, since first she had her be∣ing,
Nurst not two such that..... such in Lyfe and death agree∣ing. These two loving Brothers were both buried the 25th of December, 1618.
DIV4.P: Upon another Grave-stone is this In∣scription.

Q.P: Heere lye interred the Bodies of THOMAS CHERRY, of Maydenhead, in this Parish, who dyed 14th Sept. 1657. Anno Aetatis 61°. And of ELLEN his Wife, who died 19th Sept. 1657. Anno Aetatis 59°. They lived together in Wedlock 35 Yeares, and had 8 Sons and one Daughter, and were both interred here in one Grave, Sept. 20. 1657.
Heere lye also the Bodies of WILLIAM CHERRY and THOMAS CHERRY, Sons of WILLIAM CHERRY, fourth Son of the said Thomas and Ellen. They were aged 4 Yeares.

DIV4.P: On a Brass Plate in a Grave-stone, un∣der the Feet of a Man lying between his two Wives, all three habited in the Fa∣shion of their Times, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Orate pro animabus Willielmi Smith, Agnetis, et Matilde Vxorum ejus; qui quidem Willielmus obiit..... Quorum animabus propicietur Deus. Amen.
DIV4.P: In the Body of the Church, on ano∣ther Brass Plate fixed in a Grave-stone, is the following Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Orate pro anima Johannis Bird. Cujus corpus jacet hic humatum.
DIV4.P: In a Ms. Book of Heraldry, wrote in 1601. communicated to me by a Gentle∣man, I find Pedigrees of the following Persons of this Place.

DIV4.HEAD: MAIDENHEAD,
DIV4.P: Or as some have falsely called it, Mai∣denhith, is the only Village, besides Bray, in the Hundred of that Name.
We are not ignorant that Hithe agrees to the Situation of the Place; but we have that Authority for the other Name, which ought never to be slighted.

It is of no great Antiquity. The an∣tient Name, according to ourLeland's Intinerary, Vol. II. p. 3. greatest Antiquary, was South Alington, which Stow has contracted into Sudlington. But it took the Name of Maidenhead, accord∣ing to the same Author, from the Head of one of those Eleven Thonsand Virgins, said to have suffer'd Martyrdom with St. Ursula, which was had here in very great Veneration. This is the true Original of the Name, and this Opinion the World then had of the great Numbers that ac∣companied St. Ursula in her Death.

But the true Foundation of this Story having been discover'd, we shall take this Opportunity of acquainting the Reader
with it. It will deserve the more credit, because it comes from a Roman Catho∣lick Writer, and he too one of the greatest of hisSirmondus the Jesuit. Order. In a very antient MS. Mar∣tyrology, older than the general Ignorance of the Monks, he tells us he met with the following Words: Ursula & Undecimilla, VV. MM. i. e. Ursula and Undecimilla, Virgins and Martyrs. This Undecimilla, the Name of one Virgin only, came after∣wards through Ignorance to be changed by the Monks into Undecim mille, i. e. Eleven Thousand, which by degrees came generally to prevail.

About two Miles above the Town Northward, there was formerly a Ferry at a Place called Babham-End; so that 'twas not till after a Bridge was built at Maidenhead, and the Road brought that Way, that the Place began to flourish.

Leland says, at the West End of the Bridge, in his Time, was a great Wharf∣age of Timber and Fire Wood, which came out of Berkshire, out of the Woods of the Forest of Windsor, and out of the great Fryth.

This Town was first incorporated by the Name of the Fraternity or Guild of
the Brothers and Sisters of Madenheith, in the 26th of Edward III. and John Hus∣bands, Citizen and Blader of London, be∣queathed 100l. in Money to obtain a cer∣tain Revenue, sufficient for a Chanter to one Chapel, which was dedicated to St. Andrew the Apostle, and St. Mary Mag∣dalen. In consideration of this 100l. the Prior and Convent of Hurley obliged them∣selves to find one Chaplain for the said Chapel.
In the 30th of Henry VI. the Patent-Roll, dated Dec. 20. recites this Grant, and confirms it with the Addition of seve∣veral new Privileges. Tho. Mattyngham was constituted the first Chaplain.

After the Reformation it was incorpo∣rated by the Name of Warden and Bur∣gesses, and it continued so till the Reign of King James II. who granted them a new Charter, and incorporated them by the Name of Mayor and Aldermen, with Liberty to chuse a High-Steward and a Steward. So that their present Constitu∣tion is a High Steward, a Mayor, a Steward, and ten Aldermen: Out of these last mention'd they chuse two Bridge-ma∣sters every Year. The Mayor, the Stew∣ard, and the Mayor for the Year prece∣ding, are Justices of the Peace. The Mayor is Clerk of the Market, and Coro∣ner:
He is likewise Judge of the Court, which he is obliged to hold once in three Weeks, and oftner, by Adjournment. The Mayor and Aldermen chuse two Serjeants yearly, who bear the Mace. They have a Goal within the Corporation, not only for Debtors, but also to secure such Felons as shall happen to be taken there. The Mayor holds a Session twice a Year, and, in Conjunction with the Aldermen, has Power of making By-Laws for the Good of the Corporation.
They have a very good Market here every Wednesday, and three Fairs in the Year; on Wednesday in Whitsun Week, on St. Mary Magdalen's Day, i. e. 22d of July, and on that of St. Thomas the Apo∣stle.
The Revenue of the Corporation is but small, consisting chiefly of the Toll of the Market, the Toll of the Bridge, and three or four small Tenements.

The Town is situated in two Parishes, part of it in Bray, and part in Cookham, though they have a Chapel peculiar to the Corporation, founded by Mr. John Hus∣bands. The Minister is chosen by the Inhabitants in a Common Hall, called for that purpose. He is not obliged to attend the Bishop's Visitation. His In∣come is by Subscription, saving 14 No∣bles
from the Crown, in Consideration of the 100l. above-mentioned, which was paid into the Exchequer at the Dissolution of Monasteries, a good House, Garden and Orchard, a Close called Little East-more-Hill, given him by one Mr. Towns∣end, of Staple-Inn, and a small Slip of Meadow, lying in Foreleys, given by the Founder Mr. John Husbands.

James Smith, Es{que} Citizen and Salter of London, in the Year 1659. erected an Alms-house in that Part of the Town which is in Cookham Parish, and endowed it with 40l. a Year. It consists of eight Houses for eight poor Men and their Wives, so that every House has yearly 5l. and every Person a new Gown once in two Years. To this Benefaction of her Husband's, Mrs. Smith, his Widow, gave 8l. a Year more to the said Hospital, i. e. 1 l. to every House to buy them Wood. The Salter's Company are the Trustees of this Charity.
Mr. Smith left also 5l. 4s. a Year to be distributed in Bread, 2s. every Sunday to the Poor of Maidenhead, on Cookham Side, and to the Poor of the same Parish at large.

He gave also the Minister of Maiden∣head, 1l. a Year for preaching a Sermon on Charity every New Year's Day, and as
much to the Minister of Cookham for preaching another on Easter Monday, and administring the Sacrament to the poor Alms-People.

He order'd besides to be paid yearly,
l. s. d.
To the Church-Wardens of Cook∣ham, 0 05 0
To the Clerk of Cookham, 0 10 0
To the Chapel-Wardens of Mai∣denhead, 0 05 0
And to the Clerk of the same Place, 0 10 0
On a small Stone over the Alms-House, in Capitals, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: These Alms-Houses were erected, and built at the sole and proper Cost and Charges Of James Smyth,Sic. Orig. Esquior, Citizen and Salter of London, in the Year of our Lord, 1659.
DIV4.P: Mr. Ralph Pool gave 10l. a Year, issu∣ing out of his House called Munkendons, for the Poor of Maidenhead, to be distri∣buted in Bread, 4s. every Sunday.
Mrs. Poole settled a Farm of about 14l. a Year to buy Cloth to clothe the Poor of Maidenhead yearly, by Trustees chosen within the Corporation.
One Ring, a Taylor, gave a Tenement worth about 8l. a Year, to be distributed yearly among such poor House-keepers as receive no Alms within the Corporation.
Mr. Rixmond gave a Tenement of 9l. a Year to put out poor Boys Apprentices.
Mrs. Merrywid gave 5l. a Year, to issue out of her Houses in Maidenhead, to teach five poor Boys to read and write.
Four Pounds a Year was given for the same purpose by Mr. Abraham Spoor, and another Sum to put out Apprentices: But his Gift is not for above 20 Years to come.

The Bridge is maintained by the Cor∣poration, for which they have the Tolls allow'd them both over and under the Bridge; to which may be added three Trees given by the Crown yearly out of the Forest of Windsor, towards repairing the same.
The Barge-Pier divides the two Coun∣ties of Buckingham and Berks.

About the middle of the Town stands the small Chapel before-mentioned, where∣in is only the following Inscription, on a
Black Marble Grave-stone, in the middle Ile, in Capitals.

Q.P: Here lyeth interred the Body of John Whitfeild, Es{que} who dyed the 9th Day of Aprill, in the Yeare of our Lord, 1663. in the 46th Year of his Age.
Here lyeth also interred the Body of Mrs. Hannah Whitfeild, Widd. and Relict of the said John Whitfeild, who dyed the 5th Day of July, An. Dom. 1665. An°. Aetat. suae 49.

DIV4.P:
In an MS. in the Possession of Thomas Rawlinson, of the Middle Temple, Es{que} and F. R. S. is the following Account of an Estate (in this Place) formerly in the Possession of the Hospital of St. Nicholas at York, and at the Dissolution passed into o∣ther Hands, which the following Passage gives you a full Account of.
Page 80. Parcell. Possession. nuper Dne. Anne de Cleva ac antea Parcell: Possessi∣onum nuperi Monasterii de Bustlesham, alias Bisham, in Com. Praed.

FIrma scitus Manerii de Ives, cum suis pertinentiis scituatis, jacentibus, & existentibus, in Madenhithe, in Parochia de Bray, cum omnibus edificiis, hortis, pomariis, gardinis, terris, pratis, leasuris, pasturis, ac cum omnibus aliis commodi∣tatibus quibuscunque dicto Manerio spe∣ctantibus, sive pertinentibus, exceptis om∣nibus grossis, arboribus, boscis, subbos∣cis, Wardis, Maritagiis, Mineralibus, & quarr. Curiis letis, vis. franc. pleg. rele∣viis, herietis, finibus, Amerciamentis, quietis, escaetis, redditibus bonis, catallis, serviciis nativorum, felon. & fugit. felon de se & in exigend. praedict. condempnat. ut lagat. waif. & extrahur quorumcunque & omnibus advocationibus Ecclesiarum & Capellarum quarumcunque dicto Mane∣rio spectant. & pertin. sie nuper dimiss. Ricardi Noke, per literas Patentes pro term. Ann. expirat reddendo inde per Annum, vijl. xiijs. iiiid.

Firma totius illius pastur. vocat. Laver∣more, jacen. & existen. ad finem orien. Vill. de Madenheth, in Parochia de Cookeham,
in dicto Com. Bark. cont. per estim. vj acr. terr. viz. int. past. nup. Willielmi Dan∣vers, gener. ex. parte orien. & prat. nuper Thome Martin, Ar. ex parte occiden. & campum voc. Cookeham Ray, ex parte bo∣real. & communem Mariscum ibidem voc. Forgmore, ex parte austral. simul cum una acr. pastur. jac. in Maydenhed Field, in Paroch. de Cookeham, pred. in cultur. ibi∣dem voc. Brokefere, juxta Portam nuper Alicie Buckland, voc. Kermorles tenente extenden. in uno capite versus occiden. su∣per viam que ducit de Maydenhedd, usque le North Towne & in occiden. sup. claus. dicte nuper Alicie modo vel nuper in ten. sive occupatione Roberti Peck, vel assign. ann. redd. vjs. viijd. Ac tocius ill. sepa∣rat. Piscar. in rivolo et aqua Thamisis ac terr. insul. voc. The Eighth, in eadem a∣qua ex parte Com. Barks. Que quidem Piscar. in aqua pred. extenden. se xx pedes ex parte orien. de Madenheth Bridge, per totum dictirivoli aque Thamisis usque quen∣dam locum in eodem rivolo voc. Riddel Pole, Abuttan. super Paroch. de Clewer, ann. redd. viij s. Que quidem premiss. sunt parcell. dict. Man. de Ives, infra pred. Domin. de Braie except. omnibus grossis, Arbor. bosc. subbosc. miner. & quarr. pre∣miss. sic nuper dimissis Rogero Amyce, Ar. (inter al) per literas Patentes per tem.
ann. expirat. reddendo inde per annum, xiiijs. viiijd.

Firma tocius illius tenenenti & quatuor claus. cum suis pertin. jacen. & exist. apud Boynehill, ex parte Braie contin. per. estim. decem acr. terr. insimul jac. al. dict. Boyne∣hill Closes, in dicto Com. Barks. Quod quidem Tenementum et ceter. premiss. sunt parcell. Maner. de Ives, infra Do∣min. de Braie, predict. nuper dimiss. pre∣fat. Rogero Amyce, per literas Patentes modo expirat.

LIST.ITEM: Past in Fee Simple, Summa to∣talis Manerii de Ives, infra Dominium de Braie, per Annum, 16 14 9

DIV4.P: The Manor of Ives, per Annum, xvil. xiiijs. ixd. was Sold to Sir William Gar∣way, Kt. in Fee Simple, by Indenture dated the xxiiijth Day of October, 1617.
In an MS. Visitation Book, I find the following Pedigree of the Family of Aun∣sley inhabiting here.

LIST.ITEM: Tho. Aunsley, of Aunsley in Not∣tinghamshire.

... Daughter to William Parker, of Maydenhead.
Hen. Aunsley, of Mayden∣head.
Dorothy, Daughter to John Kempe, of Twickenham, Com. Middlesex.
Joan, Wife of... Atkynson.
Edmond Aunesley, of Maydenhead.
Margarett, Daught. to Sir Tho. Speeke, Kt. of North Lavington, Com. Somerset.
Maryel
Cecilia
Frauncis, 2d Sonne.
Henry Aunsley.
Elizabeth.
Anne.

DIV4.HEAD: WINKFEILD,
DIV4.P: Is a Vicaridge in the Deanery of Read∣ing; Patrons are the Dean and Chapter of the Cathedral Church of Salisbury, Incum∣bent the Reverend Mr. Gunnis.
On a Marble Grave-stone, lying in the Chancel, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Here lyeth the Body of THOMAS WINDER, Son of CUTHBERT WINDER, somtyme Vicar of this Parish, and Brother of SAMUEL WINDER, late also Vicar of this Parish; which Thomas Winder was a Cittizen of the Citty of London; and he hath given severall Legacies for ever, as well to the Poore, and to the Vicar and Clearke of this Parish; as also to the Poore and Minister, and Clerke of the Parish of Wokingham, and to the Poore of the Parish of Warfeild, who departed this Lyfe the 16 of January, 1651.
DIV4.P: On another Marble Grave-stone, laid at the Feet of the former, is this Inscrip∣tion.
DIV4.Q: Here lyeth the Body of CUTHBERT WINDER, eldest Son of JOHN WIN∣DER, who after a Pilgrimage of 44 Yeares, rendred up his Soule into the Hands of his Redeemer the 8th of Ju∣ly, 1654. leaving behind him 4 Sons, THOMAS, JOHN, CUTHBERT, and BARTHOLOMEW.
DIV4.P: At each Corner of the Grave-stone is engraved,

DIV4.HEAD: ECCE QUID ERIS.
DIV4.P: In the East Wall of the South Ile, is on a Brass Plate a Figure of one of the Yeo∣men of the Guard in his Coat, holding his Halbard in his left Hand, and his right gi∣ving a Loaf of Bread to two poor Men; beneath which is the following Inscrip∣tion.
DIV4.Q:
Here lyeth the Body of THOMAS MOUNTAGUE, borne in this Parish, where also he dyed, March 31. 1630. when he had lived almost 92 Yeares,
and had byn a good part thereof a Yeo∣man of the Guard, and a Freind to the Poore.

DIV4.HEAD: CLEWORTH,
DIV4.P: Is a small Village, distant about a Mile from New Windsor, on the Banks of the River Thames, and a Rectory in the Deane∣ry of Reading, was called Clure in Domes∣day Book. Patrons are Eton College, In∣cumbent the Reverend Mr. Horn, Senior Fellow, and Vice-Provost of that College.
In the South Ile is this Inscription en∣graved about a Grave-stone, in Saxon Characters.
DIV4.Q: Merci. .............. William Mane de Southcas..... passants par ici priez pur s'alme a Dieu. Amen.
DIV4.P: On a Brass Plate, fixed in a Grave-stone, is this Inscription in Capitals.

Q.L: He that lyeth under this Stone,
Shot with a Hundred Men himself alone;
This is true that I doe say,
The Match was shot at Oldfeild at Bray.
I will tell you before you goe hence,
That his Name was MARTYNE EXPENCE.

DIV4.P: In the East Window of the Chancel is the Figure of a Priest in his Habit, under whom are these Words yet remaining in Saxon Characters.
DIV4.Q: .... Johannis Coningham, Recto∣ris..... Regist................. Benefactorum suorum qui hanc fenestram.............. Anno Dom......
DIV4.P: On a Grave-stone, laid on the North Side of the Chancel, is this Epitaph.
DIV4.Q: Here lyeth the Body of THOMAS HAYES, borne 1613. dyed the 12th, and was buried the 24th of November, 1663.
DIV4.P: On another Grave-stone, adjoyning, is the following Inscription.
Here lyeth the Body of ALEXANDER HAYES, Gent. borne 1578. dyed the 9th, and was buried the 14th of August, 1661.
On a Brass Plate, fixed in a Grave-stone, is this Inscription.

Q.P: Here lyeth interred the Body of the Verteous Mrs. LUCIE ROBSON, Daugh∣ter to Sir WILLIAM WRAY, of the County of Lincolne, Knight and Ba∣ronett, and late Wife to Mr. JOHN ROBSON, Gentleman. She was a true lover of a godly and a powerful Mini∣stry, a despiser of the World, and a high prizer of our Lord Christ, in whose Faith she lived, and died in hope of a joyfull Resurrection by him, to whome be Glory for ever. Amen.
She died the 28th of May, and was bu∣ried the 1st of June, 1657.

DIV4.P: In the East Window are the Figures of St. George encountring the Dragon, and of St. Andrew holding a Cross Saltier.
On a Course Free Stone Grave-Stone, in the Chancel, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q:
In obitum AlexanderiSic. Orig. Hayes, Gen. 9 Novemb. 1665. Aetatis suae, Anno 26.
No other Stops but these are made use of on the Grave-stone. Heu jacet: hic haeres: florenti extinctus: in
Ad summum quicquid venerit ima: petit.
Nil aevi brevitate: tamen sibi: laudis ademptum
Aethereumque: obiit: munus obitre: nequit.
Ore: decens: bonus: Ingenio: facundus: & omni
Dexteritate: vigens religiosus erat.
Indeiget: haud urna versu nec marmore virtus
Hinc superest vivax: marmor et Ʋrna pio.
DIV4.P: On a Red Marble Grave-stone, in Ca∣pitals, is this Inscription.

Q.P: Here lyeth the Body of John Hayes, Gent. third Sonn of Thomas Hayes, Gent. aged XXVI. Years, who departed this Life the first Day of March, Anno Dom. 1673.
Under the same Stone lyeth the Body of Thomas, onely Sonn of the abovesaid John Hayes, aged 10 Days, who departed this Life the 18 Day of January, Anno Dom. 1672.

DIV4.P: In the South Ile, on a Greyish Stone, in Capitals, is the following Inscription.

Q.P: Here lyeth interred the Body of Francis Blomer,Sic. Orig. Gentheldman, who departed this Life the 17 Day of March, Anno Dom. 1672. aged 75 Yeares.
Here also lyeth the Body of Katherin his Wife, deceased Sept. 25. 1680. aged 77.

DIV4.P: On another course Grave-stone, in Ca∣pitals, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Sub hoc Positae sunt Sepulchrales Roberti Mason, de Agro Salopiensi, Generosi. Exuviae, qui obiit 4 7bris. Anno Dni. 1680. Aetatis suae 56.
DIV4.P: In the same Ile, on a course Free-stone Grave-stone, is the following Inscription.
DIV4.Q: M. S. Hic jacet Corpus JOHANNIS CROMPTON, Collegii Regal. Cantabr. Scholaris, filius natu max. JOH. CROMPTON, M. D ex ELIZABETHA, filia ANDREAE MEALE, de Midhurst, in Comit. Sussex, M. B. qui de sanitate corporis parum solicitus, dum animo excolendo nimis vacabat tabe consumptus, obiit X Die Januarii, 1702. Anno Aetat. XX°.
DIV4.P: On a Tomb, on the South Side of the Coemitery, is this Inscription in Capitals.
DIV4.Q: Here lyeth the Body of James Durdant, Gent. who departed this Life the 18th of January, 1661. in the 76 Yeare of his Age.
DIV4.P: In an MS. Heraldick Visitation, made, as I take it, in 1601. is a Pedigree of the Name and Family of Carmonds of this Place, viz.

LIST.ITEM:
Nicholas Carmond, of Cleworth, in Berks.
William Carmond, of Cleworth.
John, 2d Son.
John Carmound, of Cleworth.
Thomas Carmound, of Cleworth.
Richard 2d Son.
John Carmound, of Cleworth.
Alice, Daughter to Robert Chamber, of Bray.
Andrew, 3d Son.
2 Richard, 3 John.
Margarett, Wife of Prebant Nooke, of Braye.
Thomas Carmound.
Edith, Daugh∣ter to Rich. Hill, Widdow of.......... Browne.
Joane, Wife of Thomas Hall, of Wyndesor.
Alicia, Wife of Sylvester Hylton, of Cookeham.

DIV4.HEAD: OLD WINDSOR,
DIV4.P: Is a small Village lying near the Bank of the Thames, and a Vicaridge in the Hun∣dred of Ripplesmore, and Deanery of Read∣ing, in the Gift of the Lord Chancellor; present Incumbent is the Reverend Dr. La Croze.
In this Place is a Seat belonging to the Lord Viscount Weymouth.
In the middle of a fair Marble Slabb, on a raised Tomb, on the North Side of the Chancel, are the Figures of a Man in a Gown, and his Wife in her usual Habit, and near them the following Verses.

Q.L: A faithful Husband, and his loving Wife,
With their obedient Son here buried lye:
All which, by their religious Course of Life,
Left good Examples to Posterity.
And though their Bodies now sleepe in the Dust,
Their Soules, in Heaven, live among the Just.

DIV4.P: On another Plate of Brass, under the Man's Feet, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q:
Here lyeth interr'd the Body of HUM∣FREY MICHELL, Esquire, and Sur∣veyor
of Queene Elizabeth's Castle of Windsor, who deceased the 10th of October, An°. Dni. 1598. having two Wives, KATHERINE HOBBS, and FRANCES WALLER; by which Kathe∣rine, his first Wife, he had one only Son, viz. FRANCIS; by his second Wife FRANCES, he had SAMUELL his Son; and four Daughters, DORCAS, ELIZABETH, SUSANNA, and SARA.
DIV4.P: On another Plate, under the Woman's Feet, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Here lyeth interred the Body of FRAN∣CES MICHELL, second Wife of HUM∣FREY MICHELL, Esquire, and sole Daughter and Heir to FRANCIS WAL∣LER, Es{que} who deceased the 13th Day of May, An°. Dni. 1621. and left behind her three Daughters, DORCAS, ELIZABETH, and SARA: SUSANNA deceased in her Infancy.
DIV4.P: Lower, on the same Stone, is another Figure of a Man in a Cloak, with this Inscription.
DIV4.Q:
Here also lyeth buried the Body of SA∣MUEL MICHELL, Esquire, late Ser∣vant to King James, being one of his
Majesties Marshall of the Hall, who married ANNE, the only Daughter of ISAAC RUDSTONE, Esquire, and had by her two Sons, JOHN and HUMFRY. He departed this Lyfe the 15th of March, An°. Dni. 1613.
DIV4.P: On a Stone, fixed in the South Wall of the Chancel, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Sub hoc Depositum EDWARDI NORWOOD, ingenuae indolis: Aetatis prope 16 ex hac vita migravit, 26 Dec. 1629. Juxta quem reliquiae duorum fratrum ROBERTI et CAROLI infantium subjacent: Qui omnes, in diem Resurrectionis simul obdormiunt.
DIV4.P: On a Marble Grave-stone, near the En∣trance into the Chancel, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Here lyeth the Bodies of RICHARD POWNEY, Gent. and ANNE his Wife: The said Richard departed this Lyfe the 12th Day of August, Anno Dni. 1657. and ANNE the 22th of October, 1652.
DIV4.P: Upon a Grey Marble Grave-stone, near the former, is this Inscription.

Q.P: Here lyeth interred the Body of Cap∣taine RICHARD GRIFFIN, who depart∣ed this Lyfe the 29th of July, 1660.
Here also lyeth the Body of Martha, Wife of the said Richard Griffin, who departed this Life the 8th Day of May, 1692. in the 63d Year of her Age.

DIV4.P: On another Marble Grave-stone, ad∣joining, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Here lyeth JOHN WEST, late of Stepney-Heath, in the County of Midd. who dyed the 26 Day of February, 1665. aged 82. and left behind him one Daughter, ELIZABETH, Wife of JOHN POWNEY, Gent. of this Parish.
DIV4.P: On a Brass Plate, fixed to a Grave-stone lying under the North Window of the Chancel, is the following Inscrip∣tion.
DIV4.Q:
Here, in Expectation of a joyfull Resurrection, resteth the Body of Mr. FRANCIS KIBBLEWHITE, who
died the 7th Day of December, in the Yeare of our Lord, 1651. He tooke to Wife ELIZABETH, the Daughter of RICHARD WYATT, Citizen of London.
DIV4.P: Near this is another Brass Plate, fixed to a Grave-stone, bearing the following Inscription in Capitals.
DIV4.Q: Here lyeth the Body of ELIZABETH KIBLEWHITE, Wife of FRANCIS KI∣BLEWHITE, Gent. by whome she had 4 Daughters, viz. ELIZABETH, FRANCES, SIBELL, and MARY. She dyed the 10th of February, Anno Dni. 1647. Aetatis suae 45.
DIV4.P: On the same Stone, in Capitals, on a Copper Plate, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Here also lyeth the Body of Frances Dottin, Wife of Hen. Dottin, Gent. and second Daughter of Francis Kiblewhite, Gent. and Eliz. his Wife. She dyed the 26 of May, An Dni. 1701. Aetatis suae LXVI.
DIV4.P: On a Grave-stone, underneath the Al∣tar, is the following Inscription.

Q.P: Here lyeth the Body of THOMAS PULTON, Gent. the Sonn of Mrs. ANNE, and Grandson of Sir THOMAS ADAMS, Knight and Baronet, late Lord Mayor of London, who departed this Life the 7th Day of January, 1672. aged 22 Years and 5 Months.
Here also lies the Body of the said Mrs. Anne Pulton, who departed this Life the 28th Day of Aprill, Anno Domini, 1706. Aged 77.

DIV4.P: On a fair Monument, fixed to the North Wall of the Chancel, in double Columns, is this Inscription.

Q.P:
P. M. S. Parentum cineres suus hic adauget Virtute et traduce et proprio conspicuus, JOHANNES MICHEL, Vir in pessimis temporibus audacter bonus, in quibus nemo amicis amicior, propior propinquis, a semet magis remotus, Reliquit superstites Matrem, Uxorem, Fratrem, et Filium
Ineffabile suo lucro, damnum suorum Tandem cum reducem CAROLUM vidisset Charus Deo et Hominibus, Ad natale redit solum, Curas et sepulchrum, Annos quot habuit, tot vixit saeculi moribus parum donans, Multum suis.
Plene quinquagenarius expiravit, Octobris XXI. Anno Domini, MDCLXI.

Here lyeth interr'd ANNE, Daughter, and sole Heiress of ISAACK RUDSTON, of Boughton Mounchelsea, in the County of Kent, Es{que} Wife of SAMUEL, and Mother of JOHN and HUMPHREY MICHEL. She was afterwards married to WILLIAM DUKE, of Richmond, in the County of Surrey, Es{que} whose Relict she dyed the 24th Day of October, 1669. in the 81st Year of her Age.

DIV4.P: On the other Column is this.

Q.P:
Here lyeth also interr'd Benet, Daughter; and Co-heiress
(with her Sister ELIZABETH, afterwards Dame Oxenden) of MATTHEW READ, of Folkeston, in the County of Kent, Esqr; and Wife of JOHN MICHEL. She dyed the 12th Day of Octobr. 1683. in the 63d Year of her Age, leaving Issue JOHN, the only surviving Branch of this Family.

P. M. S. Hic juxta situs est HUMPHR AEDUS MICHELL, Deo servus, Regi subditus, Ecclesiae filius, Fidelis Fratrem, quem vivum amore summo Mortuum Pietate et Justitia pari Prosecutus est; Nepotemque et vivens & moriens Filii loco habuit. Caelibem vitam agens, Procul omni ambitu, procul negotiis, Deo & studiis solum vacavit. Cursum peregit, Fidem servavit. Eam, quae per charitatem operatur. Cujus Hospitium alendis pauperibus, Richmondiae, extructum,
Illustre Testimonium. Vitam cum morte commutavit XVI Novembris, Anno Domini, MDCXCVI. Aetatis, LXXXIV. Pietatis & Gratudinis Posuit Nepos Unicus ex hac domo superstes, JOHANNES MICHEL.

DIV4.P: On a Black Marble Monument, encha∣sed in White, fixed to the East Wall, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Sub hoc Monumentum jacet corpus Thomae Pulton, è Societate Lincoln. Armig. filius Edwardi Pulton, et Annae Uxoris ejus, mortuus est pater, sed mater adhuc inter vivos▪ filia fuit lllustrissimi Viri Tho. Adams, Baronett. Qui quondam fuit Major Civitatis Nobilissimae Londini defunctus, natus fuit sexto Die Augusti, Anno Do. 1648. Juvenis honestus et Moribus perquam bonus ex hac vita migravit septimo Die Janu. Anno. Domini, 1671. Aetatis suae vicesimo tertio tacitè hic quiescit corpus justorum expectans Resurrectionem.
DIV4.P: On a Black Grave-stone is this Inscrip∣tion.
DIV4.Q: Hic jacet Ursula Sontley, Uxor erat Roberti Sontley, in Sontley, Com. Denbeigh, Armig. & filia Thomae Corbet, de Longnor, Com. Salop, Armig. Obiit 10 Decem. 1671. Aetat. suae 63.
DIV4.P: On a White Grave-stone is this In∣scription.
DIV4.Q: Here lyeth the Body of Mrs. Elizabeth Orlebar, the Daughter of John Orlebar, Esqr; and Elizabeth his Wife, Daughter of John Whitfeild, Esqr; of Maidenhead, in this County. She died the 28th Day of Sept. 1703. in the Eightieth Year of her Age.
DIV4.P: On a Black Marble enchased in White, on the North Wall, in two Columns, is this Inscription.

Q.P: Here lyeth the Body of John Powney, Esqr; who died the 27 of January, 1678. in the 61 Year of his Age. John Powney, the onely Son of the above-named John Powney, died February the 24th, Anno Do. 1684. Aetat. suae 38.

Here lyeth the Body of Mrs. Elizabeth, the Wife of John Powney, Es{que} of this Parish: She was the Daughter and Co-heir of Mr. John West, late of Poplar, in the County of Middlesex. Shee dyed the 20th of November, 1672. in the 47th Year of her Age.

DIV4.P: On a fair White Marble Monument, fixed to the same Wall, is this Inscription.

Q.P:
Sacred to the Memory of JOHN POWNEY, of this Parish, Esqr; the 3d of the Name which adorns these Walls, and was an Ornament to the Place he lived in. Having been a great Example of Piety towards God, Loyalty towards his Prince, Affection towards his Relations, Munificent towards his Neighbours. He died in the bloom of his Age yet ripe in Vertue, and fit for Heav'n,
leaving a Widdow full of Sorrow, and three Sons full of Hopes.
He departed this Life the 30th of October, 1704.

DIV4.P: At the West End, on a Black Marble Grave-stone, is this Inscription.

Q.P: Here lyeth the Body of JAMES WELDON, Es{que} Son of GEORGE WELDON, of Cookham, in the County of Berks, Es{que} and of MARY his Wife.
He was borne in this Parish, January IX. MDCXLVIII. and dyed here in July XX. MDCXXXVI.

He gave CCCCl. to be lad▪ out in Land for an Augmentation to this Vicarage for ever, and also certain Tithes, called North Town Tithes, in the Parish of Cookham aforesaid, to buy Bread for the Poor of this Parish.

DIV4.P: On a White Free-stone Grave-stone is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q:
Here lyes the Body of William Smith, Es{que} of this Parish, who was
buryed July the 28th. 1708. aged 91 Years.
DIV4.P: On another Free-stone Grave-stone, Southwards, towards the West End, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Here lyes the Bodys of Coll. Richard Billing, Son of Richard Billing▪ of Billing, in Lancashire, dyed the 22d of July, 1707. aged 57 Years.
DIV4.P: On the Wall, painted at the West End, is this Inscription.

Q.P: This Church wasSic. Orig. beutifyed in the Year of our Lord, 1696.
John Capers, Andrew Cope, Church-Wardens.

DIV4.P: On a Tomb in the Church-yard, on the South Side, raised on Brick, is a Lion Ramp▪ and this Inscription.
DIV4.Q:
Here lyeth the Body of Grace Bowtell, Wife of Nathaniel-l Bowtell, of
Parham-Hall, in Suffolke, Gent. and Daughter to James Sadler, of London, Es{que} who departed this Life on All-Saints Day, Anno Domini, 1694. in the 47th Year of her Age, In certaine Hope of a glorious Resurrection, through the Merits of our Lord and Saviour Christ Jesus. Amen. Amen.

DIV4.HEAD: NEW WINDSOR,
DIV4.P:
Has the Addition of the Term New, to distinguish it from the last mentioned Place (out of whose Ruins it rose) and lyes at the East End of this County, and is divided by the River Thames (which washes the lowest Parts of this Place) from Eton in Buckinghamshire. It is a Vi∣carage situate in Ripplesmore Hundred, in the Patronage of the King. Of this Place we have no Account before the Saxon Times, when it was called Windleshore, from its winding Banks on the River. It was by Edward the Confessor bestowed on Westminster-Abbey, in whose Possession it remained but a short Time, being trans∣ferred to Will. the Conqueror in Exchange for other Lands elsewhere, by the Abbot
and Monks of that Convent. This Place was made a Free Borough, and had a Charter of great Privileges granted to it by King Edw. I. 1276. from which Time it has been gradually encreasing in build∣ing, &c. Much is said of this Place in Brady's History of Boroughs, pag. 38, and 84. and in Bohun's Debates in Parliaments pag. 332, and 333. where is the follow∣ing Charter, copied from the 141st. Page of the XXVth Volume of the laborious Mr. Dodesworth's Collections, among theCatalog. MSS. in Angl. pag. 197. MSS. of the Bodleian Library in Oxford.

EDWARDUS, Dei Gracia &c. sa∣lutem: Sciatis quod concessimus pro∣nobis et heredibus nostris, quod villa nostra de Nova Wndesore, de cetero li∣ber Burgus sit, et quod probi hominess nostri ejusdem Ville, et eorum Nere∣des et Successores liberi Burgenses smt, et Gildam Mercatoriam habeant, et eisdem Libertatibus et liberis Con∣suetudinibus utantur in eodem Burgo, quibus alii Burgenses aliorum Bur∣gorum nostrorum in Regno nostro ra∣tionabiliter usi sunt, et quod quieti sint de Theoloneo prestando in omnibus
Burgis et Villis, et Dominiis, per totum Regnum nostrum predictum, et quod habeant Porcos suos proprios de pannagio, quod dicitur Fencake, quietos in Burgo predicto. Et quod Iusticiarii nostri in Comitatu Berks itinerantes, tam ad Communia Pla∣cita, quam ad Placita Forestarum, I∣tinera sua de cetero teneant in eodem Burgo Et etiam quod Capitalis Gaola nostra ejusdem Comitatus sit in ipso Burgo liberatio dicte Gaole sem∣per facienda ibidem. Quare volumus, et firmiter Precipimus, &c. Niis Testibus, &c. Dat. per Manum no∣stram apud Windesore, 28 Die Maii, Anno Regni nostri quinto.

This Corporation consists of a Mayor, two Bailiffs, and twenty eight other Per∣sons, who are to be chosen out of the In∣habitants of the Borough, thirteen of which are called Fellows, and ten of them Aldermen, or chief Benchers, out of which the Mayor and two Bailiffs are to be elected. This Place sends also two Burgesses to re∣present it in Parliament, of whom you may see the List in pag. 35, 36, 37, and 38. of the Notitia Parliamentaria, Vol. I. Lond. 1715. 8vo. compiled by that wor∣thy Patron of, and diligent Enquirer into
the Antiquities of England, particularly those of the County of Bucks, Browne Willis, of Whaddon Hall, Es{que} This Town consists of several Streets, many of which lye near the Castle: The High Street, and largest, lyes Southward, where in 1380. 4 Ric. II. was erected a handsom Cross by John Sadler, which was much beautified and repaired, and a Crucifix placed on its Top in 1635. by Godfrey Goodman, Bishop of Gloucester, which, as I have seen in Letters to, and from the said Prelate, gave great Offence to some of the purer Saints of those Times, by whose Endeavours, I presume, it was demolish∣ed in the most impious Rebellion, begun 1641. there being now not the smallest Vestigia of its Existence. In this Street stands a fair Market-House, or Guild-Hall, on Pillars, erected in the Time of King Charles II. at the North End of which is a Statue, vested in her Royal Robes, of the late Queen Anne, with a Scepter in her right Hand, and a Globe in her left, and under her Feet this Distich, made by William Piesley, Es{que} Counsellor at Law, of the Middle Temple, in London, late Un∣der Steward of this Town, and Castle ad∣joining, in Gold Capitals, at the Charge of this Corporation.

Q.P: Anno Regni sui VI. Dni. 1707.
Arte tua; sculptor, non est imitabilis ANNA, ANNAE, vis similem sculpere? sculpe Deam.
S. Chapman, Pretore.

DIV4.P: At the South End is a Statue of his Royal Highness GEORGE, late Prince of Denmark, in a Roman Military Habit; in his right Hand is a Battoon, as a Gene∣ral, and his left is on a Globe set on a Pe∣destal with a Compass as an Admiral, erect∣ed at the sole Expence of Christopher Wren, Es{que} one of the late Representatives for this Town in Parliament, with this In∣scription under his Feet.
DIV4.Q: SERENISSIMO PRINCIPI GEORGIO PRINCIPI DANIAE, HEROIOMNI SAECULO VENERANDO, CHRISTOPHORUS WREN. ARM. POSUIT. MDCCXIII.
DIV4.P:
Near this Edifice stands the Parish Church, dedicated to the Honour of St. John Baptist; Vicar is the Reverend Tho.
Dawson, D. D. one of the Proctors in Con∣vocation for this County of Berks.

Against the South Wall, in the Chan∣cel, is a stately Monument, on the Top whereof stands an Angel, as it were sound∣ing a Trumpet, under whom is the Coat of Arms. On each Side the Atchievement stands an Angel; and lower, in an oblong Square of Black Marble, is the following Inscription.
DIV4.Q:
C. S. D. To the living Memory of Richard Bra∣ham, Esqr; descended from that anci∣ent Family of the Braham's in Comit. Suffolke.
Reposed in this holy Ground doth lye,
That Dust, which living taught, to dye;
Whose Crowne rewarded, Earth doth give,
As rare Instructions to the World to live.
He liv'd a Lyfe, hut as of Earth bereaven,
His Stage was Earth.
He dy'd a Death, as if thereby,
He found a better Lyfe, that could not dye.
Obiit
secundo Die Martii,
An. Salutis, 1618.
Aet. sue 33.
Leaving Elizabeth, his dear Wife, Daughter of Nathaniel Gyles, of New
Windsor, Esqr; (by whom he had Ri∣chard, John, and Elizabeth) sad Mourners.
DIV4.P: To the precious Memory of Susanna, the Wife of Rich. Braham, of New Windsor, in the County of Berks, Esqr; Daughter of Sir George Southcott, of Dartmouth-Castle, in the County of Devon, Knight.
DIV4.Q:
Ungrateful Urne, To thy sad Trust, Wee here retourne This sacred Dust.
Preserve it as a Thing divine,
Lett Peace and Honour entertaine it;
She was a Saint, be thou her shrine,
Lett neither Eye nor Aire prophane it.
Know this alone, Our Common Mother, Will hardly groane For such another.
Dyed
In the Year of
Nature 22.
Grace 1640.
May 5th.
DIV4.P: On the right Side of the Inscription stands a Figure in full Proportion, holding a Golden Spear in the right Hand, and a Book in its left. On the left Side is a like Figure holding a Golden Anchor.
A little lower is another Inscription on a Black Marble Monument.
DIV4.Q:
C. S. D. To the sweet Remembrance of Charles, the only Child of Richard Braham, Es{que} and Susanna his Wife, who dyed the 30th of November, in the Year of Grace, 1640. being eight Months old.
Death spied this new sprung Flower, which finding fit▪
For blessed Abrahames Bosom, gather'd itt:
The Soules of Babes perfume the Almighties Throne,
Rose buddes are far more sweet than Roses blown:
DIV4.P: Near to this Monument hangs a Coat of the Arms of the first mentione'd; as also a Penon of the same.
Engraven on a Stone, at the Foot of this Monument, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q:
.... Corpus Richardi Braham, de Shaw, Armiger dormit sub hoc
tumulo, obiit 2°. Martii, A. Dom. 1618.
DIV4.P: Engraven on another Stone adjoining, is this Inscription.

DIV4.HEAD: Charles Braham.
DIV4.P: Near the East End of the North Side of the Chancel, is a Monument set in the Wall, with this Inscription.

Q.P: The Body of Mary Sandes, Daughter of Robert Colte, of Woodwick, Esqr; and Elizabeth his Wife, Daughter and Heir of Margarett, Lady Roche; which Mary was Wife first to John Johnson, Es{que} Citizen and Goldsmith of London; after to Ralph Woodcock, Citizen and Alderman of London; and last of all to Miles Sandes, of Latimer, Es{que} who leading a Lyfe in Wisdom, Godlyness, Righteousness, Sobriety, Compassion, and much Mercy to the Needy and Af∣flicted, in Favour of God and Man, and in Faith, and much Assurance, joyfully triumphing over Death, yeilded her Spirit into Hands of God, through Christ Jhesus, the seaventh of Octobr. 1613. about the 74th Yeare of her Age.
Her Brother, Roger Colte, of Wood∣wiche, Esqr; left Issue John Colte, who left Issue by Frances, Daughter of Ralph Woodcock aforesaid, John, Rowland, and Mary Colte.

DIV4.P: Under this Monument lyes a Grave∣stone with this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Here lyes the Body of Mary Sandes, Widdow, who after a godly Life, joy∣fully triumphed over Death, and sweet∣ly slept in Christ, Oct. 7. 1613. being aged about 70 Yeares.
DIV4.P: On a Monument, set in an Arch of the said North Wall, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q:
Memento Mori. Neere to this Place lyeth Edith Bo∣stock, Widdow, late Wife of William Bostock, of New Windsor, Gent. Daughter of Besells Fettiplace, of Besells Leigh, in the County of Berks, Esquire. She deceased at Wabridge, in the County of Surrey, the 17th Day of June, Anno Dni. 1643. and was brought from thence by her Brother, William Fettiplace, Gent. (to be bu∣ried here) who willingly, and not with∣out
her desert, hath erected this small Monument.
Thrice blessed Soule; our blessed Jesus brings
Thee to Heavens Quire, with Angells there she sings,
Her Halleluiah's, 'mongst the heavenly Host,
To praise her Saviour, which she loved most.
DIV4.P: On another Monument in this Wall, Westward of the latter, is this Inscription.

Q.P:
M. S. Johannis Hickmore, de Aylisford, in Kantia, Generosi, Hospitii Cliffordien∣sis in Londino, et unius Filazario∣rum Curiae Communium Placitorum a∣pud Westmonasterium, in qua post∣quam summa cum Fide, et Diligentiâ, per sexaginta annos operam navavit, senio et laboribus contractus, Jesu mise∣ricordiam et immortalitatem sperans, sexto Die Martii, Aerâ Christianâ mil∣lesima sexcentesima quinquagesima sex∣ta, carnem et mortalitatem exuit, cum septuaginta et quinque annos vix∣isset. Carolum Hickmore, unicam (aliis denatis) relinquens sobolem ex Joanna Sunnibanke, una filiarum Caroli Sunnibanke, Sacrae Theologiae Doctoris, ex Provincia Brunswicensi,
in Germania oriundi, quae maerens (conjugi bene merenti et amantissimo) hoc Monumentum posuit.
Qui legis haec, horas tuas veloces et fugientes considera, vigilato, aeternita∣tem tuam cura, et memento te esse ho∣minem, ac inter mortuos annumeran∣dum.

DIV4.P: At the Foot of the High Altar lyes a Blue Marble Grave-stone, in the middle of which is fixed a piece of White Marble, and thereon this Epitaph engraved.
DIV4.Q: Here lyeth the Body of Richard Wash∣ington, Gentleman, who was Maior of this Towne and Burrough of New Windsor four Tymes: He departed this Lyfe the 12th Day of March, Anno Dni. 1617. being of the Age of 70 Yeares. First he had to Wife Joane, who departed this Lyfe the lost Day of August, Anno Dni. 1612. and afterwards Jane, who survived him; who, in remembrance of her late Husband, hath caused this Marble Stone to be laid here.
DIV4.P: On another Grave-stone, adjoining, is the following Inscription
DIV4.Q: Here lyeth the Body of Mrs. Joane Sunnibanke, Wife to Charles Sunnibanke, D. D. and sometymes Proebendary of Windsor: She departed this Lyfe, Nov. the 7th. 1662. being aged 86 Yeares.
DIV4.P: Under the Arch, on the South Side of the Chancel, is the Figure of a young Wo∣man to the middle, on a Monument bear∣ing this Inscription.

Q.P: Erected to the deare Memory of Re∣bekah Southcote, by Richard Bra∣ham, Esqr; who married Susannah, the elder Sister of this Rebekah. C. & D.

To the unspotrted Memory of Rebekah, the youngest, and Virgin Daughter of Sir George Southcote, of Dartmouth Castle, in the County of Devon, Knight, who dyed in the Year of her Age 20, and of Man's Redemption, 1642.
Q.L: Virgin Ases sleep securely,
Here's nor Sin, nor Shame to fright thee;
Thy bright Lampe doth shine too purely,
For Death's shaddoes to benight thee.
Holy Raptures feed thy Slumbers,
With Delight too high for Numbers.

DIV4.P: At the Foot of the Arch lyes a Grave-stone, whereon is her Name.
DIV4.Q: 1640. Rebecca Southcote.
DIV4.P: On a Grave-stone, at the East End of the South Ile, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Heere lyeth the Body of William Woodeson, the Son of John Woodeson, Gentleman, who was borne the 11th of June, 1661. and was buried the 28th of the same Moneth, in the same Yeare.
DIV4.P: On a Stone set in the Wall, by the up∣permost Window of the South Ile, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q:
Willyam Canon, sumtyme Mayer Of Wyndesore, and Elisabeth his Wife and all their Childerne; the which Willyam departed out Of this World the 5th Day off Decem∣ber, yn the yere of our Lord Gode,
1509. In the fyrst Yere oft the Rayne of King Hary the VIII.
DIV4.P: In the middle of the said Ile lyes a Grave-stone, whereon (in Brass Plates) are the Figures of a Man in a Gown, and a Woman in the Habit of the Tymes vailed; beneath their Feet this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Here lyeth. under this the Body of Richard Gallis, Gentleman, who was learned, and liv'd a godly lyfe, and was thrice Maior of this Cowne of New Windfor, which Office he commendably executed, and woethily purchased Praise by his discrete Govern∣ment. He did many charitable Deedes, and att his Death he gave to the Poore of this Cown, four Nobles yearly to continue for ever. Nere also resteth Alice his Wife, by whome he had 10 Sons and 2 Daughters. He dy'd on St. Anderews Day, An°. Dni. 1574. in the sixty and nynth Yeare of his Age: And the deceas'd the 24th of January, An°. 1580. When she had liv'd 57 Years.
DIV4.P: Under the Inscription are the Figures of the ten Sons and two Daughters en∣graven on Brass Plates.
On the Pillar whereunto the Pulpit is fix'd are the aforesaid Arms and Inscrip∣tion drawn on a Tablet, and hung there, with this Addition.
DIV4.Q: Perfected the 16 of Octobr. 1606.
DIV4.P: In the said South Ile is a Monument set in the Wall, having this Epitaph.

Q.P:
In hopes of a Resurrection to Glory, here, under, sleepeth the Body of Mat∣thew Day, Gentleman, who was five Tymes Maior, a constant Patron, and as a Treasury of the Rights and Cu∣stomes of this Town and Corporation. He married Mary (eldest Daughter) of George Dowdeswell, Gent.) his now surviving Widdow, with whom he lived 63 Yeares, 7 Moneths, and 16 Dayes, and by her had Yssue 6 Sons and 6 Daughters. After his Pilgri∣mage of 87 Yeares, 9 Moneths, and 22 Dayes, he finish'd his Course, the 28th of Decemb. 1661. His Piety towards God, his constant Love to his
Wife, his christian Care of his Chil∣dren, his Charity to the Poore, his A∣mity to all, as they gained him respect and Honour when alive, so being dead, doe imbalme his Name, both as an Or∣nament to his owne, and as a Pat∣terne to succeding Generations.

Here under also, in hope of the like Resurrection, lyeth the Body of the said Mary, the Relict of the said Matthew Day, who was a Woman worthy, and a Consorte meet for such a Man: She dyed the 29th ofSic. Orig. Agust, 1667. in the 87 Yeare of herSic. Orig. Aige.

DIV4.P: At the East End of the North Ile is a Monument set in the Wall with this In∣scription.
DIV4.Q:
Memoriae et cineri Elizabeth Uxor is dilectissimae optae. Praematuro (proh do∣lor!) fato, annis ab ortu viginti, mensi∣bus ab Uxoratu sex nondum peractis, in ipso atatis flore, non sine communi amicorum luctu, abreptae; Thomas Howell, moestissimus Maritus dum Ec∣clesiam Parochialem de West Horsley,
in Comit. Surr. sub auspicatisso Caro∣li Principis ac Domini sui imperio, Ano. Regni quinto. P. P.
DIV4.P: Lower, on the said Monument, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Johannes Whitsler, de Windesor, Ar∣miger, ex Martha Uxore, faemina om∣ni virtute laudatissima, septem obtinuit liberos; filios scilicet tres, Johannem, Knollum Thomam: Et quatuor ft∣lias, Martham supra dictam Eliza∣betham, Franciscam, et Dorotheam ex His, Johannes et Thomas, Mar∣tha, et Francisca adhuc supersunt, Reliquorum, quod reliquum est, in hoc jacet sacellulo: Ubi Dorothea, Knol∣lus, et Elizabetha, una cum Martha mater (cui ad latus undi{que} obdormiscunt) carnibus exuvias, mortalitatem{que} depo∣suerunt, certa spe, cum illa novissima evocarit Tuba ad vitam es gloriam, resurgendi.
DIV4.P: On each Side the last Inscription ar these Words.
DIV4.Q: Veni Domine Jesu.
DIV4.P: On a Grave-stone, at the upper End of the North Ile, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Here lyeth the Body of William Star∣key, Sonne of George Starkey, of New Windsor, in the County of Berks, Esqr; who was borne the third of July, 1643. and departed this Life the fourth of November in the same Yeare.
DIV4.P: On another Grave-stone, near the for∣mer, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Here lyeth the Body of George Starkey, Gent. who deceased May the 13th, Anno 1649.
DIV4.P: On another Grave-stone is this Inscrip∣tion.
DIV4.Q: Here lyeth the Body of Frances Starkey, Gent. who deceased the 7th of August, Anno 1655.
DIV4.P: On another Grave-stone is this Inscrip∣tion.
DIV4.Q: Here lyeth the Body of Mary Starkey, Gent. who deceased the 7th of August, Anno 1655.
DIV4.P: Engraven about a Grave-stone, in Brass, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Under this Stone resteth in hope of a joyful Resurrection, the Body of Humfry Fawset, Alderman, who was three Tymes Maior, and twise Balyff of this Towne of Windsor, deceas'd the 17th of January, 1622.
DIV4.P: On a Grave-stone, lying in the Body of the Church, is the following Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Here lyeth the Body of Mary Chettle, the Daughter of Henry Chettle; who dy'd the 2d of September, 1595. Aetatis suae 12. In Memory of whome, Robert Gwine, Yeoman of the Guard, hath caus'd this to be done.
DIV4.P: On three Scrowls proceeding from the Figure of a Heart, are these Words.

LIST.ITEM: II. In noviss. Die de Terra surrecturus.
III. Et in carne videbo Deum salvatorem.

DIV4.P: On another Grave-stone, in the mid∣dle of the Body of the Church, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Here lyeth buried Elizabeth Har∣den, Daughter of Rich. Harden, of Farneth, in the Parish of Prescott, in the County of Lancaster, Yeo∣men; sometyme the Wyffe of Mr. Symond Allen, Canon of Windsor, late the Wife of Henry Walker, Petti-Canon, the Son of John Walker, of Orford, in the County of Kent, Gentleman, by whome this Monument was erected, for her that liv'd vertuously 50 Yeares, beloved of all, and departed this World in a constant, approved Faith the 13th of October, 1580.
DIV4.P: On another Plate, under the former, is the following Inscription.

Q.L: Her Heart in Christ was firmly bent, her Faith was settled pure,
And oft from her these Speeches went, as Lyfe might then endure.
O Lord, said she, for Christ's sake, forgive me all my Sinn,
And give me Grace with perfect Faith, so to continue in.
My Soule to thee I do commend, my Body to the Ground,
My Hope and Trust is in the Lord, where Mercies may be found,
Whose Lyfe and Conversation her Neighbours witness be,
Who for the lak and miss of her do weep and mourne with me.
What-stony Heart can be so hard, to hyde within the Ground,
The Name and Fame of such a Wife, as rare is to be found?
So christianly did lead her Lyfe, so patiently to beare
Such Trialls as the Lord did send, to dye so in his feare,
Eternal Bliss, with Christ in Heaven, her Soule is for to have;
Deserved Fame will here remain, though Body be in Grave.

DIV4.P: On a small White Marble Tablet, on the South Side of the Body of the Church, in Capitals, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: JOANNI TOPHAM, J. T Arm. Qui vixit Ann. LXIII. Obiit VII. Eid. Decembr. Ann. MDCXCII. RICHARDUS F. Haer. ex Asse optimo Parenti. F. F.
DIV4.P: In the North Side of the Body of the Church, on a fair White Marble Grave-stone, is this Inscription.

Q.P: ALEXANDER BAKER, de Windsor Armig. Vir vere bonus, in omnibus vitae officiis justus, et fidus Regi, Ecclesiae, conjugi, et natis, Legum Municipalium peritus in summo Regni senatu concivis prudens, libertatis et Imperii, ut poterat, aeque studiosus, amicis amicissimus, uno ver∣be, notis omnibus percharum caput. Post mortem Conjugis unicae, privatè et tranquillè vixit, vergenti aetate literis & amicis totum deditus, 76. agens an∣num, pie tandem efflavit animam sum∣mo omnium desiderio.

Cujus memoriae Monumentum hoc extru∣endum curavit Filia ex numerosa prole unica superstes, Penelope Rob. Lyt∣ton Armig. Uxor, quam haeredem ex asse reliquit Pater amantissimus 4 Die Aug. An. Regni Regis Magnae Bri∣tanniae Jacobi 2di. primo, Aerae Chri∣stianae, MDCLXXXV.

DIV4.P: On a small White Marble Monument, fixed to a Northern Pillar in the Chancel, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q:
Juxta heic sita est MARIA, JOHANNIS DUGDALE (primogeniti WILL. DUGDALE, de Blith Hall, in Agro Warw. Armigeri) Uxor dilectissima; ALEXANDRI BAKER, de Nova Windsor, Gen. filia, quae IX Jan. Ao MDCLXX. puerperio defuncta, Cum ELIZABETHA matre THOMAE FARRER de Harrolt, in Com. Bedf. Arm. nata ac libens chariss.
Sic Orig. se ELIZABETHA trienni, et JOHANNE infantulo contumulatur.
DIV4.P: On a Black Grave-stone, at the En∣trance of the Chancel, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q:
Here lieth the Body of Thomas Lisle, Es{que} who was a long and faithful Servant to his Sacred Majesty Charles the 2d. and died the last Day of August, 1680. aged 79 Years.
Who knew this Person, knew him to his end
A faithful Subject, Husband, Neighbour, Friend;
He that shall doubt the Verity of these Things,
May be resolved by the best of Kings:
Great Charles proclaimes this Truth, he had enjoy'd
The truest Servant ever Prince employ'd.
DIV4.P: On a White Grave-stone of Free-stone, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q:
Here lyeth the Body of RICHARD VOYL, Gent. who departed this Life, July 20, Anno
Dni. 1707.
Aetat. 83.
DIV4.P: On a Black Marble Grave-stone is this Inscription.

Q.P: Under this Stone lyes interr'd the Body of HUMF. GRAVES, Esqr; one of the Grooms of the Privy Chamber to K. Charles 2d.
He departed this Life, Sept. 7. 1703. aged 71.

Here lyes the Body of MARTHA GRAVES, the Daughter of SAM. BARON, in the County of Norfolk, Es{que} and Wife of the said HUMF. GRAVES, by whom she had IssueSic. Orig. tow Sons, viz. BARON and CHARLES. She departed this Life, Sept. 28. 1679. in the 31 Year of her Age.
And, Here lyeth BARON, the eldest Son of HUMFR. and MARTHA, who dyed Oct. 15. 1683. aged 9.

DIV4.P: On another Black Marble Grave-stone is this Inscription.

Q.P: Here lyes the Body of Thomas Thorn∣ton, Esquire, who departed this Life in the true Faith of Christ the 21st of July, 1684. and now resteth in Peace, waiting for the Resurrection of the Just.
Q.L: His LoyaltySic. Orig. er'y one did admire,
From his young Age, untill he did expire:
His Father was the first in all this Land,
Plunder'd by the Rebels cruel Hand,
And from his State and Places turned out,
He wandered with his Family about;
Thus when he was for his dear Prince undon,
He went to rest in a better Kingdom,
Leaving bis Widdow, this Son, and Ten more,
King Charles the Seconds Kindness to emplore.
But waiting here inSic. Orig. hops to find Relief,
This Son, to all his dear Relations grief,
By wicked Hands was basely murthered,
And by his Friends in this Place buried.
Let us pity his worthy Family,
Who losing him had lost certainly,
All worldly Hopes, and pray Almighty God
To comfort them that made a Loss so sad.

DIV4.P: On another Black Marble Grave-stone, in Capitals, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Here lieth the Body of Mr. Thomas Hopwood, Gent. who departed this Life the 24th Day of October, 1696. in the 33 Year of his Age.
DIV4.P: On a White Free-stone Grave-stone is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Here lyes the Body of Susan Rutter, Wife of Tho. Rutter, Alderman, sen. of this Corporation, who departed this Life, February the 23d. Anno Dom. 1714. in the 58th Year of her Age.
DIV4.P: On a Black Marble Monument, on the North Side of the Chancel, in Capi∣tals, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Here lyeth the Body of Mary Jones, Relick of John Jones, Doctor of Lawes, Daughter of George Starke, Esqr; of New Windsor, who departed this Life the 12th of Sept. 1710. in the 66th Year of her Age.
DIV4.P: On a White Free-stone Grave-stone is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Here lyeth interr'd the Body of Mrs. Margarett Reeve, late Wife of Mr. Rich. Reeve, Alderman, departed this Life the 21 of June, 1716. Aetat. 70.
DIV4.P: On a small Black Grave-stone is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Here lyeth the Body of Katherine Elford, Daughter of Richard Elford, Gent. by Katherine his Wife, who departed this Life, June the 1st. 1712. aged 2 Years.
DIV4.P:
On a fair White Marble Monument, fixed to the North Wall, adorned on the Top with an Urn between two
Lamps, supported by fluted Dorick Pil∣lasters.

Q.P: M. S. Near this Place lies the Body of ELIZABETH, the dearly beloved Wife of CHR. TOWER, of Iver, in the County of Bucks, Esqr; and eldest Daughter to RICHARD HALE, of this Town, Gent. She departed this Life the 3d Day of December, 1709. in the 42d Year of her Age. To whose pious Memory her mournfull Husband hath caused this Monument to be erected.
Near this Place also lye three Sons of the said ELIZABETH and CHR. TOWER, who dy'd in their Infancy.

DIV4.P: On a White Marble Grave-stone, with∣in the Altar Rails, is a Chevron between 3 Mullets, and this Inscription.
DIV4.Q:
Here lyeth the BodeySic. Orig. of Mrs. Elizabeth Fletcher, third Daughter of SarjantSic. Orig. at Law Fletcher, of Bury St. Edmonds,
in the County of Suffolke, Esqr; She diea the 9th of February, 1687, aged 56.
DIV4.P: On a Black Marble Grave-stone, near the former, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Here lyeth the Body of Mrs. FRANCES LEE, Widow, Relict of FITZ-WlLLIAM LEE, of Bury St. Edmunds, in the County of Suffolke, Esqr; who departed this Life the 4 Day of May, 1702. and in the 69th Year of her Age.
DIV4.P: On another White Free-stone Grave-stone is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Here lyeth the Body of Mr. Algernoon Lee, the Son of Thomas Lee, Esqr; He was borne July the 5th. 1686. and departed this Life March the 15th. 168.
DIV4.P: On a Black Marble Grave-stone is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q:
Here lyeth the Body of Mrs. Alice Fletcher, who departed this Life
the 25th Day of March, 1709. aged 72.
DIV4.P: On a small square Black Marble Grave-stone is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: HereSic. Orig. lys Walter, the Son of Isaack Clopton, of Llandrimo, in the County of Montgomery, Esqr; who dy'd the 21st Day of Jan. An. Dom. 1704. aged 5 Days. Nascentes morimur, Morientes noscimur.
DIV4.P: On the South Side of the Altar, on a Black Marble Grave-stone, is this In∣scription.

Q.P: H. J. Laurentius St. Loe, Armiger, Vir Proinde in aliorum prosapiisSic. Orig. Historica Insignis Genere et Proavis suis Insignior.

Pietate erga Ecclesiam, Constantia erga Coronam,
Quae rite vocantur nostr Insignissimus Potentissimo Principi Georgio de Dania per multos annos Servus fidelis.

Serenissimae Majestati Annae Reginae HaudSic. Orig. dui subditus, Quia anno quo potita est illa Regnum Angliae Potitur illeSic. Orig. Regnum Caelorum Ubi moestis in terra Sociis relictis Beato Angelorum fruitur consortio.
Natus,
Denatus,
Anno Christi
1702.

DIV4.P: On a Black Marble Monument, sup∣ported with two Black Dorick Pillars, on the Top are Busto's of a Man, Woman, and two Daughters, kneeling on the North Side of the South Ile, and this Inscription.

Q.P:
P. M. S. Here under lyes the Body of Nazareth, Daughter of Robert Harris, of Reading, Es{que} Wife unto three Husbands. 1. Rich. Vaughan, Citizen and Cloth∣worker of London, by whom she had one Sonne and three Daughters, Ed∣ward, Elizabeth, Nazareth, and Rachael. He dyed, An. Dom. 1608.
2d. Zephaniah Sayers, Citizen and Haberdasher of London, by whom she had Issue 3 Daughters, Elizabeth, Nazareth, and Sarah, and dyed An. Dom. 1628.
3d. James Pagett, one of the Barons of the Exchequer, in the Reign of K. Charles the first, departed this Life, An. Dom. 1638.

After whose Death she continued a Wid∣dow 28 Yeares, in a pious and chari∣table Life, desiring to lye here intomb'd with her 2d Husband, yielded up her Spirit to him that gave it the 22 of July,
An.
Dom. 1666.
Aetat. suae 88.

DIV4.HEAD: RESURGAM.
DIV4.P: On a Black Marble Grave-stone, un∣derneath, is this Inscription.

Q.P: N. P. Here lies also the Body of Robert Harris, Sen. who departed this Life January the 19th, 1695.

Here lyeth also the Body of Mary his Wife, Daughter of Andrew Umfreville, of Farnham Royall, in the
County of Bucks, Gent. who departed this Life the 15th Day of Aprill, 1715. in the 80th Year of her Age.
On a Black Marble Grave-stone is this Inscription.
Q.Q:
M. S. Siste, Viator, morae pretium habes Cum sciveris, cujus hae sunt Reliquiae, Hic jacet in spe Resurrectionis Vir bonus, Fidelis Civis, Pius Christianus, suorum amantissimus, Pauperibus amicus, Utrisque ipse, ut et omnibus, dolendus Timotheus Eman, Generosus, Antiqua familia, Moribus antiquissimis:
Natus Londini,
Denatus Windesorae,
Undecimo Martii,
An.
Aetatis 57.
Domini, 168 0-1681.
Abi jam et Imitare.
Q.P: On another Black Marble Grave-stone is this Inscription.

Here lieth the Body of George Woodeson, Esqr; Filazer at Law, and Deputy Clark of the Signet Office,
who departed this Life the 4th of July, 1715. in the 67th Year of his Age.
Here also lieth the Body of Mary, the Wife of the abovesaid George Woodeson, who died the 13th of Aprill, 1684. in the 34th Year of her Age.
Here also lieth the Body of Ralph Woodeson, Son to the above-mentioned George and Mary Woodeson. He departed this Life the 11th of August, 1707. in the 31st Year of his Age.
As also two Daughters, Elizabeth and Sarah, who died Infants.
On a Black Marble Grave-stone is this Inscription.
Q.Q: M. S. Here lyeth the Body of Eleanor, late Wife of Christopher Marshall, Cit. of Lond. Daughter of Sam. and Margaret Gillman, of this Town; also two other Daughters, both named Margarett, and a Son Still-born.
Q.P: On another Black Grave-stone is this Inscription.

To the Memory of Moses Bruch, Gent. who was twice Mayor of this Towne, which Office he discharged with great Honour and Fidelity. He was also no less eminent for his Service to the pub∣lick, in a long and skilfull Practice of Physick, in which he was honour'd by the late A. Bishop Sheldon, being made a Licetiate through the whole Pro∣vince of Canterbury. He dyed March the 18th. 1700. aged 62.
HIC JACET Mrs. Martha Bruch, the Wife of Moses Bruch, of this Town, the Daughter of Mr. Nicholas Widemere, of Maidenhead. Obiit 6•. Feb. 1692. Aetat. 56.
Here also lyeth the Body of John Bruch, Gent. Son of Mathias Bruch, and Nephew to the said Moses Bruch, He dyed November the 13th. Anno Dom.
On a course Stone at the Entrance of the South Ile, in Capitals, is this In∣scription.

P. M. S. Heus Viator. Hic te defunctae virtut isSic. Orig. gatophylacium capis lacrymarum vectigal poscit. En tibi et quod lugeas et quod aemularis, ELIZABETHA DAY, Davidis Stokes, S. S. T. P. Mortalitatis suae et quinquemestris morbi reliqui in certam resurgendi spem. Hic deposuit Nata 7. D. Maii, Anno 1628. Septendecim justos Annos virgo egit Nupta pene totidem Inde duobus filiis, duabus filiabus ditata, Diuturnis doloribus et necessitati cedens Caelo maturior tandem succubuit Non operosis indicet Quisque meruit Conjugalis, filialis, ac maternae pictatis exemplar suis, sibi dum fuit moribus optimum conscripsit Epitaphium cum est merenti Monumentum dixisse; vixit.
Obiit ult. Die Dec. 1661. M. Day, S. S. T. P. charissimae Uxoris M. P.
On a White Grave-stone is this In∣scription.
Q.Q: Here lyeth interred the Body of Anne, the Wife of Thomas Willascey, the only Child of Alexander Balam, deceased, and Anne Balam Widdow, who departed this Life in the Faith and Hope of a glorious Resurrection, Aprill the 12th. 1698. in the 31 Year of her Age.
Q.P: On a fair White Marble-Tablet, on the South Wall of the middle Ile of the Chancel, in Capitals, is this Inscription.

Near unto this Place lyeth buried the Body of Hartgill Baron, Esqr; late one of the Clercks of his Majesties Privy Seale, and Secretary to his Highness Prince Sic. Orig. Rupart, Constable of the
Royal Castle of Windsor. He dyed the last Day of November, and was buried here the 4th Day of December, 1673.
Near him also lye buried Hartgill, Penelope, and Lucy, his Children.
Here also lyeth Anne his Wife, Daughter of Phil∣lip Bartlet, Esqr; of Hamsted, in Middles. who dyed Feb. 22. 1687.
In the South Ile, on a White Free-stone Grave-stone, is this Inscription.
Q.Q: Here lyeth the Body of JOHN PILE, Mr. of Artes, and Fellow of Kings Coll. in Cambridge. He departed this Life, Dec. 27. 1710. aged 28 Years.
Q.P: In one of the South Windows is a small Oval Free-stone Monument fixed, with this Inscription.
Near this Place lyeth the Body of LUCY HEMING, the Wife of JOHN HEMING, who departed this Life the 28 of August, 1699. in the 43 Year of her Age.
And also John Heming, the Husband of Lucy Heming, abovesaid, who dyed in the 47 Year of his Age. 1704.
On a Black Marble Grave-stone, in the same Ile, is this Inscription.
Q.Q: Here lyeth the Body of Mr. William Galland, who was twice Mayor of this antient Corporation. He died the 2d of November, 1672. and was aged 64 Yeares.
Q.P: On another Black Marble Monument is this Inscription.

Here lieth the Body of Mrs. Elizabeth Galland, the
Wife of Mr. William Galland, junr. She dyed the 3d of August, Anno Dni. 1691. in the 43d Yeare of her Age.
And also the Body of the foresaid Will. Galland, Gent. who departed this Life in Hopes of aSci. Orig. beter in the 52d Yere of his Age, May the 6th. 1693.
On a White Free-stone Grave-stone is this Inscription.
Here lyeth the Body of Mrs. Mary Grape, who departed this Life (the virtuous, dear, and truly loving Wife of Mr. James Grape. Town-Clerk of this Place) 25 of March, 1717. aged 35 Years.
HereSic. Orig. is also interr'd Three of their Children, viz. Charles, Thomas, and Anne.
On a polished Black Marble Monu∣ment (in a Place set apart for the Fami∣ly) is this Inscription.
Q.Q:
Hic jacet corpus RICdi. HALE, Gen•. Juxta reliquias RICdi. HALE, avi, Et EDWARDISc. Orig. HALES, Patrui, ejus Ob. Die 4 Maii, An.
Dom. 1703.
Aetat. 64.
Q.P: On a White Free-stone Grave-stone, in the middle Ile, is this Inscription.
Here lyeth the Body of Mrs. Anne Porter, the Wife of Mr. John Porter: She departed this Life the 27 of July, 1710. in the 57 Yeare of her Age.

Here lyeth also, expecting a joyfull Resurrection, the Body of Mr. John Porter, who was twice Mayor of this Town; which Office he performed with Honour and Fidelity, frequently relieved the Poor, and gave several considerable Legacys to his Relations. He dyed the 16th Day of February, Anno Dom. 1711. aged 66 Yeares.
On a Black Grave-stone is this Inscrip∣tion.
Q.Q: Here lyes the Body of Mr. William Meritt, Harbinger to his late Majesty King William and her present Majesty Queen Anne, who departed this Life March the 31st, 1705. aged 49.
Q.P: In the North Ile, on a White Free-stone Grave-stone is this Inscription.
Q.Q: Here lyeth the Body of James Wolthorp, sometime Footman to K. Charles the 2d, and afterward to his Royal High. Pr. George of Denmark, Who departed this Life Apr. 4. 1708. agedSic. Orig. 5 Years.
Q.P: On another course White Free-ston Grave-stone is the following Inscription.
Here lyeth the Body of JANE CURTIS, the Wife of JAMES CURTIS, who departed this Life the 18th of Janry. 1710. aged 56 Years.

DIV4.P: On another Greyish Free-stone Grave-stone is this Inscription.

Q.P: Here lyeth the Body of Mrs. Mary Clarke, the Wife of Mr. John Clarke: She departed this Life 19 of Aprill, 1703. in the 53 Yeare of her Age.
Here also lyeth the Body of the above named Mr. John Clarke, late Mayor of this Towne, who departed this Life the 14th. of February, Anno Domini, 1710. aged 73 Years.

DIV4.P: On a Desk at the East End of the North Chancel, lyes a Vellum Book in Folio, containing an Account of the Be∣nefactors and Benefactions to this Church, from which take the following Abstract.
