WILLIAM EVINGTON, of New Wind∣sor, Es{que} by his Will dated Mar. 4. 1487. gave to the Vicar, the Vicaridge House over against the Church.

Feb. 15. 1503. JOHN TOMPSON, and WILLIAM HUNTRED, Chaplains, and JOHN COMB, Gent. by a Deed gave to the Corporation of New Windsor, 4 Te∣nements in Sheer-Street, that they might elect poor Persons, Men or Women, to inhabit in them. These People are said only to have been Feoffees in Trust from William Paynell, and Thomas Hunt, who are judged the true Benefactors.

THOMAS BROTHERTON, alias HUNT, by a Deed bearing Date 25 Aug. 1510. for the Support of 4 Alms-Houses in Sheer-street, gave 14 Acres of Pasture and Wood Ground, called Butter-Stoakes; 3 Acres and a half of Arable Land in Church Field; 2 Acres of Wood Ground call'd Scott's Grove; one Acre of Arable in a Field called Pidwell; and one Parcel of Meadow lying at Stakes; all the Lands in the Parish of Warfield in Berkshire, va∣lued at 10 l. per Annum; two Acres of Land in Warfield Common Field, called Ferris Hill, at the yearly Rent of Two Shillings per Annum.

THOMAS JENKINSON, of New Windsor, Gent. by his last Will made about the Year 1596. gave 5 Acres and an half of Land in the Parish of Rushcombe in Berk∣shire, called East Mead and the Eight, that the Profits should be distributed to such of the poor Inhabitants of this Place, as shall be approved of by the Vicar, and eldest Alderman of this Corporation.

THOMAS NEEDHAM, of this Place, Gent. by his last Will, dated Aug. 1. 1603. gave to the Vicar and Church-Wardens, and to their Successors for ever, 3 Houses in New Windsor; two near the Church-Gate, and one in Pescod-street, the Rents of which are to be disposed of on each Sunday to Twelve poor People of the Parish, not of the Alms-House.
THOMAS ALDEM, of this Place, Gent. by a Deed dated 23 May, 1604. gave a Close of Pasture Ground, near Puttock's Gate, in this Parish, to build Pest Houses.

WILLIAM DAY, Son of Matthew Day, Alderman of this Town, gave a House and Garden in Pescod-street, by a Deed dated 16 Aug. 1664, the Rent of which was to be distributed to such of the poor Inhabitants, as the Vicar and the three eldest Aldermen shall approve of.

The aforesaid William Day did by ano∣ther Deed dated 28 July, 1668. give 4
Acres of Meadow Ground lying in Mead∣hay, in the Parish of Langley, in Bucking∣hamshire, for the same Uses, to be distri∣buted by the Mayor, three eldest Alder∣men, and Chamberlain of the Town for the Time being.

RICHARD GALLIS, of this Place, Gent. gave by Indenture, dated 30 July, 1666. a Legacy to this Corporation, with which was bought Munday Close, lying between Woodbridge-lane, and Moat-Park, in this Parish, the Revenues of which he assign∣ed to the Support of the 4 Alms-Houses.

This Parish bought of Francis Ridley, of Windsor-Castle, Es{que} for 36 Pounds, by Indenture dated 20 May, 1673. one Acre, and one Rood and an half of Meadow ly∣ing in Meadhay, in the Parish of Langley March, in Bucks, the Profits to be applied to the Use of the Poor of New Windsor.

Arch-Bishop LAUD, by his last Will, gave 50 Per Annum to Apprentice poor Boys, and for marrying of poor Maidens in this Parish, which was settled by a Deed dated 2 Octob. 1672. by Sir John Ro∣binson, Bar. and the other Executors.

Dr. CHAILONER, Rector of Agmonde∣sham, in Buckinghamshire, by his Will about 1621. gave, after the Decease of Christian his Wife, an Annuity of 6 Pounds out of his Estate in East Oakley,
Fifeild and Bray, to be distributed half yearly to Twelve of the godliest Poor of this Parish, to be chosen and changed yearly by the Dean of Windson, Mayor and Minister of the same Town. This com∣menced 25 Mar. 1637.

JANE BALDWIN, of Hillington, in Buck∣inghamshire, Widdow, for 60 Years, from 1671. gave 4 Acres and a half of Arable Land in Meadfield, in the Parish of Lang∣ley, in Buckinghamshire, the Rent of which, Two Pounds Twelve Shillings, is appro∣priated to the Use of the Poor of this Pa∣rish.

RICHARD REEVE, of Dagnall, in Buck∣inghamshire, Gent. by a Deed dated 11 October, 1676. gave to this Corporation a Close of Pasture Ground in the Parish of Wingfeild, in this County, five Acres of Land, the Rents of which are to be distri∣buted by the Mayor, 4 senior Aldermen, senior Church-Warden, and senior Over∣seer, who are to nominate 50 poor People who receive no other Charity, to be paid yearly, on Jan. 12. and July 12. one Shilling in Bread, all to continue du∣ring their Lives, and their Vacancies to be supplied by the aforesaid Trustees.

The same Gentleman, by a Deed dated Aug. 20. 1688. gave four Brick Tene∣ments, or Alms-Houses, near the Pitts∣fields,
with the Gardens, for the Use of Four poor Women during their Lives (except removed for any heinous Crimes) to be elected by the Mayor, two senior Aldermen, Chamberlain, Vicar, and two senior Church-Wardens, within two Months after any Vacancy; and upon their Default, the Election to lapse to the Dean and Canons of Windsor. The Per∣sons to be elected are to be upwards of 50 Years of Age, Members of the Establish'd Church of England, and not to Marry af∣ter their Election, upon Pain of Expulsion.
. The same Gentleman, by his last Will, dated 9 Decemb. 1688. gave 200 Pounds to purchase Lands for the Support of the Alms-Houses, and 100 Pounds towards finishing of the New Market-House here.

KATHERINE CAREY, late Wife of John Carey of Stanwell, in Middlesex, Es{que} by a Deed dated Aug. 1. 1673. gave 100 Pounds to be distributed to 6 poor Widows, at the Discretion of John Carey, and Giles Gent, Esqs; John Carey, by a Deed dated Dec. 20. 1679. also charged an Annuity of 6 Pounds Per Annum, for ever, on the Catherine Wheel in Colebrook, to be appli∣ed to the same Uses. The Election of the Widows to be in the Mayor and Burgesses, in a Common Hall held for that end.

WILLIAM GALLAND, late of New Wind∣for, Gent. by his last Will dated 13 April, 1693. gave 3 Pounds per Annum, out of a House called the Three Tuns there, to be pay'd at two half yearly Payments, and laid out in Bread for the Poor, at the dis∣cretion of the Mayor, 3 senior Aldermen, the Church-Wardens and Overseers of the Poor.

It appears by a Decree of the Commissi∣oners for charitable Uses, held in the Ve∣stry of the Parish Church of Clewar, A∣pril 6. An. Reg. Jac. I. 7• That the Com∣missioners decred one John Phippes, Owner of a Tenement in More-street, and of a Tenement and 4 Acres of Land at Clewar, his Heirs, Executors, &c. should stand chargeable with the following Payments, viz. 10s. to be pay'd quarterly to the Poor of New Windsor; Six Shillings to the two poorest Couples that shall be married within the Year, and 3 s. and 4 d. to the Church, payable at Easter, which several Sums were decreed to be in full of the Benefactions design'd by the last Will of Henry Franklin, made Anno 17 Reginae Eliz.

It appears by the Copy of a Deed kept in this Vestry, dated 16 July, 8 Jac. I. that there is issuing out of a House next joyning to the Pest-House, the annual Rent
of 3 s. 4 d. to the Poor, which seems to have been the Gift of William Lorde, of this Place Smith.
Mrs. MARGARET OSBOURNE, by her last Will, gave 25 Pounds towards the Founding of a Stock of Corn and Coles for the Poor of this Parish.

ANDREW WINDSOR, late of Bentley, in Hampshire, Es{que} by his last Will, 2 Aug. 1653. gave 200 Pounds towards founding a Stock to employ the Poor in the Clothing Manufacture, with which a Rent Charge of 14 Pounds per Annum, payable out of Wind∣sor-Mill, which being sold to Queen Anne, in lieu of it a like Rent Charge was settled by a Deed dated 24 June, 1705. payable out of the Butcher's Shambles in the Mar∣ket Place of this Town.

Doctor John Heaver, late Vicar of this Town, Prebendary of the Church of Wind∣sor, and Fellow of Eton College, gave 100 Pounds, the Interest of it to be applied to the Apprenticing poor Boys in the Parishes of Eton, and Windsor.

WILLIAM CHILD, Mus. Dr. late of Windsor Castle, gave 50 Pounds to this Corporation, for such charitable Uses as the Mayor, &c. shall think fit; with which they have settled an annual Charge of 5 Pounds towards binding one poor Boy Apprentice.

HENRY LUCAS, late of London, Es{que} founded an Hospital at Wokingham in Berkshire, for 16 poor Brethren, 9 of which are to be Natives of Berkshire, and elected by the following Parishes, each in their turn, Wokingham Parish, Arberfield, Wokingham Town, Finchamstead, New Windsor, Easthamstead, Clewar, Old Wind∣sor, Barkham, Binfeild, Hurst, Bray, Sandhurst, Winckfeile, Swallowfeild, and Sunninghill.

Mrs. MARY BARKER, late of London, Wi∣dow, by her last Will, dated 21 Nov. 1704. gave 300 Pounds, to purchase Lands with∣in 10 Miles of this Place, for the Sup∣port of a School-Master and School-Mi∣stress in New Windsor, and in the Tything of Inglefield, in the Parish of Egham in Surrey, and in Yately in Hampshire, to∣wards teaching of the poor Children of the said Parish to Read and Work.

Mrs. ELIZ. METCALFE, by her Will dated 14 Octob. 1709. late of Isleworth in Middlesex, Widow, gave 80 Pounds, the Interest of which is to be given to 4 poor House-keepers not receiving Alms, 2 to be elected by the Vicar, and 2 by the Over∣seers, and to be pay'd half yearly.

JOHN CLARK, late Mayor of this Town, by his Will dated 27 Decemb. 1710. gave 60 Pounds towards building a Cha∣rity
School in the Church-yard, or else∣where, as the Trustees shall thind fit. And by a Codicil dated 4 Feb. 1710=17311. 50 Shil∣lings more was charged on his Dwelling House in New Windsor, to be pay'd Eight Days after Shrove Tuesday, to Twenty poor House-Keepers not receiving Alms, at the discretion of the Minister and Church-Wardens for the Time being.

This Town has a weekly Market, on every Saturday, and 3 Fairs, on June 24. Octob. 16. and on Easter Tuesday. The Manor of this Borough was Lett in Lease by King James I. 1602. to this Corporati∣on, to pay annually to the Crown a Quit-Rent of Four Pounds, Four shillings and Five Pence.

DIV4.HEAD: WINDSOR CASTLE.
DIV4.P:
In my Account of New Windsor, Page 56, I mentioned that the Manor of this Place came into the Possession of the Crown by an Exchange at the Conquest, when also a Castle was built here, which Domes-Day Book tells us contained half a Hide of Land, in these Words,—Terra Ra∣dulphi, filii Seifridi, Radulfus filius Seifridi, tenet de Rege Clivore, Pro quinque Hidis,
modo pro quatuor Hidis et dimid. Caste llum de Wyndesores est in dimidia Hida. This Castle King Henry I. re-edified and enlar∣ged, and kept his Whitsontide here in 1109. where all his Nobles attended him. Shortly after, in a Treaty of Peace concluded between the Usurper Stephen and King Henry II. this was termed Mota de Windesore. When King Richard I. went into the Holy Land, and had delegated an equal Authority to the Bi∣shops of Ely and Durham; the first of whom taking Possession of the Tower of London, the last retired hither as the second For∣tress of this Nation. Queen Eleanor, Con∣sort to King Edward I. took much delight here, and here she bore some of her Chil∣dren: In the Reign of her Son Edward II. his Queen was delivered here of Edward of Windsore, well known afterwards to France and Scotland, by the Name of Edward III. To him this Place owes most of its present Magnificence; here he employed Work∣men for many Years, under the directi∣on of the famous William of Wickham, af∣terwards Bishop of Winchester: He seems to have began this in 1348. And though Writs were issued out to the Sheriffs of several Counties to impress Labourers, &c. into the Service, yet the Buildings were scarce ready for Glasing in 1355; nor was it finish'd till 1368. In future
Kings Reigns Additions were made, as the Fabrick adjoyning to the King's Lodg∣ings, in the upper Ward by King Henry VII.
In the Windows of King Henry VIIth's Closet are these Coats of Arms.
I. A Portcullis.
II. A White Rose within a Red, the first the Badge of the true Heirs to the Crown, viz. the House of York, the other that of Lancaster.
III. A Red Rose.
Over the Chimney, in the Gallery, are,
A Lion, a Dragon, an Antilope, a Bull, a Hart, a Faulcon crowned, standing on the Root of a Rose Tree, with Roses bud∣ding out of it.

The new great Gate, at the entrance of the lower Ward, was built by King Henry VIII. other Additions were made by King Edward VI. and his Sister Queen Mary erected a curious Fountain in the middle of the inner Court, into which Water was con∣veyed from Blackmore Park, near Wink∣field, which served the whole Castle. Queen Elizabeth made the Terrace Walk on the North Side, all faced with Free∣stone, from whence is a delightful Prospect down upon Eton College, the Thames, and the neighbouring Country.
Over the Door of the Chapel, in the King's Lodge, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: This Chapel was built, 1571. E. R.Queen Elizabeth.
DIV4.P: King Charles I. An. 1636. built the Gate at the East End of the Terrace, with the Draw Bridge leading into the Park. But during the Time of the long Rebel∣lion, the Buildings, &c. run much to Ruin, which were at a vast Expence at the Restoration repaired, beautified, and a handsome Magazine of Arms placed here by King Charles II. The Lodgings were much improved in Painting, Mag∣nificence, Beauty and Convenience by King James II. and William III. so that now they not only rival, but are ac∣counted by impartial Judges, Foreigners as well as Natives, superior to the so much exalted Palace of Versailles. The Situation of this Place is so very fine, and worthy Observation, that Sir John Den∣ham, in his Cooper's Hill, has celebrated it in the following manner.

Q.L: Windsor, the next (where Mars with Venus dwells,
Beauty with Strength) above the Valley swells
Into my Eye, and doth it self present
With such an easy and unforc'd Ascent,
That no stupendous Precipice denies
Access, no Horror turns away our Eyes:
But such a Rise as do's at once invite,
A Pleasure and a Rev'rence from the Sight.
Thy mighty Master's Emblem, in whose Face
Sate Meekness, heighten'd with Majestick Grace:
Such seems the gentle Height, made only proud
To be the Basis of that pompous Load,
Than which a nobler Weight no Mountain bears,
But Atlas only that supports the Spheres.

DIV4.P: The excellent Translation of this Part of the foregoing Poem, by Mr. Pengry, of Brazen Nose College in Ox∣ford, and printed there in 1676. 4to. I cannot omit.

Q.L: Proxima (Martis Amor, Venerisquè haud (infima cura)
Per pulchrè munita meos Winsora gradatim
Ima è valle tumens oculos incurrit, in altum
Tam modicè surgens, tam lentè, nullus ut horror,
Nulla jugi praeceps Feritas ascendit, & idem
Delect atque oculum locus, & castigat eundem.
Talem se placido Dominus Tuus ore ferebat;
Talis in Augusta sedit Clementia fronte.
Is tuns & fastus dignatae pondere tanto;
Sic caput attollis sola sub mole superba,
Qua vix majorem fert Atlas, maximus Atlas
Caelumquè aethereosquè humero qui sustinet orbes.

DIV4.P: This Description is given us in polite Verse by Mr. Pope, in his Windsor Forest, Lond. 1713. Fol. pag. 13.

Q.L: With Edward's Acts adorn the shining Page,
Stretch his long Triumphs down through every Age,
Draw Kings enchain'd; and Creffi's glori∣ous Field,
The Lilies blazing on the Regal Shield.
Then, from her Roofs when Verrio's Colours fall,
And leave inanimate the naked Wall;
Still in thy Song should vanquish'd France appear,
And bleed far ever under Britain's Spear.

DIV4.P:
This Castle consists of two square Courts, with a Tower betwixt them, which are also called three Wards. The higher Ward is call'd the inner Square or Court,
the middle Ward the Tower, and the low∣er Ward the outer Square. In the inner Square, toward the East, is the Royal Pa∣lace, and in the Middle of the Square is a very fine Statue of King Charles II. on Horseback, erected in the Year 1680. On the Park-side of the Square, to the North, are the Royal Apartments, with those of the Officers of the Houshold. The rest of the Square composes the Apartments of the Officers of the Crown. The Entrance to the Royal Apartment is through a Ve∣stibulo, supported by Pillars, with some antick Bustoes in the Niches; from whence you ascend the great Stairs to these Apart∣ments on one Side; and on the Right Side of the Vestibulo, through a little Court, up another Pair of Stairs to St. George's Hall on the other Side. The Domes of these Stair-Cases are painted. From each of these Stairs you pass into a Guard-Hall, which is finely embellished with several Sorts of Arms, artfully disposed into Fi∣gures, as at the Tower of London. In the Cieling is Britannia on a Globe, the Indies offering her Riches, and Europe a Crown; all surrounded with a Circle in Form of a Snake. Above the Chimney of one of these Halls is the Picture of Prince George of Denmark on Horseback, excellently done by Mr. Dahl; and that of the late
King of Sweden over that of the other, In the Presence Chamber, over the Chim∣ney, is Judith and Holofernes, an admi∣rable Piece; and over the Door St. Mary Magdalen, masterly done. There is ano∣ther Magdalen, an Original, in the Privy Chamber; and another Judith over the Door. In the Gallery, over the Door, is the Roman Daughter giving Suck to her Father in Prison. In the Bed Chamber is ano∣ther Judith over the Closet-Door, and the Innocents over that of the Chamber. In the Cieling of the Closet the Story of Leda and the Swan is wonderfully performed. In the Dining Room all Sorts of Fish and Poultry, and Fruit are very naturally re∣presented; and in the Gallery there is a Picture much taken notice of for the Live∣liness of the Light of a Candle, by which an old Woman is seen reading. In the Room of Audience, over the Chimney, is her Royal Highness the Princess of Orange, Mother to King William; and the Dutchess of Richmond, with this Inscrip∣tion; —Numero Deus impare gau∣det. In the Cieling is King Charles II. supported by Peace and Victory. In short, every Apartment that composes this Palace is spacious and noble: The Cano∣pies of State, under which the late Queen gave Audience, are as rich as Embroidery
can make them; and the Pictures in the Closet, and little Gallery, with that of English Beauties, are worth a Stranger's coming to England on purpose to see.

From that Guard-Room, where we said before was a Picture of the late King of Sweden, we pass into St. George's Hall, the finest Room in the World. This Hall is very large and long, and designed from the first Institution for the Entertain∣ment of the Knights of the Garter at their Installation; and the Sovereign us'd to give a Feast to his Twenty Five Knights Companions every St. George's Day. But this latter Custom has not been observed since the Reign of King Charles II. who made the last Feast of that kind at the In∣stallation of the present Duke of Bucking∣ham, then Earl of Mulgrave.

On one Side of the Hall is painted King Edward III. sitting on a Throne, receiving his triumphant Son Edward the Black Prince, with the Kings of France and Scotland Prisoners, full as big as the Life. To this Story Sir John Denham alludes in the following Lines, where he takes par∣ticular Notice.
DIV4.Q:
Of Thee, great Edward, and thy greater Son,
(The Lilies which his Father wore, he won)
And thyQueen Philippa. Bellona, who thy Consort came
Not only to thy Bed, but to thy Fame;
She to thy Triumph led oneDavid King of Scotland. captive King,
And brought thatThe Black Prince. Son which did theJohn King of France. other bring. Thus translated by Mr. Pengry, pag. 5.
—Tacuisse nefas Te magne Edoarde, tuumque
Te Patre majorem natum, qui Lilia carpsit
Victrici dextra, atque Tibi gestanda ferebat;
Bellonamquè Tuae sociam famaequè soriquè,
Uno quae capto peperit Tibi Rege triumphos
Atque Illum peperit, cui Captus paruit Alter.
DIV4.P:
On the Cieling are painted the Tri∣umphs of King Charles II. over Faction, Rebellion, and Sedition, where the Pain∣ter has put the Picture of the Earl of Shaftesbury, Lord Chancellor in the Reign, representing Sedition with Libels in his Hand, a Man, who served all Times and Parties, according to his Interest, and was named as one of the King's Judges, though he had the Wit not openly to ap∣pear. At the upper End of the Hall is the
Picture of King William III. seated on a Throne, ten Steps high, five of which on∣ly are painted; and above this St. George killing the Dragon.

From the Hall you pass into the Cha∣pel-Royal, under an artificial Curtain sup∣ported by 4 Statues larger than the Life, which is pav'd with Marble, like the Hall, and admirably painted with some Histories of the New Testament. The Altar-Piece is the last Supper, and on the Cieling is a noble Ascension. All which excellent Pieces of Painting were performed by the masterly Hand of Signior Verrio a Neapo∣litan.

In passing from the inner Court to the outer, you go by the Tower above-men∣tioned, which is the Habitation of the Con∣stable or Governor. It is built after the Manner of an Amphi-Theatre, very high, and very magnificent; and the Apartments are suitable to the Character of the Office, very noble. On the Top of the Tower the Standard is erected, as often as the Court, or Constable is at Windsor. King Charles II. had a Design of facing the Hill it stands on with Brick; but that Project was never finished.

The lower Court is much larger, and equally broad with the upper. Here for∣merly stood a Chapel built by King Henry I.
and dedicated to King Edward the Confes∣sor: This was demolished by King Ed∣ward III. who raised another Pile, which he dedicated to St. George: But King Ed∣ward IV. (whose Inclination to, and Kind∣ness to this Place was very extraordinary) finding, upon a Survey, that this Chapel was very much decayed, and not thinking the Building large or stately enough, he resolved upon raising the present noble E∣difice; for this purpose he constituted Ri∣chard Beauchamp, Bishop of Sarum, Master and Surveyor of the Works, to whom he also gave a plenary Power of removing several irregular Buildings, or Offices, which might be Obstacles, particularly some antient Buildings on the East Side of the Chapel, which reached unto the Walls of the North Side of the Castle, where the Towers, commonly called Clure ys Tower, and Le Amener ys Tower, and Barner ys Tower were situated; as also on the South Side of the Chapel unto the Belfrey.

This elegant and beautiful Gothick Stru∣cture, by the Diligence of the good Bishop, was soon raised and enlarged, in length, at least, One Hundred Fathom, in 1474. though it attained to its present Beauty and Perfection not till the Reign of King Henry VIII. In the Reign of King Henry VII. Sir Reginald Bray, (one of the Knights
of the noble Order of the Garter) became a liberal Benefactor to the finishing of the Body of this Chapel, and building the middle Chapel on the South Side of it, still called by his Name (where his Body lyes interred) as it is manifest not only from his last Will, but also from his Coat of Ar∣mour, Crest, and the Initial Letters of his Christian and Surname, cut in Stone in several Parts of the Roof.

By an Indenture dated June 5. 1505. John Hylmer and William Vertue, Free Masons, undertook the Vaulting of the Roof of the Choir (that curious and excel∣lent Piece of Architecture) for 700 Pounds, and to finish it by Christmas 1508. The Rood Loft and Lanthorn were erected by the Contributions of the Knights Com∣panions of the Garter in 1516.

Within this Chapel of St. George have been several Chantries founded, and en∣dowed with Lands and other Revenues, appointed for the Maintenance of Chap∣lains and Priests to sing Masses there for the Souls of their Founders, and their Kindred, of which Mr. Ashmole's printed History, as well as MS. (from whom we must borrow much concerning this Cha∣pel, College, and its several Endowments) gives us the following Account, viz.
1. “William of Wickham, Bishop of Winchester, gave 200 Marks for buying 20 Marks Rent per Annum to maintain a Chaplain to celebrate Mass in this Chapel for the Health of his Soul; the Soul of King Edward the IIId. of the said Bishops Father, Mother, and all his Benefactors. The Covenants between him and the Dean and Chapter for Per∣formance thereof, bear date at Windsor the 29th of May, Anno 3 H. 8. (1511.)”

“The 26 of November, Anno 18 Edw. IV. (1477.) the Feoffees of Richard Duke of Gloucester, confirmed and deli∣vered to the Dean and Chapter, the Manors of Bentfieldbury in the County of Essex, Knapton in the Country of Nor∣folk, and Chellesworth in the County of Suffolk; who, thereupon, granted (a∣mong other Things) that they and their Successors should cause yearly for ever, a Mass to be daily celebrated in this Chapel, for the good Estate of the said Duke, and of Anne his Dutchess, while they lived, and their Souls when dead; as also for the Souls of their Parents and Benefactors.”

“Sir Thomas St. Leger, Kt. (sometime Husband to Anne Dutchess of Exeter, Sister to King Edward the Fourth) founded a Chantry of two Priests,
who (in the middle Chapel, situate on the North Side of the Church) were or∣dained to pray for the healthful Estate of King Edward the Fourth, and his Queen, and Cicely, dead; as also for the Soul of Richard Duke of York, the good Estate of the said Sir Thomas, and Ri∣chard Bishop of Salisbury, then living, and after their decease, for their Souls, and the Soul of Anne Dutchess of Exeter. The Foundation of this Chantry, and the Covenants between Sir Thomas St. Leger, and the Dean and College, are dated the 20 of April, Anno 22 Ed. IV. (1481.)”

“By the last Will of King Edward the Fourth, a Chantry was ordained to be founded of two Priests to serve at his Tomb, to whom was appointed an Ex∣hibition of Twenty Marks yearly a∣piece. They were called King Edward's Chantry Priests.

“The Chantry of Thomas Passche (one of the Canons of this Chapel) was found∣ed for a Priest to pray daily for his Soul, and the Soul of William Hermer (ano∣ther of the Canons there) as also for the good Estate of Master John Arundel, and Master John Seymer, Canons, and of Master Thomas Brotherton, and their Souls, after they should depart this Life.”
“There was another Chantry Priest assigned to pray for the Souls of the said Passche and Hermer, and of John Plu∣mer, Verger of the Chapel, and Agatha his Wife; which Devotion was appoint∣ed to be perform'd at the Altar on the North Side of the new Church, and the Settlement thereof bears date the 18 of March, Anno 9 Hen. VII. (1493.)”

“The first of March, Anno 12 Hen. VII. (1496.) Margaret Countess of Rich∣mond, obtained Licence from the King, that she or her Executors might found a Chantry of four Chaplains to pray for her Soul, the Souls of her Parents and Ancestors, and all faithful Souls depart∣ed. This Celebration was to be per∣formed in a Place near the East Part of the new Work of the Chapel. And the 18 of July, Anno 13 Hen. VIII. (1497.) the Dean and Canons granted, That the Countess, or her Executors, should erect such a Chantry in the Chapel, as is beforementioned.”

“The Chantry of William Lord Ha∣stings, founded for one Priest to pray for his Soul, the Souls of the Lady Cathe∣rine his Widow, and of Edward Lord Hastings his Son, and Mary his Wife, after their Death. The Chapel where∣in this Service was celebrated, is that
on the North Side of the Choir, about the middle thereof, where the Body of this Lord lyes interred. The Ordinati∣on is dated the 21 of February, Anno 18 Hen. VII. (1502.)”

“Charles Somerset, Lord Herbert, (crea∣ted afterwards Earl of Worcester) was buried in the South Chapel (dedicated to the Virgin Mary) at the West End of the Church, where he ordained a Secu∣lar Priest to say Mass every Day, and to pray for the Souls of him and his first Wife, Elizabeth, the Daughter and Heir of William Herbert Earl of Hun∣tingdon, Lord Herbert of Gower, who also lyes interred here. The Foundation of this Chantry is dated the 30 of July, Anno 21 Hen. VII. (1505.)”

“In this Chapel of St. George were heretofore several Anniversaries or Obits held and celebrated; some of them, as they are entred down in an Account of Owen Oglethorp, Treasurer of the Col∣lege for the Year, commencing the first of October, Anno 38 Hen. VIII. (1546.) and ending the last Day of September, Anno 1 Edw. VI. (1546.) inclusive, we will here remember.”

LIST.HEAD: FEBRUARY.
LIST.ITEM: 28 Roger Lupton, Canon, Provost of Eton College

LIST.HEAD: JUNE.
LIST.ITEM: 14 Brothers and Sisters of St. Anthony.

DIV4.P: During the great Rebellion this Church∣es Fate was very deplorable, and her in∣side was very much abused by the Saints of those Times, who had a Garrison here; the Organs and Windows being also defa∣ced on 6 Septermber, 1643.
In this Church are the following Mo∣numents, viz.

In the East Ile, behind the High Altar, on a Marble Grave-stone, whereon is fix∣ed a Brass Plate, having the Figure of an Ecclesiastick in his Habit, over which is his Robe, with an Escotcheon of St. George on his left Shoulder, is this Inscription.

Q.P: Orate pro anima Will. Atkinson, sacre Theologie Professoris, et hu∣jus sacri Collegii Canon. Qui obiit 8 Die Augusti, Anno Dni.
Millemo quingentesimo nouo. Cujus anime propicietur Deus. Amen.

DIV4.P: On another Grave-stone, in the middle of the said Ile, from whence the Figure in Brass is torn away, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Here under this Stone lyeth John Bockle, Preeste, Maister of Arte. Batchelour of Divinitee, who at the Tyme of his Death was one of the secular Canons of Wynde∣sore, and in his former Lyfe time was Pryor of the Regular Cha∣nons of the dissolved Monastery of Merton in the County of Surrey, who dyed the 15th of Augt. 1559.
DIV4.P: In the Ile on the South Side of the Choir' within an Arch made in the Wall, near the East End, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q:
Who leyde this Booke here? The Reverend Fader in God Rich Beachamp, Bischop of this Diocess
of Sarysbury. And wherefore? To the intent that Preestes and Ministers of Goddes Church may here have the Occupacion thereof, seying therein theyr Divyne Ser∣vyce, and for alle othir that ly∣styn to sey thereby theyr Devocy∣on. A shyth he any speritual Mede? Yee, as moche as oure Lord lyst to reward hym for his goode intent; praying every Man, whose Duty or Devocion is eased by this Book, they will say for hint thys commune Oryson, Domine Jesu Christe: Knelyng in the Pre∣sence of this Holy Crosse, for the wyche the Reverend Fadir in Godde aboveseyd hathe grauntyd of the Tresurye of the Church to every Man 40 Daies of Pardon.
DIV4.P: At the South East End of this Ile is a Chapel, wherein stands a fair Alabaster Monument; on the Top is a Man pro∣strate, his Feet on a Grey Hound coller'd and chain'd, and by him a Woman, whose Feet stand on a Monkey coller'd: At the Head are the Statues of 2 Daughters, and on one Side 5 Daughters more; on the other Side 3 Sons, with a Head Piece between them. On the Sides is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Nobilissimo Domino Edovardo Finio, Lincolniae Comiti, Clintoniae et Saiae Baroni, inclyti ordinis Periscelidis Mi∣liti, et summo Angliae Admirallo, cum, post praeclaram operam quatuor (con∣tinua serie) Illustrissimis Principibus, Henrico, Edovardo, Mariae, et Eliza∣bethae tam confilio, quam armis, et do∣mi et foris terra Mari{que} fideliter na∣vatam, placide fato functus esset, cha∣rissimo marito amantissima conjux Eli∣zabetha, Comitis Kildarienlsis filia, piae perpetuaeq; memoriae ergo maerens posuit. Obiit 16 Die Januarii, 1584.
DIV4.P: Near the East Window of this Ile hang the Helmet and Crest of...Bowyer, Es{que} sometime Gentleman Usher of the Black Rod.
Under the 4th Arch, on the Side of the Choir, lyes a Plate of Brass on a Grave-stone, and on it is the Figure of a Priest in a Canons Mantle, with St. George's Arms on his left Shoulder.

Q.P:
Orate pro anima Mri. Thomae Rawe, Artium Mri. quondam hu∣jus sacri Collegii Canonici; qui obiit 12 Die Maii, An. Dni. Mil∣limo
quingentesimo quinquagesi, mo sexto.
Cujus anime propicietur Deus. Amen.

DIV4.P: A little South wards of this lyes ano∣ther, like the former, with this Inscrip∣tion.
DIV4.Q: Hic facet Johannes Seymorus, sactre Theologie Baccalaureus, hujus Collegi quondam Canonicus, quiobiit 28 Die Novembris, Anno Dni. 1573.
DIV4.P: Within the Fifth Arch hang the At∣cheivements of Charles Brandon, Duke of Suffolk, viz. a Coat of his Arms, a Tar∣get of the same, Helmet and Crest. At each Corner of a Marble Grave-stone is this Coat of Arms, viz. Horses Passant parted by a Fess. Over it thus.

Q.P: Equus paratur ad Deim belli.
Underneath.
Dominus autem salutem tribuit.

DIV4.P: In the middle of the Stone is this In∣scription.
DIV4.Q: Antonius Rushe, Sacre Theologie Doctor, Cicestrensis Ecclesie Deca∣iss: hujus honorati Collegii Ca∣nonicus Prebendarius, &c. et Serenissime Maestatis Capella∣nus, quum gravi et diuturno Intabuisset morbo: Vix quadra∣genarius, immatura morte (quam solam sibi sacro futuram sepius ecinerat) extremum confecit dient de{que} tanto viro (sic est vita homi∣num) nisi cineres et ossa, restat aliud nihil, at sedati et tranquilli animi laude florescit quotidie ma∣gis: Suisq: virtutibus et bene∣ficits vivit adhuc, memoria{que} su∣a vissimi hominis morietur nun∣quam Decessit primo Aprilis, 1577. Miserando illo nefasto{que} suis Die Criduo{que} post, lugu∣bri Lamentatione fletu{que} suo∣rum, funere elatus hac requiescit humo Ad perpetuam defuncti Memoriam posuit pia Conix.
DIV4.P: On another Grave-stone, adjoyning, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Here lies Charles Cleland. Triumph with Joy.
DIV4.P: Within the 6th Arch is a little Chantry Chapel erected, called Oxenbridge's Cha∣pel, mentioned pag. 126. On the top of the Door is a Lion Rampant with many Escallops round him, and the Rebus of the Founder's Name, viz. an Ox, the Letter N, and a Bridge with Water running un∣der it. Within is painted the History of St. John Baptist preaching in the Wilder∣ness, his Head delivered to the Damsel, and the Damsel presenting it to Herod. As also a Priest kneeling, having over his Sur∣plice a Red Mantle lin'd with Green, and underneath the aforesaid Arms this Date.
On a Marble Grave-stone, lying over against this Chapel, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q:
Here lyeth the Body of Mrs. Susanna Parrye, the late Wife of Hugh Parrye, Gent. who departed this Life the 20th
of Feb. Ann. 1656. Aetatis suae, 27.
DIV4.P: Under the 4th Arch is painted on large Panes of Wood these Figures.
I. Of Prince Edward, Son to King Henry the 6th, having a Prince's Cap on his Head, a Gold Verge in his Hand, and vested in a Robe lin'd with Ermin, un∣der his Feet this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Primogenitus Henrici Vj.
DIV4.P: This Nich is diaprd with Swans and Ostrich Feathers, and over him are France and England, quarterly, a Label Argent, and are supported on the right Side with an Antilope Argent, attired, Or, accolled with a Ducal Coronet, and chained Or, and on the left with a Swan proper, gorged also with a Coronet proper, and chained, Or.
II. Of King Edward the 4th, crown'd, and in his Robes, holding a Scepter and a Globe, under his Feet,
DIV4.Q: Edwardus quartus.
DIV4.P: And beneath are a Lion and a Hart.
Of King Edward the 5th, vested in the like Robe, Scepter and Globe, but his Crown set over, not on his Head, under whom is this,
DIV4.Q: Edwardus quintus.
DIV4.P: Also the Figures of a Lion and a Pricket.
Of King Henry the 7th, robed, crown'd, bearing a Scepter and Globe, with thse Words,
DIV4.Q: Henricus Vij.
DIV4.P: And lower, a Dragon and a Grey Hound.
Underneath these Pictures is this In∣scription.

Q.P: Orate pro Dno. Olivero Kyng, Iu∣ris..... Professore, ac illustris Edwardi primogeniti Regis Hen∣rici sexti, et Serenissimerum Re∣gum Edwardi 4tt. Edwardi quinti, et Henrici septimi, Principali Se∣cretario, dignissimi Ordinis Gar∣terii Registro, et hujus sacri Col∣legi Canonico, An. Dni. 1489.
Et postea per dictum Illustrissi∣mum Regem Henr. septim. Anno Dni. 1492. ad sedem Exoniensem commendato.

DIV4.P: Opposite to the said Pictures, on the South Side of the Ile, lyes a Grave-stone thus circumscribed.
DIV4.Q: William King, Second Son to John King, Praebendary of this Chapell, and Mary his Wife, being soon weary of his Aboad on Earth, left them to pre∣serve a Memorial of him, after ten Weeks Pilgrimage, under this Marble, Dec. 22. 1633.
DIV4.P: Near the Head of the Stone is the Fi∣gure, of the said Infant in his Cradle on a Brass Plate. Underneath are these Verses.

Q.L: Here the sad Parents second Summons lyes
Withdrawn, to draw from Earth to Paradice
Their stooping Thoughts, he hasten'd to repay
What they could lend, dull macerated Clay,
To feast the Worms; what Heaven gave them doth rest
To feast with Innocents: Thus from the Brest
Ravish'd by Death, so near our Saviours Birth,
To share in Saints and Angells Christmass Mirth.

DIV4.P: On another Grave-stone, exactly like the last mentioned, is the following In∣scription.
DIV4.Q: Dorothy King, lent to her Parent John King, Doctor of Divinitie, Prebendarie of this Chappell, and Marie his Wife, but speedily requir'd again, Octob. 18. 1630.
DIV4.P: On a Brass Plate, in the middle of this Stone, are these Verses.

Q.L: Here lyes a Modell of frail Man,
A tender Infant, but a Span
In Age or Stature, here shee must
Lengthen out both, bedded in Dust,
Nyne Months imprison'd in the Wombe,
Eight on Earths Surface free, the Tombe
Must make compleat her Diarie
So leave her to Eternity.

DIV4.P:
Between the Choir and the Altar, un∣der an Arch on the South Side, was a fair Monument erected over the Body of Henry VI. murder'd by Richard Duke of Gloucester, and removed from Chertsey Abbey in Surrey hither, of which nought now remains, except the several Devises of this King, and on the Key Stone his
Royal Arms, ensigned with a Crown, and supported by two Antilopes, collered and chained together. In the South Win∣dow of which Arch was painted the Histo∣ry of his unhappy Life, which, with many other Windows, were destroyed in the Rebellion. He was the Founder of St. Mary's College at Eton, and St. Ni∣chola's at Cambridge. Of him and his Rival, Mr. Pope, in his Windsor Forest, descants in the following manner, pag. 13.

Q.L: Let softer Strains Ill-fated Henry mourn,
And Palms Eternal flourish round his Urn;
Here o'er the Martyr King the Marble weeps,
And fast beside him once fear'd Edward sleeps,
Whom not th' extended Albion could contain,
From old Belerium to the German Main,
The Grave unites; where ev'n the Great find rest,
And blended lie th' Oppressor and th' Opprest!

DIV4.P: In the North e, near the Chapter-House Door, on a Marble Grave-stone, was the Figure of an Ecclesiastick, but now stol'n away; on either Side of the Body are remaining 3 Scrowls thus inscribed.
Grace me guide.
At the Feet is this defective Inscription.
DIV4.Q: ..... Thomas Danett, Doctor, quondam sacre Theologie, Deca∣nus istius Collegii, ac..... Elemosinarius....... Regis Edwardi quarti. Qui obiit 18 Die Mensis Septemb. An°. lxxxiij. Cujus..................
DIV4.P:
Near this Place is a Monument of Steel polished and gilt, representing a pair of Gates betwixt two Towers, all or tran∣sparent Workmanship, after the Gothick Manner, placed in the North Arch, faced through with Touch Stone, erected in Memory of King Edward the Fourth, who died 9 April, 1483. Over this Arch hung the King's Coat of Male, gilt, cover∣ed over with Crimson Velvet, and on it were the Arms of France and England quarterly, richly embroidered with Pearl and Gold, interwoven with several Ru∣bies. This Trophy of Honour had ever since his Funeral bung safely over his Grave, but was plundered thence by Captain Fogg, 23 October, 1642. (on which Day he also robb'd the Treasury of the Chapel of all the rich Plate, dedicated to the Use of the Altar) yet having met with
an exact Measure and Size of each Part thereof, as also of his Banner, both here∣tofore taken by Sir William le Neve, some∣time Clarencieux King of Arms, an exact Observator of any Thing curious, referring to Arms of Ceremony, we think fit to transmit it thus to Posterity.
The Coat of Arms was two Foot seven Inches deep, and below two Foot in breadth.
Above (the Maunches being extended) in Breadth three Foot and six Inches; whereof the length of each Maunch was one Foot.
The Breadth of the upper Part of the Coat, besides the Maunches, one Foot and a half.
The Breadth of each Maunch one Foot and eight Inches.
The Arms were embroidered upon Vel∣vet, lin'd with Sattin, and better wrought than they used to Work in those Days.

The Banner, which also hung over his Grave, was of Taffaty, and thereon paint∣ed quarterly France and England: It had in Breadth three Foot four Inches, besides a Fringe of about an Inch broad, and in Depth five Foot and four Inches, besides the Fringe.

On the Monument there never was any Inscription, take one therefore composed
for him by some Rhiming Monk, and Re∣gistred in a Book in the College of Arms, marked E. VI. viz.

Q.L: Carmina que letus ceini, cano tristio mstus,
Heu Pater, heu Pastor, heu Rex, heu bellirus rmis,
Heu doctus Solomon, Jonathas, Arthurus in hoste,
Heu vere legis custos, heu gloria plebis,
quartus Anglis Rex, et decus orbis,
Tollitur a nobis fiosa mundi, sloque Triumphi,
Absolon in vultu, Solomon tristi quasi cultu,
Templi fundator, Castri novus et recreator,
At nobis notis qui sit jam queso beatus.
Gallus obedit ejus bustu, luctusque subegit,
Protector Christi , victus nece tristi,
Celsa petens astri, jacuit jam colmlua castri.
Sol latet obscuris gravibus dolet Anglia curis
Castra thoris plen psllentum sunt peramena,
Olim jam flentum, verba referre valentum,
Luce migrat cels nona Fiex noster Aprilis
Edwardi, Christi matris, precibusque ▪
M. semel C. quarter octo∣decies tribus annis.
Tristi sed fiegni wees trenus annis,
Natus quo mense necat hunc mors illius case.
Anglia psange parens sic Neustria nutrix
Rex tuus ex jure moritur cur Gallia conslet,
Regem nunc Reges plangant, geniti genitores,
Princeps uxque comes genetrix, eginaque proles
Spiritus exorent Reges petat alta Polorum
Omnes Angligene quia Rex et Tutor eorum,

DIV4.P: Near unto King Edward the 4th's Tomb lyes another Marble, with the Fi∣gure of a Prebendary in his Habit and Mantle, with St. George's Arms. On each Side of his Neck is this Scrowl.
DIV4.Q: Oblivio non aspiciam hominem ultra.
DIV4.P: And on each Side of him 2 other Scrowls thus inscribed.
DIV4.Q: Nil preter misericordiam.
DIV4.P: On a Ledge of Brass round the Stone is this Inscription.

Q.P: Orate pro amima Dni. Richardi Surlonde, nuper Canonici hujus Collegii, nec non Subdecani Ca∣pelle Regie in temporibus Illu∣strisimorum Principum Edwar∣di quarti, Richardi tertit, Henrici septtmi, et Henrici Octavi. Qui obiit vicesimo Mie Mensis Augusti, Anno Dni. Millesimo, quingen∣sesimo nono.
Underneath these Verses.
Q.L: Richardus jacet hic Surlonde, venerabile morum
Eremplar, pietas, presidiumqz bonis
Crimius cantu, dum vox etasqz vigebat,
Regia cui palmam jure sacella dabant.
Hic reliquos inter florebot honore sacerdos,
Hic cesidens sacrâ nuper in ede fuit.
Quatuor hunc Reges adamabant. subqz decanum
einceps hunc sacris preposuere Dei.
A quarto Edwardo nitidos sortitus honores.
Henrico octavo sceptra regente, perit.

DIV4.P: Under the 6th Arch, near the North Window, lyes another Grave-stone, on which, on a Ledge of Brass, is this In∣scription.

Q.P: Hic jacet humatum Corpus vene∣rabilis Viri, Magistri Galfridi Wren, quondam hujus Collegii Canonici, necnon Illustriss.......
Qui obiit quinto Die Mensis Aprilis, Anno Dni. Millimo Quingentesimo vicesimo septimo. Cujus anime propicietur Deus, Amen.

DIV4.P: In the midddle of the said Stone is his Image, with a Mantle of St. George on him; under his Feet these Verses.

Q.L: Sub Saxo ponor, et vermibus ultimo donor,
Et sicut ponor, ponitur omnis honor.

DIV4.P: On another Brass Plate, on a Grave∣stone between the Seventh and Eighth Ar∣ches, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q:
Here lyeth Master James Blyth, the which deceasyd the.....
Day of August, in the Year of our Lord God, Ao. MCCCCCXLVII. On whose Soul Iesu have Mercy.
DIV4.P: On another Stone, under the Eighth Arch, near the Window, on Brass Plates, are these Inscriptions.
DIV4.Q: Here lyeth the Body of Paul French, Batchelor of Divinitie, who was 40 Years Prebendarie of this Church, who the Lord having many Waies blessed, while he liv'd took unto himself in the Peace of the Gospell, and of a good Conscience, when he had lived 79 yeares, he dy'd the year of Grace, 1600. Novemb. I.
DIV4.P: At the Head of the Stone these Words.
DIV4.Q: The Bodies of the godly and holy Men are buried in Peace, but their Names live for evermore.
DIV4.P: Adjoyning to the aforesaid Stone is ano∣ther Grave-stone, bearing a Brass Plate, with the following Inscription.
DIV4.Q:
Hic jacet Erasmus Webb, Sacrae Theologiae Baccalaur eus, hujus Regiae Capellae quondam
Canonicus: Qui obiit 24o Die Martii, An. Dni. 1613. Aetatis suae 63.
DIV4.P: On a Marble Grave-stone▪ lying with∣in the seventh Arch, is the following In∣scription.
DIV4.Q: Antonii Hawles, Hujus Collegii Canonici quod reliquum est, hic Jesu Christi adventum praestolatur. Qui vitam mutavit 16. Januarii, 1663.
DIV4.P: On a Brass Plate, on a plain Marble Grave-stone, is the Figure of a Person in a Mantle, bearing an Escotcheon of St. George's Antis, and underneath this Inscription.

Q.P: Johanni Chamber, Socio primum Collegii Merton, 1569. dein Aetonensis, 1582. postremum Canonico hujus Ecclesiae, 1601.
Theologo, Medico, Mathematico insignil. Henr. Neville, et Henric. Saville, Milites, Posuere.
Natus apud Swillington, in Comitat. Ebor. 1546. Mense Maio, obiit Aetonae 1604. ineunte Augusto.
Corpus hoc marmore humatum jacet, Praeter alia legavit moriens Collegio Mertonensi Mille libras.

DIV4.P: On a Marble Grave-stone, near the Entrance into the South Ile, is this In∣scription.
DIV4.Q: Sub hoc marmore, futuram in Christo Resurrectionem expectat, Gregorius Baker, notissimae probitatis, diligentiae, Prudentiae, Fidei Vir non gregarius, West wellae, in Comitatu Cantii natus, D. D. Decano et Capitulo Windesor, Clericus a Capitulo, at{que} Collegii Aetonensis Computorum Auditor, Obiit Aetatis suae Anno 61. Decemb. 15. A. D. 1637. Beati mortui qui in Domino moriuntur. Apocal. 14. 13.
DIV4.P: In the middle Southern Chapel, on the East Wall, is an Alabaster Monument, bearing the Bust of a Person vested in an Episcopal Habit, and this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Individuae Trinitati per omnia saecula, gloria per quam fui, sum, ero. Hic situs est Aegidius Tomson, hujus Capellae quondam Decanus, cujus mens sincera, lingua docta, manus munda fuit. Londini natus, educatus Oxoniae in Collegio Omnium Animarum, bo∣norum, indigentium, eruditissimorum amantissimus semper vixit, cujus cor∣pus quamvis mortalitas terrae subjecit, illius tamen animam pietas caelis inse∣ruit. Hunc virum moribus gravem, prudentiâ insignem, pietate summum, haec Regia Capella per 10 annos Deca∣num habuit. Inde a Serenissimo Rege Jacobo in Episcopatum Gloucest. com∣mendatum, Mors intempestiva (Anno decurso) Praesulem rapuit. Obiit 14 Junii, An. Dom. 1612. Aetatis suae 59.
DIV4.P: On the Right Side of the said Pourtrai∣ture stands the Figure of Time, over whose Head is an Angel holding a Scrowl, thus inscribed.
DIV4.Q: In Memoria Aeterna erit justus.
DIV4.P: On the left Hand Death, over whom is a∣nother Angel with a Scrowl thus Inscribed.
DIV4.Q: Justorum animae in manu Dei sunt.
DIV4.P: Adjoyning to the former, is another Monument, on which is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q:
In obitum Richardi Wortley, de Wortley, in Comitatu Ebor. Equit is Aurati, qui obiit 25° Die Junii, 1603.
Hic Wortleie tuis dolor, et decus omne recum∣bis,
Plebis honos, Equitum gloria, Regis amor.
Qui, quod er as patriae bonus, or be charus, egenis
Utilis, hi pariter te cecidisse dolent.
Verum, quando fides, pietas, constantia, virtus
Inveniet similem religiosa virum.
Invenire quidem similem, sed dispare sexu:
Sic Uxor similis, dissimilis{que} tibi.
DIV4.P: Under the South Window stands an Al∣tar Monument of Grey Marble bearing this Inscription.

Q.L: Hoc Gulielme manet, tibi Fitz-Williamze sepulchrum,
Caetera mors, vita deficiente, tulit.
Catera cum dico, fundos et commoda dico
Corporis, et quantum mundus habere potest.
Mens etenim tua, cuncta Deo, durabit in astris
Et locuples laudis patria testis erit.
Mortuus est, annus cum quinquagesimus esset
Nonus, et Octobris tertia nata Dies.

DIV4.P: On another Monument, under the West Window, is this Iuscription.

Q.P: D. O. M. Johannes Dent, de Thornburie in Agro Gloucestrensi, Armiger, morum suavitate, vitaeq; integritate Praecellens, vixit N. XXXII Sic. Orig. XII die Febr. Anno a verbo carne facto ICXXXXIIII at{que}

H. S. E. Qui ex Katherina Uxor sua dulciss. filia Georgii Huxley, de Wyerhall, in Agro Middlesex, Armigeri, suscepit prolem Johannem, Katherinam, et Elizabetham, adhuc superstites, Conjux maerens moestiss. H. M. S. P. P. C.

DIV4.P: The Body of Sir Reginald Bray is said to lye in this Chapel.

In the middle of this Chapel stands a rais'd Tomb, whereon are the Pour∣traitures
cut in Alabaster of 2 Persons prostrate, a Man and a Woman, their Feet standing on a Grey Hound Couchant.
On the South Side are the Figures of six Men, in the midst of whom stands an An∣gel holding a Coat of Arms, and on the North Side six Women in the same man∣ner.
At the Top of a Brass Plate, set in the North Wall, thus.

DIV4.HEAD: MAGISTER ROBERTUS, HONYWODE, LEGUM DOCT.
DIV4.P: In the middle of the Plate is his Figure in his proper Habit, kneeling before our Lady with Christ in her Lap, and this In∣scription in a Scrowl issuing out of his Mouth.
Virgo tuum natum pro me precor ora.
Behind him stands St. Catherine with her Sword and Wheel, and underneath is this Inscription.

Q.P: Orate proanima Magistri Roberti Honywode, Legum Doctoris, nu∣per Archi-Diaconi Tawnton, ac Canonici hujus Collegii. Qui obiit 22 Die Januarii, Anno Dni. 1522.
Cujus anime propicietur Deus. Amen.

DIV4.P: In the North Cross Ile, on a Brass Plate, is this Inscription following.

Q.P: Here lyeth buried George Maners, Knyght, Lord Roos, who decesed the xxiij Daye of Octobre, in the Yere of our Lorde God, MVcXIII. and Ladye Anne his Wife, Daugh∣ter of Anne Duchess of ExeturSic. Orig. SufferSic. Orig. unto Kyng Edward the Fourthe, and of Thomas Sentlynger Sic. Orig. Knyght. The whyche Anne de∣cessed the xxij Day of Aprill, in the Yere of our Lord God, M. V.c. XXVI.
On whose Soulls God have Mercy. Amen.

DIV4.P: Arms are, Or, two Barrs Azure, a Chief Gules, impaling St. Leoger, being Azure Fretty Argent, a Chief, Or, and a Crescent for distinction.

On another Gilt Brass Plate, is engra∣ven the Figure of a Man in a Surcoate,
with his Arms, and his Lady in a Robe lin'd with Ermine, viz. Azure, a Frett, Arg. a Chief, Or, and a Cresc. for a diffe∣rence —Sellynger—parted per Pale on the dexter Side, and England quarterly, without any Distinction, and on the sini∣ster Side, Party, France per Fess Burgh and Mortimer, and this Inscription un∣derneath.
DIV4.Q: ythin this Chappell lyeth hu∣ried Anne Dutches of Exeter, Su∣ffer unto the Noble Kyng Edward the forth; and also of the Body of Syr Thomas Sellynger; Knyght, her Husband. Which hath tended wythin this College a Chauntre wyth too prettys synging for ever∣more. On whose Soule God have Mercy. The which Anne, Dutches, dyed in the yere of our Lord A Thousande CCCCLXXV. the Dominical Letter S. primium S xiiij. Daye of January.
DIV4.P: On a painted Tablet, On the North East Side of the said Chapel, is this In∣scription.
DIV4.Q:
Here under lyeth the Body of the Lady Katherine Villers, the Daughter of
the right Honourable Christopher Vil∣lers, late Earl of Anglesey, and the Lady Elizabeth his Wife; the which said Lady Katherine departed this mortal Life the 8th Day of March, 1630. according to our Church Account.
DIV4.P: Over it hang the Atchievements, viz, a Coat of Arms, a Sword and Target, a Helmet and Crest, together with an Earl's Coronet.
On a Black Marble Grave-stone is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Here lyeth interred the Body of BAPTIST MAY, Esqr; Privy Purse to this Maj. King CHARLES the Second, who departed this Life the Second of March, 1696. aged 69.
DIV4.P: Over the Door of the Chapel, on the North West Wall, is a Coat of Arms cut in Iron, and fixed to the Iron Spikes. Underneath is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q:
Orate pro animabus Regis Henrici 7mi. et Christofori Urswyk, quondam ejus Elemosinariiinagni
et istius Collegii Decani, Ave Ma∣ria, &c. Et benedicta, sit sanctissi∣ma tua mater Anna, et qua sine macula processit tua purissima ca∣ro Virginea. Amen. God have Mercy on the Soulls of King Harry the 7th. Christofyr Urswyk, and all Christyn Soulls Amen. .... Deus qui per unigenitum tuum, ex utero virginis incarna∣tum, ac morte passum, genus hu∣manum redemisti, eripias que∣sumus animas Henrici 7•. ac Chri∣stofori, necnon omnium eorum, quos ipse Christoforus, dum vixit, offendit, ab eterna morte, at{que} ad eternam vitam perducas, per Xm. Dominum nostrum. Amen. God have Mercy. Ut sup.
DIV4.P: In the Body of the Church, near the West End, under the Second Arch, on a Grave-stone, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Here lyeth buried the Body of Dame Margarett Paule, Wife to Sir George Paule, Knight, and Daughter to Charles Sonibank, Doctor in Divi∣nitie, and one of the Canons of this Church, who departed this Life on Sonday the 24th of January, 1629.
DIV4.P: On another Grave-stone, under the 4th Arch, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Here under lyeth the Body of John King, sometime Fellow of Merton Col∣ledge in Oxford, Doctor of Divinity, and Chanon of this Churchy, who depart∣ed this Life in the Christian Faith the 7th of August, Anno Domini, 1638.
DIV4.P: On a Plate of Brass fix'd on a large Grave-stone, under the 5th Arch, is this Inscription.

Q.P: Ricardus Field, hujus olim Coll. Canonicus, et Ecclesiae Gloucest. Decanus, verè Doctor Theologiae et Author librorum V de Ecclesiâ.
Una cum Elizabetha Harrisia, sanctissima et charissima Conjuge, ex quâ sex reliquit filios, filiam unicam.
Hic sub communi marmore expectant Christi reditum, qui felicitatem, quam ingressi sunt, adventu suo perficiat ac consummet.

Obierunt in Domino,
Ille Anno Salutis 1616.
Aetatis suoe 55.
Hoec Anno Salutis 1614.
Aetatis suoe 41.

DIV4.P: On a Brass Plate, on another Marble Grave-stone, towards the North, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Here under lyeth buried Mary King, sometime the Wife of John King, one of the Prebendaries of this free Chap∣pell of Windsor, Daughter of William Bird, of Walden in the County of Essex. She departed this Life the 11th Day of March, in the Year of our Lord, 1606.
DIV4.P: On another Brass Plate, on the same Grave-stone, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Here under lyeth buried the Body of John King, sometime Prebendary of this free Chappell of Windsor, together with his Wife above-named. He de∣parted this Life the 13 Day of May, Anno Dni. 1607.
DIV4.P: On the North Side lyes a Graye-stone, on which, in Brass Plates, is the Figure of a Man, and this Inscription.

Q.P: To me to live is Christ, and to dye is Gain. Philip. 1. 21.

Here underneath lies interr'd the Body of William Wilson, Doctour of Divi∣nitie, and Prebendarie of this Church by the space of 32 Years. He had Yssue by Isabell his Wife six Sons and six Daughters. He dy'd the 15th of May, in the Year of our Lord 1615. of his Age the 73, beloved of all in his Lyfe, much lamented in his Death.
Q.L: Who thinke of Deathe in Lyfe, can never dye,
But mount through Faith, from Earth to hea∣venly Pleasure,
Weepe then no more, though here his Body lye,
His Soule's possest of never ending Tresure.

DIV4.P: On another small Plate, on the same Grave-stone, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Neere unto this Place lyes buried William Wilson, the third Son, who, after a long Tryal of greivous Sickness, did comfortably yeild up his Spirit in the Yeare of our Lord 1610. of his Age 23.
DIV4.P: Near the former, on an Altar Monu∣ment, is the Statue of a Bishop lying on his right Side. Over against him, on the Wall, is this Inscription.

Q.P: M. S. Maturus Deo Mortalitatem exuit Revd•s. in Christo Parter, Radulphus Brideoake, Vir audacter probus, magnus, sed humilis, Ingens Attaicae, et omnis eloquentiae Thesaurus, Exule Carolo II. bonis multatus, reverso, a sacris, Hujus Capellae Canonicus, Decanus Sarisburiensis, postea Cicestrensis Episcopus, LOZENO IArAO Diocoeseos tanquam familiae pater, Qui (alienae saluti consulens, immemor suae) Dum gregem visitaret, grassante febri correptus, Episcopali muneri immortuus est III°. Non. Octob. MDCLXXVIII. Aetatis suae LXIV.
Marito optimo Monumentum hoc posuit Conjux moestissima.

M. B.
Imp.
See of Chichester.
Imp.
Grey Hound current within a Bordure Sable.
Grey Hound ut supra.
Bende between 2 Spread Eagles.
without Colours.

DIV4.P: On a White Marble Tablet, near the former, is the following Inscription.

Q.P:
M. S. Francisco Junio, Francisci Junii, Biturigis filio, Nobilitate generis, integritate morum
Et omnigenâ doctrina, conspicuo viro, Nato Heidelbergae, Anno Salutis MDLXXXIX.
Qui per omnem aetatem sine querelâ, out Injurià cujusquam, Musis tantum et sibi vacavit.
Universitas Oxoniensis, Cui scripta et Monumenta laboris sui moriens pene nonagenarius commisit, In grati animi significationem Lubens meritoquè Titulum Posuit. Anno MDCLXXVIII.

DIV4.P: In the South West Corner of the Church is a small Chapel, dedicated to the Virgin Mary, underneath which is a large Vault; at the West End of it hangs a Marble Table, like a Curtain, with this Inscrip∣tion.

Q.P:
This Chappell (belonging to his Ance∣stours) wherein lye buried, not only the Bodies of those, whose Tombs are erected, but likewise that of Henry, late Marquess of Worcester, his Grand∣father (so eminent for the great Sup∣plies of Men and Mony afforded to his Soveraign King Charles the Martyr,
whose Cause he strenuously espoused) and for the keeping his Castle of Raglan with a strong Garrison at his own sole Expence, till it became the last in Eng∣land or Wales, but one, that held out against the Rebels, and then not yeild∣ing it, but after a long Siege, and to the Lord Fairfax, Generalissimo of the Par∣liaments Forces, in revenge of which Obstinacy, as they termed it, it was demolish'd, and all his Woods and Parks (which were vast) cut down and de∣stroyed, and his Estate sold, by the Act of the then rebellious Parliament, to the great Damage of himself and Poste∣rity (wherein also lyes the Body of Henry the Restorer's Son.)

This Chappell being in the Time of the aforesaid Rebellion, upon the foremen∣tion'd Account, much defac'd and the Brass Work, to a considerable Value, plunder'd and imbezell'd, was restor'd to its primitive Form and Shape, and what was wanting thereunto sup∣ply'd, at the Expence and Charge of his present Grace, Henry Duke of Beaufort, Marquess and Earl of Wor∣cester, Lord Herbert of Chepstow, Raglan, and Gower, &c. Knight of the most Noble Order of the Garter, and in the last 2 Reigns President of
the Council; in the Principal▪ of Wales, Lord Lieut. of the Counties of Cities of Gloucester, Hereford, Bristoll, Mon∣mouth, and of all Wales, Constable of the Caste of St. Briavels, Lord War∣den of the Forest of Dean, High Steward of the Cities of Gloucester and Hereford, and of the Townes of Malmesbury, Tewksbury and An∣dover, Gentleman of the Bed-Cham∣ber, and one of the Lords of her Maje∣sties most honourable Privy Councill. In the Yeare of our Lord 1699.

DIV4.P:
In this Chapel stands a fair raised Tomb, erected by himself, for Charles Somerset. Earl of Worcester, who died April 15. 1526. and his first Wife, Eli∣zabeth Herbert, Daughter and Heir of William Earl of Huntington, and Lord Herbert of Gower and Chepstow. On it lye their Statues in Alabaster; He appa∣rell'd in the Habit of St. George, She bear∣ing on her Kirtle the Arms of Herbert em∣bossed and painted, and on her Mantle her Husband's Arms. The Monument is surrounded with Brass Work. Over it hang his Helm and Crest. On the Wall are painted several Devices and Badges, viz. a Portcullis, with a Bend Sinister over it, a Fleur de lis, a Plume of Fea∣thers,
the Red Rose, a Grey Hound, Anti∣lope, &c.

At the East End of this Place is a noble White Marble Monument, representing a Person cumbent, with a Canopy over him, and Justice on the Top of it, adorned with Penons, a Standard, Banners, &c. At the bottom is this Inscription.

Q.P: Sub hoc Marmore conquiescit, Annorum et Titulorum satur, HENRICUS SOMERSET, Dux de Beaufort, Marchio et Comes de Vigorniâ, Baro Herbert de Chepstow, Raglan et Gower, E nobilissimo Ordine Periscelidis Eques: Excellenti animo ac virtute vir; Qui singular is prudentiae laudem Cum infigni Justitiae Gloria conjunxit, Et illustrissimae suae familiae Non modo Fortunas, a Perduellibus eversas, In integrum restituit, Sed & Antiquos Honores Feliciter ampliavit.

Neque tamen Rei Privatae studio intentus, Defuit Publicae. Erat enim idem Regnante Carolo et Jacobo 2 o▪ Concilii in Principatu Wallensi Praeses,
Comitatuum Civitatum{que} Gloucestriae, Herefordiae, Bristolii, Monumethiae, Nec non totius Walliae Praefectus; Arcis de Briavil Castellanus, Et Saltus de Dean Custos Principalis, Civitatum insuper Gloucestriae et Herefordiae, Municipiorum Malmsburii, Teuxburii, et Andoveri▪ Senescallus, Quin et utrisque Carolidum, Quibus intemeratâ semper fide adhaesit A Camerâ et a Consiliis sanctioribus. Conjugem Unicam atque unice dilectam habuit, Mariam Honoratissimi Arthuri Domini Capel Filiam natu maximam; Ex qua progeniem satis numerosam suscepit.
V. Filios. Henricum Dominum Herbert hic juxta sepultum, Carolum de Vigornia Marchionem Henricum & Edwardum Proematurâ marte abreptos, Arthurum Dominum Somerset.

IV. Filias Elizabetham tenerâ aetate mortuam, Mariam Ormondiae Ducissam, Henriettam Dominam de Obrien, Annam Coventriae Comitissam, H. M. Carissimo Viro Dominoquè Posuit
Superstes et maerens Ducissa: Cui, post Annos XLIII suavitèr in conjugio actos, Triste sui desiderium reliquit senex Septuagenarius, Jan. xxi. A. D. MDCXCIX.

DIV4.P: On a Brass Plate, on a Grave-stone Northward of the last, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: William Wilson, late of Wellsbourne, in the county of Lincolne, Bent, departed this Lyfe, within the Ca∣stle of Windsor, in the yeare of out Lord 1587. the 27th Day of August, and lyeth buried in this Place.
DIV4.P: On a Grave-stone in the Nave of the Church, under the Figure of a Person To∣gated, in this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Hic sacet Gulielmus Kynge, Cleri∣cus, Sacre Dheologie Baccalau∣reus, Regie Majestatis Capella∣nus ac Drebenoarius, side Cano∣nicus infra Ecclesiam Collegia∣tam sibe liberam Capellam Regi∣am Sancti Georgii, in Castro be Wyndsor, qui obiit 23 Die Septemb. Anno Diti. 1590.
DIV4.P: On another Grave-stone, near the for∣mer, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Here under lyeth the Body of the Wor. Andrew Osborne, Gent, late Master of the Wor. Company of the Merchan-Taylours, London, who first took to Wife Alice Stratford, of Francott, in the County of Gloucest. Gent. by whome he had divers Children, whereof now living three Sonnes, John, Edward, and Charles; and one Daughter, Alice. Secondly, took to Wife Margarett Carye, with whom he liv'd in Love, and Peaceful Days 16 Years, and de∣parted this Lyfe the 21st of December, Anno Domini, 1614.
DIV4.P: On a Brass Plate, fix'd on a Grave-stone near the Ascent to the Choir, is this Inscription.

Q.L: John Thomson lyeth here, Batcheler in Divinity,
Prebendary of Windsor Church Chaplain eke in Ordinary,
Vnto Elizabeth our Queen, and Soveraign Lady deare,
Of her noble Reign and Government, even the 13th Yeare,
At One and Fiftie of his Age, in Aprill Moneth to saye,
In Year of Christ here fixt aloft, the Three and Twentieth Daie,
Whose Soule, we hope, abides in Bliss of heavenly Ioy and Rest,
With Prophets and with Patriarks, in faithful Abraham's Brest,
His vertuous Steps in Lyfe on Earth, God grant we may ensue,
To Gods Glory, who grant that we his godly Herte pursue.

DIV4.P: Engraven on Brass on another Marble Grave-stone, at the Foot of the said Ascent, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Orate pro anima Magistri Johan∣nis Robins, Sacre Theologie Bac∣calaurei, nuper hujus Regie Ca∣pelle Canonici, et quondam Ca∣pellani tam Regis Henrici octavi, quam Serenissime Regine Marie, qui obiit 25° Die Augusti, Anno Domini Miusimo, quingentell∣mo quinquagesimo octavo, Cujus anime, ut in Celo requtefrat, Deus optimus fuam miserecordi∣am concedac.
DIV4.P: In the middle is his Figure in a Canon's Habit, with a Robe of St. George over it. On his right Side are Three Scrowls thus inscribed.
DIV4.Q: Vivit post funera Virtus. Redemptor meus vivit. In te Domine speravi.
DIV4.P: On his left Side are Five Scrowls thus inscribed.
DIV4.Q:
In te Domine speravi. De Terra Resurrecturus sum.
Vivit post funera virtus. In te Domine speravi Vivit post funera virtus.
DIV4.P: Under his Feet are these Verses on a Brass Plate.

Q.L: Qui jacet Aagusta sub saxo hoc clausus in arcâ,
Johannes Robins nomine dictus erat.
Iure haminis docti vivens cognomen habebat
Cultor virtutis semper ab unguiculis
Claruit arte illa, bene bene qua numerare docemur,
Nec qua metimur, nescius artis erat.
Nobit nature tacitas exquicere causas,
Quid solem abscurat luna ubi lumen habet.
Vnde runnt venti, mare cur fluit at{que} recurrat,
Nir unde et Conitru, fulmina, grando, gelu.
Scivit fucatis veras discernere gemmas,
Quas Adamas vires, quasquè Pyropus habet.
Seduius in Sactis docuit qui scripta libellis:
Hieronymus quicquid, quid{que} ait Ambrosius.
Qui multis solitus rimari Sydera terris,
Iam videt Etheriis certius illa locis.

DIV4.P: On a Grave-stone, at the Entrance of the South Door, is the following Inscrip∣tion.

Q.P: D. O. M. S.

Spirituum Patri, Gulielmus Chamberlayne, Spirituum suum, anhelans, mandavit, Corpus communi Matri
Subdiali sepulchro humandum, S. T. Theoreticae, Practicae, verus Professor, scientiâ, pietate, charitate, cum humilitate conjunctis suspiciendus, hujus Ecclesiae Canonicus, Qui sacello potuit Regio, pro dignitate suâ condi, pro humilitate noluit, sibi vilis, Deo charus, Honorem quem sibi negavit in terris, a Domino laturus in Coelis, Qui vivus servum se inutilem dixit, Redivivus audiet, Euge bone serve, Intra in gaudium Domini tui. Praeiit non periit.
Imitaminim sequimini superstites, M. P. GEO. CHAMB. Obiit 18° Die Maii, 1666.

DIV4.P: On the South Side of the Chapel, on a Marble Tablet, is this Inscription fol∣lowing.
DIV4.Q:
Brunus Ryves, S. Theologiae Professor, Reg. Majestati a Sacris, Liberarum Windsorensis et Wolverhamptonensis Capellarum, a Restitutione Sereniss. Caroli 2 Regis Decanus primus; Nobilissimi Ordinis a Periscelide Scriba,
Fide
Zelo
Affectu
in rebus
Regis
Ecclesiae
Regni
promovendis.
Toto nuperae Rebellionis tempore nemini secundus, celeberrimis hujus saeculi Conciontoribus, a primo juventutis flore ad extremam usque senectam annumeratus, hic sepultus jacet baetam expectans Resurrectionem.
Obiit Julii 13. An. Dom. 1677. Aetatis suae 81.
DIV4.P: In St. Stephen's Chapel, which belongs to the Family of the Hastings, Earls of Huntingdon, is,
In the first Pannel St. Stephen repre∣sented Preaching to the People, and these Words under him.

Q.L: Predicat hic Chxistum, denatus honore videri,
Arguit et mulcet, doctrina corda virorum.

DIV4.P: In the second Pannel He is represented before the Tribunal of Herod, and under him these Words.

Q.L: Invidie fac bus succussa potenter Herodi,
Instat et accusat Stephanum plebs impia justum.

DIV4.P: In the third Pannel is a Prospect of the Jews stoning him, with these Words un∣der him.

Q.L: Sponte sua servat Paulus vestes lapidantum,
Sara pluunt Protho Martic pro quibus adorat.

DIV4.P: In the fourth Pannel He is represented lying along dead, with this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: In Domino moritur Ex quo vita perennis, datur.
DIV4.P: On another Grave-stone, in the South Ile, is this Inscription.

Q.P: In Memory of the worthy Docter Nathaniel Giles, Docter of Musick, who served Q. Elis.

K. James, and K. Charles. He was Master of the Children of this free Chappell of St. George 49 Years, and Master of the Children of his Majesties Chappell Royall 38 Years. He married the eldest Daughter of John Stayner, of the County of Worcester, Es{que} with whom he lived 47 Years, and had Issue by her 4 Sonns and 5 Daughters, whereof 2 Sons and 3 Daughters are now liveing.
He died the 24th Day of January, 1633. when he had lived 75 Years.

DIV4.P: On another Grave-stone, near the for∣mer, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q:
Pattern of Patience, Gravitie, Devotion,
Faithfull to the end, Heir of Heaven's Pro∣motion. Pietatis ergo Nat. Giles, Filius natu maximus maerens posuit 2o Feb. 1634. Die Cinerum versa est in cineres.
DIV4.P: On another Grave-stone, in the North Ile, lies Mr. John Barrow, once Chaplain to Sir William Temple, and Author of one Sermon, with this Inscription.
DIV4.Q:
Johannes Barrow, Art. Magister, Serenissimo Principi Ruperto Com. Palat. a Sacris, Vicarius de Nov. Windsor, hujus Collegii Canonicus Concionator sedulus, celeberrimus, hic sepultus jacet Beatam in Christo expectans Resurrectionem▪ Obiit 19 Die Martii, Anno
Domini, 1684.
Aetatis suae 34.
DIV4.P: On another Grave-stone, near the for∣mer, in the South Ile, in Capitals, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: D. O. M. Hic situs est MARTINUS MEY, Chirurgus experientissimus, felicissimus, natus fuit Lanspergae, prope Regi∣omontanum, in Borussia, Anno MDCXXXV. relicto solo natali, in Principibus Germaniae Civitatibus artem suam exercuit, postea Electori Moguntino per aliquot annos in serviit, a quo Serenissimo Principi Ruperto, Com. Palat. ad Rhenum, &c. de meliori nota commendatus, in Angliam transiit, et Chirurgi officio per 23 annos, functus est fideliter: Tot et tanta Artis et faelicitatis suae in curandis agris edens specimina, ut omnibus charissimus evaserit, obiit Anno 1687. Mense Novemberis, Uxor moerens posuit.
DIV4.P: On another Grave-stone, in the South Ile, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Here lieth the Body of the Honble. Marmaduke Darcy, Es{que} Brother to the Earl of Holderness, first Gentleman Usher of the Privy Chamber to his Majesty, who dyed in this Castle, on Sunday the 3d Day of July, in the 73d Year of his Age, Anno, Dom. 1687.
DIV4.P: On a Grave-stone is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Here lies interred the Body of Robert Delaval, Esqr; eldest Son of Sir Ralph Delaval, of Seaton-Delaval, Bart. he departed this Life the first Day of Au∣gust, 1682. in the 36th Year of his Age. He was the 27th Heir of his Family.
DIV4.P: on another Grave-stone is this Inscrip∣tion.
DIV4.Q: Sir Francis Wortley was buried here, 1666.
DIV4.P: On another Grave-stone is this Inscrip∣tion.
DIV4.Q: Dr. William Brough, Dean of Glou∣cester, and Prebendary of Windsor, was buried here.
DIV4.P: On another Grave-stone, in the Body, towards the West End, is this Inscription.

Q.P: Hic jacet David Stokes, Sacro Sanctae Theologiae Doct. quadraginta plus minus annos hujusce Windsorii Regalis Sacelli Praebendarius, qui Linguam Latinam, Graecam, Hebraicam, Chaldaicam, Arabicam, Syriacam, nec non et omnia scientiarum genera ad amussim callens, in septuagesimo octavo Aetatis suae Anno animam exhalavit.
Ad Defunctum Vade anima et Coeli portas attingito Terris, Non quia non digna es, sed quia digna Deo Te, cum tot parvo didicisti tempore linguas Nunc facile Angelicam discere posse reor.
Obiit Decimo Maii, 1669.

DIV4.P: On another Grave-stone, in the North Ile, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Johannes Durell, S. Th. D.Windsoriensis, Sacelli Decanus, hic jacet beatam expectans Resurrectionem, obiit Ann. Aetatis 58. A. Chr. Nat. 1683. 8 Id. Jun.
DIV4.P: On another Grave-stone, in the North Ile, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q:
H. S. I. Johannes Heaver, S. Theologiae Professor hujus Ecclesiae Canonicus, Coll. Etonensis Socius; Vir Pietate pariter et Eruditione insigni, ingenio, simul et animo liberali fido pectore etiam et aperto, illibata in Ecclesiam, in Principem fide utraque sorte felicissime usus, adversa, ut probata constantia sibi, prospera, ut eximia munificentia aliis benefaceret, qua virtute, (saeculo in charitatem frigido) adeo unice inclaruit, ut res omnis pauperum et amicorum magis videretur quam sua, sed nec moriens prodesse destitit, nam et eorum supremis Tabulis memor, et Aulae St. Clarae quae Cantabrigiae est, ut aedificiis altir cultirque assurgeret, ubi et ipse
ingenii cultum juvenis acceperat, septingentas libras legavit, Academium sibi in sepulchrum exstruens, dignum Literato Viro Monumentum. Obiit Jun. 23. A. D. 1670.
DIV4.P: On another Grave-stone is this In∣scription.
DIV4.Q: Here lies Charles Brandon, Duke of Suffolk, who married Ring Henry the 8th's Sister, and died in his Reign, in August 1545. and was buried at the King's own Charge.
DIV4.P: On another Grave-stone is this In∣scription.
DIV4.Q: Here lieth a godly Matron.
DIV4.P: On another Grave-stone, in the South Ile, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Here lieth interred Dr. John Butler, Canon of this Chappell, as also Susannah his Wife, who were both buried the 2d of August, 1682.
DIV4.P: On a fair Marble, at the West End of a Chapel, in the South Ile, is this In∣scription.
DIV4.Q: Hic sita est ANNA, Conjux dilectissima GULIELMI ALDWORTH, de Frogmore, in Com. Berks, Armig. ex qua, praeter numerosam sobolem jam in Coelis, una cum beata Genetrice triumphantem, tres liberos suscepit Matri superstites, CAROLUM, SUSANNAM et ELIZABETHAM. Obiit Die nono Septembris, Anno Domini, 1695. Aetatis suae 45.
DIV4.P: On another Grave-stone, in the South Ile, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q:
H. S. I. Johannes de Saumares, Sarniensis, S. Th. P. Decanus de Guernsey, Liberae hujus Capellae Canonicus, Rector de Hasely, Magn. in Agro Oxon. Eccl. Anglicanae cultor sincerus, et In predicta Insula instaurator, fide in Deum, fidelitate in Regem conspicuus, amicis candidus, inimicis aequus, omnibus benevolus, post sexaginta et quinque annos
in studiis sacris consumptos inculpatae probitatis, et patientiae invictae praemium optatum inter beatos tulit. Obiit Kal Sept. A. D. MDCXCVII.
DIV4.P: On another Grave-stone is the follow∣ing Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Here lieth the Body of Edward Bow∣man, Es{que} late of Ramesdon, in Ox∣fordshire, Gentleman Usher to K. Ch. 1st. and K. Ch. 2d. he departed this Life the 27th of August, A. D. 1679. aged 57.
DIV4.P: On another Grave-stone, in the South Ile, is this Inscription.

Q.P: Hic sepultus jacet JACOBUS DE HAVILAND, Sarniae, Generosus, Curiae Regiae ibidem JUSTICIARIUS, Vir scientia et pietate conspicuus; a Patria ad Reg. Car. 2^dnm. LEGATUS, post sexaginta duos Annos, et tres Menses, Virtutis tulit praemium, Fato succumbens 22°
Die Octobris, Anno Domini, MDCLXXIV. cujus filius JOHANNES DE HAVIlAND, Patris Memoriae sacrum hoc Marmor posuit.

DIV4.P: On another Grave-stone is this In∣scription.
DIV4.Q: Subtus requiescunt Exuviae Susan. Bush, Bristoliensis, fil. Hen. Rich. ibidem Urbanae, Militiae, quondam Ducis, et Uxoris Johannis Bush, A. M. hujus Eccl. Can. Min. Nec non Div. Jo. Bapt. Oxon, nuper Socii: mulier erat in om∣nes comis, Conjux Materque tenerrima, vere pia, vere Christiana, obiit Apr. 21. 1696.
DIV4.P: On a Marble Grave-stone, at the West End of the North Ile, is the following In∣scription.
DIV4.Q: To the Memory of Elizabeth Randue, who departed this Life the 2d. Day of November, 1680. in the 69th. Year of her Age. This Marble is dedica∣ted by her only Son, Theodore Randue, Page of the Bed-Chamber, and Keeper of his Majesties House in Windsor Castle.
DIV4.P: On another Grave-stone is this In∣scription.

Q.P: Piae Memoriae Viri vere venerabilis. Thomae Horn, S. S. T. D. olim Mertonensis Coll. Oxon. Socii, post annos aliquot Domi et peregre feliciter studiis exactos, Li∣beri et Regii Sacelli in hoc Castro Windsor. per 24 annorum lustra Cano∣nici, propositi sanctissimi vita innocenti∣ssimi, in virtutibus et doctrina multi∣plicis
Uxor Anna Gilesiorum familiâ antiquâ oriund. quae cum eo vixerat Ann. 18. conjunctissime, hoc amoris sui Monumen∣tum posuit, obiit Ann. Salut. 1636. Aetat. 60. Sept. Idus Novembris.

DIV4.P: On another Grave-stone, in the South Ile, is this Inscription.

Q.P: M. S. Sub hoc marmore jacet THO. DOUGHTY, S. T. P. hujus Ecclesiae per 29 Annos Canonicus, Serenissimarum Principum Mariae et Annae, Jacobi tunc Ducis Eboracensis, postea Mag. Brit. Fr. et Hib. Regis filiarum olim Praeceptor, deposuit mortalitatis Exuvias Dec. 2o. Anno Dom. MDCCI.
Aetat. suae LXV. UxorSic. Orig. Maestrissima. H. M. P.

DIV4.P: On another Grave-stone is this In∣scription.

Q.P: Hic jacet Johannes Dyke, A. M. hu∣jus Ecclesiae Can. Min. qui obiit 19 Die Januarii, 1604.
Hic jacet in fossa, fossae qui nomen habebat Et tumulum, multos qui tumulavit, habet.

DIV4.P: There were more Verses on this Brass, but now stolen away.
On another Grave-stone is the follow∣ing Inscription.
DIV4.Q:
Here lies the Body of Will. Child, Dr. of Musick, one of the Organists at the Chappell Royall at Whitehall, and of his Majesties Free Chappell at Windsor 65 Years. He was born in Bristol, and died here the 23d of March, 1697. in the 91st Year of his Age. He paved the Body of the Choir.
Go happy Soul, and in the Seats above,
Sing endless Hymns of thy great Maker's Love;
How fit in heavenly Songs to bear thy Part,
Before well practiced in the sacred Art?
Whilst hearing us, sometimes the Choir Di∣vine
Will sure descend, and in our Consort joyn;
So much the Musick, thou to us has given,
Has made our Earth to represent your Hea∣ven.
DIV4.P: On a Grave-stone, near the West End of the Church, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q:
H. S. E. Paucorum Annorum, sed Optimae Spei Puer, Tenerae Aetatis flosculus, sed coelo maturus, THOMAS, Edovardi Jones, Hujus Ecclesiae Canonici, & Catharinae Uxoris Filius alter, Amor Parentum, Amicorum desiderium, Obiit 2do. Martii, Anno
Dom. 1704.
Aetat. 6.
DIV4.P: On another Grave-stone is this follow∣ing Inscription.

Q.P:
Hic sepultus jacet THOMAS, Filius natu quartus THOMAE GODDARD, Hujusce Lib. Capellae Reg. Canonici, et ANNAE Uxoris, Puer Optimae Indolis, et Vivacissimi Ingenii,
Mortuus
Sepultus
est
19
21
Sept. 1710.
Aetat. 6. etiam Henricus filius sextus natus et sepultus eodem Anno, Quo moriebatur Frater.

DIV4.P: On a Black Marble Grave-stone, near the West End, are these Arms, a Lion Rampant, Crest, a Hand issuing out of a Wreath, holding a Sword, and the fol∣lowing Inscription.
DIV4.Q:
Pax quaeritur Bello. To the Memory of Major WILLIAM GAY, who honourably served King Charles the Second,
King James the Second, King William the Third, and Queen Anne, who departed this Life the 5th. Day of November, Anno Dni. 1711. aged 75.
DIV4.P: On another Black Marble Grave-stone is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Here lyeth the Body of Ferdinando Ivey, who served King Charles the first during the whole Civill WarreSic. Orig. in Armes; and dyed one of the poor Knights of this Castle, Novemb. the 26. 1695. aged 75.
DIV4.P: In the North Ile, on a Black Marble Grave-stone, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Here lyes the Body of John Brisben, Es{que} who served King ChrlesSic. Orig. the Second in many honourable Imployments, and died Envoy Extraordinary for Portugall, in the Year 1684. aged 46 Years.
DIV4.P:
Near the first Haut Pace, in the Choir of this Chapel, were interred the Bodies of King Henry the VIIIth. and according to Clarendon, Jane Seymour his Wife; but it is said to have been his last Queen, Ka∣therine Parr, according to Mr. Ashmole: A noble Author ends this King's Life with wishing that he could leave him in his Grave, which seems to have put an autho∣ritative Stamp on that fabulous Story raised on his Daughter Queen Mary, that she was so bigotted, as to permit the burn∣ing of her Father's dead Body, as a Here∣tick; but I think her own Character (fair enough, notwithstanding all the Obloquy thrown on it) would sufficiently clear her from such an Inhumanity.
