But there is said to be stronger, as well as later Evi∣dence of its falsity: At the Burial of King Charles the Ist. of Blessed Memory, who was laid in the same Vault, with his Head lying over against the Eleventh Stall, on the Soveraign's Side; the Earl of Cla∣rendon tells us, in his History of the Rebelli∣on, printed in 8v°. at Oxford 1707, Vol. 5. pag. 260. that King Charles I. was interred only near; (whereas our Author, Mr. Ash∣mole, says it was in the very Vault of King Henry VIII.) but I wonder not at all at their Disagreement, when I consider they
both might have received it from the Re∣ports of Persons present, who in the Confusi∣on they were in at the Funeral, might have easily been mistaken; but where-ever King Charles Ist's Body was laid, by the Care of the rebellious Governor of this Castle, Whit∣chcot, after the Restoration, neither Grave nor Corpse could be found, tho' no small search was made after it, when an honourable Interment was designed, and some Persons then alive present at the Solemnity, giving this Account to the King (Charles II.) the thought of that Remove was laid aside; and the Reason communicated to very few, for the better discountenancing farther Enquiry. Our noble Historian, in pag. 260, and 261. is more particular than I have here, to avoid Repetition, mentioned. On the other Hand, Dr. Nalton in his Preface to the King's Trial, tells the World, that when the Long Parliament had voted an honour∣able Interment for their late Prince, who had suffer'd so unjustly, all was stopt, by reason that the Persons order'd to regulate the Ceremony, when they came to examine the Royal Coffin, found the Body missing. This, says an AnonymousThe Secret History of the Calves Head Club, compleat: Or, The Republican Unmasked, &c. 5th Edit. Lond. 1705. vo. pag. 14, 15. Author, (upon
what Grounds he knows best) “puts me in mind of what a worthy Gentle∣man, who travelled with Lord A— into Italy, told me some Years ago, viz. that during his short stay at Bern, in Switzerland, a Syndic of the Town, who used frequently to visit Major Ge∣neral Ludlow, heard him in a vaunting manner affirm, That tho' Ireton and Cromwell were buried under Tyburn, yet 'twas a Comfort to him, that the Roy∣al Martyr kept them Company; for, says he, foreseeing that his Son would undoubtedly come in, we took care that his Father's Body should not be idolatrously worshipped by the Cava∣liers, and therefore privately removed it to the Place of common Execution.”

In the Choir are several Stalls, on which the Arms and Title of every Knight of the Garter are engraven on Copper Plates, from which they are never re∣moved, though the Banners hanging over are taken down on the Death of each Knight, to give Place to his Successor.
In the Roof, over the Body of the Church, are these Arms.

LIST.ITEM: 2. France and England quarterly, sup∣ported by a Dragon and a Grey Hound.
3. In the Roof of the South Ile France and England as before.
4. In the Cross Iles both North and South the same.

DIV4.P:
In the Roof of the Choir.
1. A Rose supported by a Dragon and Grey Hound.
2. A Portcullis held by an Angel.
3. A Portcullis crown'd, and supported by a Dragon and Griffin.
4. France and England quarterly as above.
5. Edward the Confessor supported by 2 Angels.
6. A Shield of St. George held by an Angel.
On the South Side of the Roof.

LIST.ITEM: 1. The Stafford's Knot within a Garter.
2. A Rose encompassed with Sun Beams, and surrounded with the Garter.
4. An Horse and Oak-Tree within a Garter.

DIV4.P: On the North Side of the aforesaid Roof.

LIST.ITEM: 1. A Rose surrounded with Sun Beams.
5. A Rose, and a Wing united by a Knot a Shield, whereon is a ragged Staff impal▪
11. A Cock, or some such Bird.

DIV4.P: These Royal Letters are cut on divers Knobs on both Sides the Arch over the Choir and crown'd.
On the Roof on the Side.

LIST.ITEM: 1. France and England quart. support∣ed by 2 Lions.
2. A Rose encompassed with the Rays of the Sun.

DIV4.P: Near the Church, towards the East End, are Situate the CLOYSTERS, where∣in the poor Knights, and others, are interred.
In the East Cloyster, on a small Mar∣ble Slab, in the Wall, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: To the Memory of James Mauleverer, of Arncliffe, in the County of York, Gent, sometyme Governour of the poor Knights, who departed this Life the 17th. of Aprill, 1703. aged 75.
DIV4.P: On a Grave-stone is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q:
Here lyeth the Body of Matthew Greene, Gent. who was one of the Gent. of this his Majesties Free Chappell Royal 40
Yeares, and also Master of the Choiristers. He departed this Life the 8th Day of November, 1703. aged 81.
DIV4.P: On another Grave-stone is this Inscrip∣tion.
DIV4.Q: Here lyeth the Body of Mr. Robert Boucher, of Enstone, in the County of Oxon, who was one of his Majesties poor Knights of this Castle, who departed this Life the 5th Day of July, 1715. aged 81 Yeares.
DIV4.P: On another Grave-stone is this follow∣ing Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Here lyes the Body of Mrs. Eliz. Paterson, Daughtr. of Capt. Whyt, Wife of Capt. Robt. Paterson, of the British Fuzelliers, who departed this Life the 8th of March, 171-14. aged 26 Years.
DIV4.P: On another Grave-stone is the follow∣ing Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Here lyeth the Body of Capt. Richard Leader, who departed this Life the 17th of Aprill, 1706. aged 61 Yeares.
DIV4.P: On another Grave-stone is the follow∣ing Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Here lyeth the Body of Alexander James, Gen. 1706.
DIV4.P: On a small Marble Slab, in the Wall, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Neare this Place lyeth the Body of Lieutent. Alexander James, of Grade, near Helstone, in Cornwall, one of the poor Knts. of this Church, who departed this Life, Mar. 29. 1706. Aetat. 88.
DIV4.P: On another Grave-stone is this In∣scription.
DIV4.Q: Here lyeth the Body of Capt. Thomas Baskervill, late one of the poore Knights of this Place, who faithfully served King Charles the first, of glorious Memory, maintaineingSic. Orig. a Troop of Horse at his owne Charge. He departed this Life the 7th Day of March, Anno Dom. 1711. aged 106.
DIV4.P: On the East Wall of the North Cloyster, on a small Marble Slab, is this Inscripti∣on following.
DIV4.Q:
Near this Place lyeth the Body of EDMUND HOOK, Gent. of Bramshott, in Hampshire, sometime Governour of the poor Knights, who departed this Life
the 11th Day of July, in the Year of our Lord 1707. and of his Age 85.
DIV4.P: On a Grave-stone, in the North Ile, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Here lyeth the Body of Capt. Alexander Storey, who departed this Life the 15th of Feb. 170-09. aged 92.
DIV4.P: On another Grave-stone, in the same Ile, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Here lyeth the Body of Capt. John Baynes, who departed this Life the 3d of September, 1711. aged 112.
DIV4.P: On a small Grave-stone, in the same Ile, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Here lyeth the Body of Mrs. Rachel Hartley, Sister to Dr. Wickart, 1717.
DIV4.P: On a Brass Plate, fixed in the North Wall, in Capitals, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Near this Place lyeth the Body of Captain Richard Vaughan, of Pantglas, in the County of Carnarvon, who behaved himself with great Courage in the Service of King Charles the First (of ever blessed Memory) in the Civill Warrs, and therein lost his Sight by a Shott: In recompence whereof he was in July, 1663. made one of the poor Knights of this Place, and dyed the 5th Day of June, Anno Dom. 1700. in the 80th Year of his Age.
DIV4.P: In the West Cloyster, on a Grave-stone, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Here lieth the Body of Capt. Daniell Donn, of Carmarthenshire, South Wales, one of his Majesties poor Knights of this Castle, who departed this Life the 8th Day of Aprill, 1697. in the 76 Year of his Age, and was buried the 11th.
DIV4.P: In the South Cloyster, on a Grave-stone, in Capitals, is this Inscription.

Q.P: Here lyeth the Body of Mr. Zachary Irish, one of the Petti-Canons, and Sub-Chantor of this Church, who departed this Life the 10 of June, Anno Dni. 1672. aged 67 Yeares.
Here also lyeth the Body of Mrs. Urith Irish, the Wife of Mr. Zachary Irish, who departed this Life the 20 of June, An°, Dni. 1670. aged 62 Yeares

DIV4.P: On the North Side of the Church, on the paved Walk, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Here lyeth the Body of Nathanael Vestment, one of the Gentlemen of her Majesties Chapell Royal of Whitehall, and of this Free Chappell, and of Eton College. He departed this Life the 23 of August, 1702. aged 42 Years.
DIV4.P: On another Black Stone Tomb is this Inscription.

Q.P: Here lieth the Body of Mr. William Howe, late Gent. of the Chappell to King Charles the First, of blessed Memory; to his most sacred Majesty King Charles the Second that now is, and Petit-Canon of his Majesties Free Chappell, in all which he lived 46 Yeares, and having laboured in his Calling with equall Industry and Skill to the good of maney, and Satisfaction of all, at length left this Life for a better in a good old Age. He dyed aged 66 Yeares, on the 21 of Aprill, Anno Dom. 1676.
As also the Body of Anne his Wife, who dyed February the 1st. 1680. aged 63 Years.

DIV4.P: On a Brass Plate, fix'd in the Wall, near the North Door, is this Inscription.
DIV4.Q:
Here lieth George Brooke, some∣tyme Yeoman of the Guard unto K. Hen. 8. Ed. 6. Q. Mary Q. Elis. and now is until the Time of his Death, who died the 24 of October, 1593. in the 35th Year of her Majesties Reign.
He lived Content with mean Estate,
And long ago prepared to die,
The Idle Person he did hate,
Poor Peoples Wants he did supply.
DIV4.P: The foregoing is the original Inscription.
DIV4.Q: Out of a Respect to the Memory of the deceased, and also to the Honour and Antiquity of the said Guard, this Plate was repaired, enlarged, and engraven at the sole Charge of Edward Phillips, Citizen and Merchant-Taylor of London, and one of the 100 Yeomen of the Guard to King William the III. and Queen Mary the II. of Blessed Memory, and now to her Majesty Queen Anne, in the 6th Year of her Reign, and the 52d Year of his Age, Anno Dom. 1707.
DIV4.P: On a Tomb Northward, on the out∣side of the Church, within the Rails, is this Inscription.

Q.P: M. S. THOMAE BROWNE, olim Aed. Christi, Oxon. S. T. D. qui 36. Annos Windsorii Sacelli Regii Canonicus, 4. Annos Caroli primi Beatiss. Memoriae, 14.
Annos Illustriss. Principis Henriettae Mariae, Sacellanus extitit, Verun tamen ob Pietatem DEO, Fidemque Regi Patria necnon muniis hisce sacris exulans foris publico Patriae dispendio diu delituit.

Quippe Suffragiis audivit omnium Vir apprime doctus et eruditus, Criticus acutus, Facundus Orator, Faelix Philologus, Antiquitatum Chronologioeque cultor solertissimus Aenigmatum, Dilemmatumque, Conscientiarum Dubitantium OEdipus admodum Christianus; verbo, vir frugi, eoque parce providus, ut amicis omnibusque foret munificè beneficus,

Qui denique per varius turbulenti saeculi vicissitudines agitatus, et cum Beato Apostolo alternatim dextrae sinistr aequae flatibus famoe expositus, tandem sub hoc portu humanle salutis MDCLXXIII. Aetatisque LXX. complicatis aerumnarum carbasis heic anchoram defixit.

DIV4.P:
Adjoyning to the East End of this Chapel is a fair Edifice of Free-stone, raised by the most munificent Cardinal Wolsey, called the Tomb-House, from a stately Tomb which the Cardinal de∣signed, some say for himself, others with more Truth, for his Master, King Henry VIII. this he had near finished before his
unhappy Fall, and more miserable Death. This Place King Charles I. designed to en∣large, and make it a proper Dormitory for himself and all succeeding Royal Families; but the worst of Times hasting on him, his Thoughts were diverted another Way, and the Place and imperfect Tomb were demolished and defaced, by the Command of the Rebel Parliament, on April 6. 1646. and all the Statues, and Figures of gilt Copper, of an exquisite Workman∣ship, made for its Ornament, taken from thence, and clandestinely made away with. Some Years after, upon some other Thoughts, the famous Verrio was employed in the painting of the Roof, and is said to have in this Place exceeded all his other Labours, and out-done him∣self: Pity it is that this beautiful Roof is not more exposed to the publick View, and the Place it self kept in better Order. The Design and Scheme of this Piece of Painting is in it self very proper, and deserves the ablest Pen to give an equal Description; but since none have yet gratified the World, take the following, as communicated to me by a worthy Gen∣tleman, who, though altogether unskilled in these Affairs, was unwilling this should be entirely omitted, viz.

Ist. King James the Second in his Royal Garter Robes, holding a Scepter in his Hand, is seated on a triumphal Arch; over him, Westward, are the Representations of several Poetical Deities; a Crown is held over his sacred Head by Two Figures of Time and Peace (as I conceive) over these an Angel holds a Scrowl with this Inscription.

DIV4.HEAD: CONCORDIA FRATRUM.
DIV4.P: IId. Below him, Eastward, are more of the Gods, as Mars, &c. beating down, and destroying Faction, Fury, Sedition, Re∣bellion, &c.
IIId. At the East End, in two Ovals, are two several Figures of King Charles the Martyr, with a Scrowl bearing this Inscription over him.

DIV4.HEAD: CALAMITAS PUBLICAS.Sic. Crig.
DIV4.P: On the North Side of St. George's Chapel, is a House built for the Habitation of the Priest that officiated in the Chantry of Wil∣liam Lord Hastings, whose Arms, surround∣ed with a Garter, is fixed over the Door.
Adjoyning to this is another House, built by Charles Somerset, Lord Herbert, and Earl of Worcester, for his Chantry Priest; and over the Door, as a Distincti∣on, are his Arms in a Garter.

Against the North Door of the Body of this Church, is a House called the New Commons, erected by James Denton, Dean of Lichfield, and formerly one of the Ca∣nons of this Church, Anno 1519. for the Lodging and Dieting of such of the Chan∣try Priests, Choristers, and Stipendiaries, who had no certain Place within the Col∣lege where to hold Commons in, but were constrained daily to eat their Meals in se∣veral Houses of the Town: This House he furnished with proper Utensils for such an Use, the whole Charge amounting to 489 l. 7 s. 1 d. and for all which the Cho∣risters were desired by him (in the Statutes ordained for their Rule and Government) to say certain Prayers, when they entred into the Chapel, and after his Death, to pray for his, and the Souls of all the faith∣ful departed.

On the North Side are Houses for the Dean and Canons, and at the West End others for the Petty Canons, built in the shape of a Fet-Lock (one of the Royal Badges belonging to King Edward IV.) in the Reign of King Henry VIII.
In the Dean's House, on a Tablet of the Coats of Arms of the Knights of the Garter, is this Inscription.

Q.P: AETERNAE, AUGUSTAE LAURO BRITANNICAE. ab EDWARDO III ante annos 300 Plantatae, Et a Successorum ejus optimo Maximo Fotae, Tam faelix dedit Deus Incrementum, Ut in umbra illius glorientur Reges terrae, Ex hac lauro desumptam LAUREAM CAROLINAM Cujus Baccae singulae Hinc Principum nominibus Gentilitiis Splendent, Illinc coronis virtutum maximarum praemiis, Fulgent Cuivis Folia singula, Hinc Armorum Insignìbus bellica virtute partis Illinc honorum Titulis Pacis artibus acquisitis Turgent.
Ad Immortalm Gloriam NOMINIS CAROLINI, In AUGUSTO PATRE ORBIS hujus Monarcha Et CAESARE FILIO Juventutis PRINCEPS Faelicissimi.

Et honoratissimae Societatis Commilitonum Qui sub illo florent Sacro hoc Emblemate suspiciendam proponit Humillimus illius ORDINIS Servus et Scriba.
Christopherus Wren, Decanus Windsoriensis. 1638.

DIV4.P: This Square (in which is the Library) is surrounded by a high Wall with several Towers on it.

On the South Side of the lower Ward of this Castle is a Pile of Building for Thir∣teen of the poor Knight, which contains 13 Rooms, besides a Hall, a Kitchen, and a Pastry. The Stone for Building was brought from Reading, in this County, the Timber from several Places in the Forest, and the Lead and Chimney Orna∣ments from Suffolk Place in Southwark. This Work was begun on the last Day of February, 1556. and compleated 25 Septem∣ber, 1558. and cost 2747 l. 7 s. 6 d. and is allotted for the poor Knights, who were coaeval with the first Foundation, and were then in Number 24, and afterwards encreased to 26, and so continued to 1481. when upon Account of many tedious Quarrels and Brawls between them and the Dean and Canons, they were en∣tirely dropt in the Act of Parliament for the new Incorporation of this Church, and divided from its Constitution. It appears by the last Will of King Henry VIII. that he designed a Re-establish∣ment of this Order, and a Reduction to
Thirteen, and ordered a Settlement of 600 Pounds per Annum to be made on the Dean and Canons for that end: This King Edw. VI. confirmed Octob. 7. 1549. and immediately after put the Chapter into Possession, who for a short space received the Rents, but were constrained to return the whole Settlement back, to be employ∣ed in building a proper Receptacle for these poor Knights. But Queen Elizabeth settled the Foundation, Number, Statutes, and Endowment, as they now stand, which last was doubled by King James I. and made payable out of the Exchequer. To these Thirteen Sir Peter le Maire, Kt. by his last Will, dated 8 January, 1631. added by a Legacy of 1500 Pounds for charitable Uses, at the disposal of his Exe∣cutor, Sir Francis Crane, Kt. sometime Chancellor of the most noble Order of the Garter, who himself designing an addi∣tional Number of Alms Knights, deter∣mine to spend the 1500 Pounds he was en∣trusted with, on a Pile of Building for the Reception of Five he intended; to this end he charged his Executor, Sir Richard Crane, Bar. in his last Will, dated 27 August, 1635. to see the Buildings, him∣self had begun, finished; he also bequeath∣ed for ever 200 Pounds per Annum to be settled in Land by his Executor, according
to the Advice and Direction of Thomas, then Earl of Arundel and Survey, and Henry Lord Matrevers, his eldest Son, for the perpe∣tual Maintenance of five Alms Knights, viz. 40 Pounds per Annum to each. But Charity, as usual, being carried on very slowly, and meeting with many Inter∣ruptions, it was at last determined in the Court of Chancery, 19 July, 1655. that the 200 Pounds per Annum should be re∣gularly paid out of the whole Estate of Sir Richard Crane aforementioned, and that the Expences of the Building should be discharged out of his personal Estate; upon this Decree the Building against the West Wall, in the lower Ward, between the Chancellor's and Garter's Towers, was again undertaken, and soon finished, at the Expence of 1700 Pounds. At last, at the end of this Suit, on Jan. 27. 1659. it was decreed that the Manor of Carbrooko, in Norfolk, should for ever stand charged with 200 Pounds per Annum, and 20 Pounds more annually for all future acci∣dental Repairs to this Building, and the whole to be pay'd quarterly in four equal Portions. But enough of this, which is so amply accounted for by our Author, Mr. Ashmole, elsewhere. I shall here omit any mention of the Knights of the Garter, the Officers of that Order, Mem∣bers,
or Servants of the Church, their Statutes, Endowments, Privileges, &c. which are all so much enlarged on in the Excellent History of the Garter, to which I refer my Reader for farther Satisfaction; and as to the Succession of the Dean and Canons, and their History, Mr. Frith's Catalogue in its original Language is hereunto annexed, and the proper Ad∣ditions made to it.

Over against the Stone Bridge which leads into the upper Court, is a neat lit∣tle Seat, purchased by the late Queen be∣fore her Accession to the Throne, and during her being in Disgrace with her Brother, K. William III. The fine Green House, and Gardens adjoyning to the Park, are worthy the Notice of all.

Between the Castle and the little House is a Passage into the Little Park, (so called to distinguish it from the larger) which is about Three Miles in compass, the Walks are finely shaded, and is well stock'd with Deer. In this Park, near the Road side, from Old Windsor, is the Keeper's Lodge, a very beautiful Retire∣ment, which received great Improvements from the late Admiral Churchill, who made a fine Aviary and Gardens. The House of Office must not be passed over, adorned with the History of Cortez, the
famous Spanish General, his Expedition to Mexico in America, &c. all painted on Mother of Pearl, being part of that in∣famous Plunder committed at Port St. Mary's and Vigo; and by some of the Actors in it presented to the Admiral.

Facing this Park, and near the Castle, is a handsom Seat belonging to Charles Beauclair, Duke of St. Albans, one of the Knights of the Garter, which was built by his Mother, in the Reign of K. Charles II.

Adjoyning to this Little Park is another larger, containing Fourteen Miles in its Circumference. It is stocked with all Sorts of Game for the Royal Diversion. In it King Charles II. built a Lodge for the Use of the Keeper, and for his own Diversion. It received many Additions and Advantages from the late Earl of Portland; and since from the present Ran∣ger, the Dutchess of Marlborough.

About a Mile from hence, in the Forest, on the top of a Hill, is CRANBURN Lodge, built by Richard Jones, late Earl of Ranelaugh, Pay-Master to the Army during the Time of K. William III. Here is visible an elegant Taste of Architecture, Painting, and Gardening, but more remarkable for the spaciousness of its Prospect. In one of the Closets,
which has Windows on every Side, is a View over Windsor, and both the Parks, East∣ward to London, and the Country round, at above Twenty Miles distance, and Westward a fine View of easy rising Grounds covered with Trees; in short, every Way the Prospect is delightful: Nor has Art been less profuse than Na∣ture, if we consider the large and fine Gardens, the Fish-Ponds, and curious Greenswerd Descent to them, which, with the other Improvement, must have cost much Time, and have been very expen∣sive. Not long since a Bill was brought into Parliament for a Sale of this Estate, but on February 24, 1717-18. it was rejected.

About the Year 1705. at St. Leonard's Hill, about a Mile and half from Wind∣sor Castle were found the Roman Anti∣quities (of which you have the Draughts in the Page) under a large Stone by Mr. Robert Butler, a Gardiner: In dig∣ging he observed a considerable Quantity of Ashes, Cinders, &c. upon the Brow of the Hill, and found also several Earthen Vessels, entire as well as broke, some of larger, and others of smaller Dimensions, some of which the Gardiner conceived to be Molds: At the same Place were found many fair, intelligible Silver and Brass Roman Coins. This Place was, I doubt
not, part of the antient Bibroci, who submitted to Caesar, and a Roman Camp at no great distance, seems to favour the Notion of this having been a Fabrica, or Forge for the making of their Warlike In∣struments.

To what Uses the Instruments (here delineated) have been put, is a Question among the Learned; as to (Numb. I. and III.) some have conjectured them British, and to have been Axes, Others Heads of Spears, or walking Staves used by the Britons, Others Roman Catapulta; some have thought them to be sacrificing In∣struments; but these Notions, and se∣veral others, having been refuted by Mr. Hearne, and the Matter it self clearly stated concerning these two Instruments, I shall refer you to his Discourse concerning some Antiquities lately found in Yorkshire, in a Letter to Mr. Thoresby, of Leeds, with an Extract out of Mr. Thoresby's Letter (dated Nov. 19. 1709.) that occa∣sioned this Discourse, printed at the End of the first Vol. of John Leland's Itinerary, Oxford, 1710. 8 vo. pag. 97. In this ex∣cellent Piece, the Matter seems to be ac∣curately examined, and the Opinions of Antients and Moderns weigh'd, and the Affair it self exhausted. (Numb. II.) I take to be the Head of an Arrow, Dart, or
Javelin. (Numb. IV.) gave me some trou∣ble to find out a Lamp (for such I take it to be) like it, already described: In particular, I carefully consulted a Piece wrote ex pro∣fesso on the Subject of the antient Sepul∣chral Lamps, entitled, Le Antiche Lu∣cerne Sepolcrali figurate raccolte dalle Cave sotterannee, Grottee di Roma nelle quali∣si contengono molte erudite Memorie diseg∣nate, ed intagliate nelle loroforme d Pietro Sancti Bartoli divisee in tre parti con POsservationi di Gio. Pietro Bellori. Rom. 1691. Fol. but among that great Variety in this excellent and useful Piece, I could find no Resemblance, or gather any Light. I cannot say that in some o∣thers on this Subject I do remember any Thing of this Figure, though I have not been so happy as to see Licetus on this Subject; but a midst these my Searches and Enquiries, a worthy Gentleman was pleased to communicate to me a Book entitled, Batavia Illustrata, seu de Bata∣vorum Insula, Hollandia, Zelandia, Frisia, Territorio Trajectensi, et Gelria, Scriptores varii not melioris nunc pri∣mum Collecti simulque Editi. Ex Musaeo Petri Scriverii, Lugd. Batav. 1609. 4to. herein, pag. 217. I found a Lamp very much, though not altogether, like this, which our Author calls Lucerna Poly∣myxos,
which was found at Romaeoburgi, i. e. Roomburgh, near Leyden; he describes it in the same Page in this manner, Lam∣padem oeneam, quadrifidam (quae in qua∣tuor veluti guttos exit unde Ellychnia flammam vomebant, et in quarteras, co∣lumnas circinarum coelum excipientes assur∣git) istic repertam asservat, et expressam opera Pictoris communicavit, ut hic ap∣ponetur, Cornelius Nicolaus Aquanus, homo Antiquitatis studiofissimus. Of this Sort of Lamp, Martial speaks in his Epigram on LUCERNA POLYMYXOS, Lib. 14.
DIV4.Q: Illustrem quum tota meis convivia flammis, Totque geram Myxas, una Lucerna vocor.
DIV4.P:
In consulting several Authors to dis∣cover the Uses Numb. V. and VI. were put to, I have been no ways negligent, but cannot be so happy as to make any Discovery, or a meer probable Con∣jecture. I must question whether they are Roman or Danish; the several Sorts of Things discovered here do but per∣plex us; in particular, a very large, long Spur, which undoubtedly belong∣ed to the Danes, and of which there is one now preserved in the Physick School near the Bodleian Library in Oxford. Wa∣ving
therefore all impertinent Conje∣ctures, I shall leave this Subject: to be more at large enquired into by the Lo∣vers of Antiquity, and return my Thanks to the, worthy GENTLEMAN, who was pleased to take the Draughts of these Curiosities, and communicated them to the Editor of this Work.

DIV1.P: CATALOGUS DECANORUM, NECNON CANONICORUM Liberae Capellae Regiae STI. GEORGII, Infra Castrum de WINDESORE, In Ordinem redactus.
A THOMA FRYTH, Ejusdem Ecclesiae Canonico, & ab aliis auctus, & ad hunc Annum 1718. con∣tinua serie deductus.
LONDINI, MDCCXVIII.

DIV1.HEAD: CATALOGUS Custodum sive Decanorum Liberae Capellae Regiae STI. GEORGII, INFRA Castrum de WINDESORE. NECNON Canonicorum sive Prebendariorum ibidem.
DIV1.P:
EX Archivis ejusdem Liberae Ca∣pellae collectus, & in ordinem, juxta annorum in quibus instal∣lati sunt, seriem redactus, Ann. Dom. 1618. & Sereniss. Reg. Jac. 16o. Quo tempore ex Praede∣cessorum negligentiâ & incuriâ, si non impro∣bitate quorundam factum est, ut quam plurima ejusdem Capellae Munimenta, unde haec &
hujusmodi magis exquisitè peti possint & debe∣rent, vel deperdita sunt, vel malâ fide servata, vel saltem imperfecta & mutilata habebantur.
Cum continuatione ejusdem usque ad annum praesentem.

Haec autem memorialia quasi è tenebris eruta, & in lucem hanc nostram Windsorianam edita sunt operâ & industria Thomae Fryth, praefatae li∣berae Capellae Canonici, qui hoc quale quale stu∣dium suum impendit, tum ut demortuorum no∣mina saltem in memoriam revocaret. Eorum∣que quam plurimorum qui optima d hac nostra republica literaria promeruerunt, quorum fama melior est unguento pretioso: Nonnullorum vero qui & propriam suam & aliorum memo∣riam flocci pendentes (quamvis memoria justi in benedictione erit sempiterna, nomen autem improborum putrescet) neque monumenta pro∣pria ex rebus bene gestis sibimet erigere, neque munimenta publica de rebus utcunque geis posteris promittere curarunt: quia potius bo∣num publicum privato commodo postponentes, universa (saltem temporalem Collegii statum spectantia) susque deque habuerunt. Imo pes∣sum ire vel procurarunt vel promiserunt: dum haereditamenta Collegii pleraque prorsus & in perpetuum abalienarunt, plurimaque alia ad tempus immensum dimiserunt, prout in sequen∣tibus, in Catalogo Decanorum hujus Capellae patebit.

DIV1.HEAD: CUSTODES ive DECANI.
DIV1.P: GULIELMUS MUGG, per D. Reg. Edw. 3. Fundatorem, Custos primus constitutus est Ann. Reg. sui 22. Dom. 1348. Benefactor, cujus Obitus celebratus est 20 Feb. Custos uit per triginta & duos annos.

Quamvis Statuta Collegii, & Constitutiones, juxta quas, Custos sive Decanus & Canonici, unà cum ministris ibidem regulari debent, non sunt edita ante ann. 26 dicti Regis, constat ta∣men quod praefatus Rex per Literas suas Paten∣tes fundationem instituit, dictumque Custodem & 8 Canonicos de duodecim inibi sustentandos in hac Liberae Capelia constituit Ann. Reg. 22. quibus tantum de Thesauro suo annis singulis Clarigi concessit, quantum cum emolumento ex Ecclesiis de Wyrardsbury, Southanton & Utto∣zatre, dictis Custode & Canonicis praeconcesso proveniente, ad supportationem omnium one∣rum & juxta condecentiam statûs sui sufficiens videretur, quousque de bonis immobilibus, ter∣ris seu reditibus usque ad summam mille librarum
annuatim per semetipsum provisum uerit. (Sic enim in dictis Literis Patentibus habetur) dat. 6 Aug. Ann. 22 praedicto.
WALTERUS ALMALY, sive ALMARY, Ca∣nonicus dictae Capellae, installatus Custos 26 Feb. 1380. 4 Ric. 2. Custos per 20 Annos.
THOMAS BUTTILLER, Archi-Diaconus de Northampton, ex Canonico installatus Custos 1403. 3 Hen. 4. Cust. per 9 Annos.

Forsa Ricardus. THOMAS KINGSTONE, tertius suit a Ca∣nonicatu ad Praefectuarum in hac Libera Ca∣pella promotus. Primus vero qui per nomen Decani praesentatus per Regem Hen. 4. Ann. Reg. ult. Dom. 1412. Decanus per 5 Ann.

JOHANNES ARUNDELL, qui, etiam sicut om∣nes Successores sui, per nomen Decani praesen∣tatus est. Installatus 1417. 6 Hen. 5. Decan. 30 Ann. Isto Johanne Arundell, Decano, omnia spiritualia, hoc est omnes Rectoriae, decimae & decimarum portiones una cum Ecclesiastica Jurisdictione Prioratui de Okeburne Alienig. in Com. Wilts, à Monasterio Beccensi, in Norman∣nia dependenti, spectantia, huic Collegio per oem Bedfordiae Ducem, concessa sunt & an∣nexa. Per Literas vero Patentes Reg. Hen. 5. confirmata & stabilita, postquam Prioraus alienigeni Universi per totum Regnum Angliae p aefato Regi per Parliamentum Leicestriae ten∣tum, preconcessi sunt.

Nova etiam ejusdem Capellae Incorporatio per nomen Decani sive Custodis, & Canonico∣rum, &c. instituta est; totusque Collegii status
unà cum possessionibus ejusdem corroboratus, & quasi de novo Constitutus est ex decreto Par∣liamenti. Idemque Decanus Registrum hujus Collegiivetus, membranum affabre conscriptum, Vocat. The White Leiger Book, composuit, vel propriis suis sumptibus componi fecit.

THOMAS MANNING, installatus Decanus 1452. 31 Hen. 6. Decanus per 10 Annos. Quamvis juxta praescriptas primi Fundatoris Le∣ges, non licuit Decano & Canonicis terras & tenementa Collegii ad firmam dimittere ultra quinquennium, quod quidem statutum per di∣versas Successiones sartum tectum habebator, tamen circa hoc tempus effugium quoddam ex cogitarunt, unde se ex hac tanta angustia ex∣tricarent. Dictas scilicet terras dimittendo ad quinquennium usque ad terminum 20, aut 30, aut fortasse 40 Annorum, sed non ultrà, quam formam & modum postea per alias fere totidem Successiones observarunt.

JOHAN. FAUX, installatus 1462. 2 Edw. 4. obiit 1470. Decanus per 8 Annos. Qua De∣cano, Rex Edw. Maneria de Ashorston, in Com. Warw. de Chesingbury, in Wilts, & de Quarte in Com. Southampt. Prioratum de Uphaven, Deca∣natum S. Burianae in Cornubia, & annuam pen∣sionem de XX lib. ex Rectoria de Rotheram, in Com. Ebor. uno eodemque Diplomate con∣cessit. Sed ex his omnibus Pensionem tantum de Rotheram possidemus, Manerium de Chesing∣bury ad paucos annos possiderunt Praedecesso∣res nostri, sed quomodo, vel quâ de causâ ab eodem recesserunt, non constat, de reliquis nihil unquam habuerunt.

Etonense etiam Collegium Authoritate Regali nec non Papali Pii, scil. 2. huic Regiae Capellae annectitur & appropriatur. Pensionibus qui∣busdam Praeposito & Sociis, &c. ad terminum vitae eorum assignatis. Sed Gulielm Westbury, tunc Praepositus, summa prudentiâ & animae fortitudine praeditus, huic Unioni acquiescere noluit, sed se totis viribus opposuit: Unde post aliquantulam, regnante Ed. 4, mutationem, tamque praeclari aedificii ruinam minitantem, fundatio praedicta, Henrico 7. rerum potito, au∣thoritate Parliamenti redintegratur & stabilitur. Bulla praedicti Pii 2. per Papam Paulum 2. prius revocata & annihilata.
GULIELMUS MORLAND, installatus per Pro∣curatorem 26 Febr. 1470. 10 Ed. 4. & in per∣sona sua 8 Martii, Decanus per Anm 1. & 8 menses.
JOHANNES DAVISON, install. 30 Octob. 1471. 11 Edw. 4. ad Decanatum Sarum translatus 1473. Decanus per 2 Ann.

GULIELMUS DUDLEY. Coll. Univers. Oxon. Alumns, Ecclesiae Collegiatae de Wolverhamp∣ton Praebendarius, cui etiam Benefactor: Johan∣nis Dudleii Baronis filius, postquam Canoni∣catum suum in hac Libera Capellâ resignâsset, An. 1470. installatus est Decanus 4 Dec. 1473. 13 Ed. 4. Episcopus Dunelmensis consecrtu 1476. obiit 1483. Decanus per fere Annos, Tempore Decanatus ejus praefatus D. Rex Edw. Domum sive Hospitale S. Antonii, Lond. (ubi olim Synagoga Judeorm) huic Liberae Capellae adjunxit, una cum possessionibus ejusdem munitis, ac Privilegiorum emolumentis (dum tempus tu∣lit) amplissimis. Nam Possessionum redditus
annui vix aut ne vix quidem ad supportanda onera omnia inde incumbentia sufficiunt. Sed ex privilegio unico (inter alia quam plurima eademque Papalia) hoc est intromittendi por∣cellum S. Antonianum, vulganter vocatum, A Tan∣tony Pig, in unam quamque villam per totum Regnum Angliae, Cum tintinnabulo per collum dependente (cui villani pabulum abude admi∣nistrarunt, eumque in porcum crescentem quot annis saginarunt, quam diu porcos suos pro∣prios benedictionem S. Antonii inde obtiner opinati sunt) Unde Proverbium tunc temporis usitatum, He'll follow one like a Tantony Pig. De∣cani & Canonici sexcentas libras annuas & am∣plius per Procuratores suos percipiebant. Unde ne Denarium quidem hodie capiunt. Tanto lucrosior est superstitio Romana, quam Religio Orthodoxa. Prioratus quoque de Brymesfield, in Com. Glouc. de Cherlton, in Com. Wilts, & Stae. Helenae, in Insula Vectensi, ac Maneria de Bla∣kenham, in Suff. de Pennington, & Wedon, in Dorset, cum diversis aliis terris & tenementis, idem D. Rex per Lit. suas Patentes concessit, de quibus nihil unquam ad Decanum & Cano∣nicos pervenit.

PETRUS COURTNEY, Philippi Courtneii, Eq. Aur. & Elizabethae (filiae Walteri, Baronis Hunger∣ford,) filius, L. L. D. Archi-Diaconus Exon. Mr. Hospitali S. Antonii, Lond. tempore annex∣ationis ejusdem huic Regiae Capellae: Cui De∣canus & Canonici Pensionem annuam 100 Marcarum concedunt, quonia custodiam dicti Hospitalis resignavit, An. 1474. quousque promotus fuerit per D. Regem ad tale benefi∣cium, quale ipseacce ptare voluerit. Unde De∣canus
hic per eundem D. Regem constitutus, installatus 11 Oct. 1476. 16 Edw. 4. ad Episco∣patum Exon. promotus, 1477. & ad Winton. tran∣slatus, 1486. Decan. per. Annum 1. & 6 menses.

RICHARDUS BEAUCHAMP, L. L. D. ex Re∣gali Prosapia ortus, qui per 27 Ann. ante In∣stallationem in Decanatum hunc, fuit Episcopus Sarum. Nam Episcopus consecratus est 1450. & installatus Decan. 1477. 17 Edw. 4. Mar. 4. primus Cancellarius praeclarissimi Ordinis de Garter, Constitutus 10 Feb. 16. Ed. 4. Decanus & Episcopus simulque dicti Ordinis Cancellari∣us per 4 Ann. hoc est, quam diu deinceps vixit.

Reverendus ille Praesul Prioratum de Sandle∣ford, juxta Newbury in Berks, a Monachis dere∣lictum indeque in manus suas devolutum, una cum possessionibus & haereditamentis ejusdem huic Regiae Capellae assignavit & appropriavit.

Eodemque Episcopo adhuc Decano & apud Regiam Majestatem mediante, idem Rex Ed∣wardus Patronus & Benefactor munificentissi∣mus concessit licentiam, pro terris in manu mortua tenendis ad valorem 500 l. per Ann. Praebendam quque de Ecorne, in Com. Dors. & Eccleam de Cheshunt, in Com. Hertf. sed haec Ecclesia processu Legali amissa est Hen. 7. reg∣nante, Domina Margaretta Comitissa Richmon∣diae Actore.

Wolverhampton etiam Decanatus, huic Deca∣natui per eundem D. Regem est unitus, & am∣plissimum illud Manerium de Leighton Bussard, in Bedfords. cum membris suis ex licentia, De∣cano & Canonicis conceditur per Willielmum Ducem Sff. & Miciam Uxorem suam.

THOMAS DANET, S. Theol. D. Eleemosy∣narius D. Regis, ex Canonico installatus Deca∣nus 1481. 21 Edw. 4. Obiit & sepultus est Wind∣sorae Vide pag. 139. juxta ostium domus Capitularis 1483. De∣canus per 2 Annos.
GULIELMUS BENLEY, installatus Anno 1483. 1 Rich. 3. Decanus per Annum 1.

JOHANNES MORGAN, L. L. D. installatus 1484. 2 Rich. 3. consecratus Episcopus Mene∣vensis 1495. Decanus per 11 Annos. Ab. Ann. 1470. ad Ann. 1484. inclusiv, hoc est, infra spatium 15 annorum installati sunt (ut superius patet) octo Decani: quamvis a prima Collegii fundatione usque ad praedictum Ann. 1470. viz. per spatium 122 annorum tantummodo septem in hoc officio praeuerunt.

CHRISTOPHERUS URSEWYKE, Decanus ex Ca∣nonico installatus 20 Nov. 1495. 12 Hen. 7. cui ex secretioribus consiliis, Eleemosynarius sum∣mus. & ad Carolum 8 Francorum Regem Legatus: fuit etiam Decanus Ebor. Hunc inter Cardinales recenset Panvinus, sed fallitur; erat Christope∣rus Bambridge, proximus hujus Decani & hic & Ebor. successor. Obiit 24. Oct. 1521. & sepul∣tus est Hackneiae prop. Lond. ubi etiam Rector fuit. Decanus per 10 Annos.

Ad ejusdem & Canonicorum positionem, Prioratus de Sandleford, cum justa solennitate & secundum exigentiam juris iterum appropriatur per Hen. Episcopum Sarum: Quod perfunctorie & non in Juris forma per Rich. Beauchamp (ut supra) factum est.

His etiam temporibus, eo quod possessiones bonaque nonnulla per D. Regem Edw. 4. De∣cano & Canonicis collata, per potentiam ali∣quorum magnatum substracta fuerunt & detenta, ad valorem ultra summam 400 Marcarum per Ann. bonaque alia & Possessiones hujus Collegii in quibus ex antiquo dotatum erat non medio∣criter diminuta extiterunt, ideo ut de congrua subventionis pe provideretur, Vicaria de North Marston, in Com. Buck. Decano & Canonicis per Willilmum Episcopum Lync. praehabitâ, Licentiâ Regiâ, appropriatur (sed non sine summis impensis summâque hujus Decani & Ca∣nonicorum cura & diligentiâ adhibitâ, nec mi∣nori studio ac labore praestito, cum debita so∣lennitate ac singulis stricti Juris circumstantiis ad apicem usque observatis) quae quidem Vi∣caria in suis proventibus, praesertim in oblati∣onibus factis in Ecclesia ibidem, ex devotione fidelium ad tumbam Magistri Johannis Shorne, dudum Rectoris ibidem copiose confluentium, tam fertilis & abundans extitit, quod ex hujus∣modi oblationibus & proventibus, praefati De∣canus & Canonici in suis necessitatibus releva∣rentur (sic enim permissa in ipso appropriati∣onis Instrumento totidem fere verbis habentur, in qua quidem appropriatione pensiones quae∣dam perpetuae Episcopo Lync. Decano & Capi∣tulo Lync. & Arch-Diacono Bucks: ad summam 40 sol. ad minus per Ann. reservantur, quas hodie Decanus & Canonici ex Rectoria ibidem persolvunt, dum fructus & proventus ipsius Vi∣cariae universi ad sustentandum Curatum idone∣um vix, aut ne vix quidem sufficiunt.
Heu quanto conatu & sumptu, quantisque Praedecessorum exantlatis laboribus, successo∣rum dispendium comparatur. Dum tandem su∣perstitionis caligine dissipata, lux Evangelii elucescere caepit.
Iste demum Decanus Benefactor fuit, ex cujus beneficentia Decanus & Canonici, sicut etiam Choristae & alii non nihil annuatim percipiunt, qui in Domo post festum Paschae intersunt.

CHRISTOPHERUS BAMBRIDGE, vel Bain∣bridge, Coll. Reginae Oxon. Alumnus, cui etiam Benefactor, L. L. D. Custos Rotulorum, De∣canus Ebor. installatus hic Ann. 1505. 21 Hen. 7. Ad Episcopatum Dunelmensem promotus 1507. & ad Archi-Episcopatum Ebor. translatus 1508. In Cardinalium numerum a Papa Julio 2. coop∣tatus 1511. Obiit Romae veneno extinctus 1514. & sepultus est ibidem in Ecclesia S. Trinitatis Anglorum. Decanus per 3 fere Annos.

THOMAS HOBBES, S. Th. D. Coll. Omnium Animarum Oxon. Socius electus 1482. deinde Custos ibid. 1494. Ex Canonico installatus Decanus 1507. 23 Hen. 7. Obiit Windsorae, ubi & sepultus est An. 1510. Decanus per 3 Annos.

NICHOLAUS WEST, Etonae educatus, ad Coll. Regale Cantabrigiae translatus, indeque expulsus. In Academiam tamen ob indolem receptus, tan∣demque L. L. D. creatus est, Decanus installa∣tus in 1510. 1 Hen. 8. consecratus Episcopus Eli∣ensis 1515. Obiit 1533. Decanus per 5 Annos, & in Ecclesiae Eliensis Capella ab ipso fundata, sepultus est. Praedium vocatum Coldhams, in Parochia de Clavering, in Com. Essex. per De∣canum hunc & Canonicos justo pretio compa∣ratur.

JOHANNES VOYSEY, alias HARMAN, Coll. Magdal. Oxon. Socius, L. L. D. Domest. Ca∣pellae Regiae Decanus, installatus 1515. 6. Hen. 8. Ad Episcopatum Exn. promotus 1519. cujus depraedator extitit. Oppidanis vero de Sutton Cofield, in Com. Warw. (unde ortum duxit) Benefactor insignis. Oppidum enim ipsum Mercatorium fieri procuravit, & pro Oppidanis Incorporationem impetravit. Quibus terras pluresque & alia proicua diversa, praeter tene∣menta ibidem permulta, ex lapidibus quadratis de novo aedificata, in perpetuum affignavit, Decanus per 4 Annos.

JOHANNES CLERK, S. Th. D. (potius utrius∣que Juris Professor) Rotulorum Custos, instal∣latus 1519. 11 Hon. 8. ad Pontificem Romanum Legatus Regius, consecratus Episcopus Bath. & Well. 1523. Obiit ex veneno in Germania 1540. Decanus per 4 Annos: De eo vide in vita Hen. 8. per D. Herbertum Edit. 1672. p. 94. sub. Ann. 1520.

RICHARDUS SAMPSON, L. L. D. Domest. Capellae Regiae Decanus, nec non Ecclesiae D. Pauli Lond. installatus per Procuratorem, (ipso in remotis agente Regiisque negotiis detento) 14 Nov. 1523. 15 Hen. 8. & in propria per∣sona 20 Maii, 1526. ad Episcopatum Cicestren∣se promotus 1536. & ad Covent. & Litchfield, translatus 1543. Decanus per 13 Annos. Obiit 25 Sept. 1554. & sepultus est in Ecclesia de † Ec∣cleshall,Vid. Antiq. Eccles. Lichfield, pag. 48. in Com. Staffordiensi.

GULIELMUS FRANKLIN, Coll. Regalis Can∣tabrigia Socius, Rector de Chalfontsti. Aegidii in
Com. Bucks, installatus 19 Decem. 1536. 28 Hen. 8. Decanus per 17 Annos. Primus De∣canus fuit, qui una cum Canonicis tunc Resi∣dentibus, postposito prorsus Fundatoris Statuto (quamvis Juramento proprio sancito) possessi∣ones Collegii quamplurimas ad tempus immen∣sum, nec adhuc (1618.) elapsum dimisit. Imo pri∣mus & ultimus fuit, qui haereditamenta nonnulla in perpetuum alienavit, viz. Maneria de Ivor in Bucks: & de Damory Court in Dors. &c. Rex autem Edw. 6. (eodum adhuc Decano) diver∣sas Rectorias appropriatas Decano & Canoni∣cis donavit, tum ad compensandum eos pro Maneriis, &c. praedictis Regi Hen. 8. Patri suo praeconcessis, tam ad sustentandum pauperes Milites in hac Regiâ Capella. Atque haec do∣natio Nova Dotatio appellatur.

OWENUS OGLETHORP, S. T. P. Coll. Magd. Oxon. Socius deinde Praeses, ex. Canonico instal∣latus Decanus 1553. Mariae 1o. electus & ad∣missus Scriba Ordinis de Garter in Vigiliis S. Georgii, Anno eodem [potius in Ann. 1554.]

Et ut consuetum salarium 50 librarum dicto Officio debitum è Scaccario quotannis per Su∣premum & Commilitones sancitum est 24 ap. Ann. sequente ad Episcopatum Carleolensem pro∣motus 1556. Reginam Elizabetham Diademate Regio infignivit 1558. Decanus per 3 Annos.

A prima praecellentissimi Ordinis praedicti in∣stitutione huc usque nemo nisi merè Canonicus, Scribae seu Registrarii Officium obibat. Iste etiam Decanus & successores sui, non quatenus Decani, sed quatenus Canonici ejusdem mu∣neris capaces facti sunt, prout statuta dicti Or∣dinis exigunt.

HUGO WESTON, S. T. P. Coll. Lync. Oxon. Rector. In Convocatione totius Cleri Cantua∣riensis Provinciae, Mariae 1o. habita Prolocutor: Decanus Westmonasterii, unde volens nolens ut Monachis ibidem aditus iterum patefieret, ad Windesoram translatus est Ann. 1556. 4o. Mariae, sed in Adulterio deprensus, Decanatu isto una cum aliis beneficiis suis universis privatus est per Cardinalem Polum Archi-Episcopum Cant. 1557. A cujus sententia appellavit, ugamque ad partes transmarinas capessit. Sed intercep∣tus & in Turrem Londinensem conjectus, ibique detentus est usque ad initium regni Elizabethae Reginae: Ex cujus gratia tunc particeps factus, libertate donatus est, qui paulo post obiit. De∣canus per Annum 1 & amplius.

JOHANNES BOXHALL, S. Th. D. Mariae Re∣ginae Principalis Secretarius, installatus 1557. Phil. & Mariae 4. & 5. Scriba nobilissimi Ordinis de Garter electus, & juratus eodem Anno Feb. 6. eo quod Reformationi ab Elizabetha Regina in∣stitutae adversaretur, Decanatu isto multatus est, & cum Tonstallo Dunelmensi, & Thirlbaeo Eliensi Episcopis in liberam Custodiam Archi-Episcopi Cantriensis donatus est 1559. Decanus circa duos Annos.

GEORGIUS CAREW, Edmundi Baronis Carew de Mullesford filius tertius, Georgii Baronis Ca∣rew, de Clopton, & Comitis de Totness pater, magister de la Savoy, Lond. Qui simul etiam & eodem tempore Decanus fuit Domesticus & hu∣jus liberae Capellae Regiae, necnon Ecclesiarum Cathedralium Exon. & Oxon. Rector de Silferton, in Devon. & installatus hic 1559. Eliz. 1o. & Scriba inclytissimi Ordinis praedicti cum foedo 50
librarum ex fisco Regio quotannis percipiend▪ admissus & juratus est 22 Apr. Eliz. 2o. Deca∣natum hunc cum Canonicatu resignavit Eliz. 14. sicut etiam reliquas suas dignitates & beneficia Ecclesiastica universa ante mortem. Obiit 1585. & sepultus est in Ecclesia Sti. Aegidii Occid. prope Lond. ubi & Rector fuit. Cui in Deca∣natu successit G. Day, & in Canonicatu Hugo Blyth, Decanus per tredecim Annos.

Satis liquet Decanum hunc propter promo∣tiones suas predictas, aliaque beneficia Ecclesia∣stica quibus perfruebatur, ab hoc Coll. ut plu∣rimum abfuisse; & utrum praesens an absens fuerit in aliquibus ex pessimis illis & iniquissi∣mis sub Decanatu suo firmarum dimissionibus incertum est. In quam plurimis eum abfuisse manifeste liquet; hoc autem certo certius est, quod Maneria hujus Collegii fere universa una cum Sylvis & Regalibus annexis, nunquam au∣tem elocatis, necnon pleraque alia haeredita∣menta praecipua, infra spatium octodecim men∣sium sub Decanatu suo ad 99 Annos dimissa. Nec dubitandum est quin reliqua etiam omnia eodem modo elocarentur, nisi Honoratissimus Custos magni Sigilli Angliae, D. Nich. Bacon, Eq. Aur. hujus Regiae Capellae, ratione officii, Visitator dignissimus, tempore maxime oppor∣tuno respectu agendorum, quamvis sero ni∣nimis respectu actorum, primo per Literas suas absens, deinde in propria persona sua adveni∣ens in Visitatione sua An. 1568. inchoata, De∣canum & Canonicos a dimissione quacunque fa∣cienda inhibuisset. Demumque Injunctionibus suis An. 1571. editis, dimissiones praedictas, ut nequiter factas, condemnasse. Lex etiam in∣terim
saluberrima, ex corruptiimis iorum moribus ad sempiternum omnium Ecclesiarum & Collegiorum bonum nata, & ab ipso Honoratissi∣mo Visitatore composita in Parliamento faeliciter lata & edita est Eliz. 13o. de non elocandis Ter∣ris & tenementis ultra terminum 21 Annorum aut tum Vitarum.

GULIELMUS DAY, S. Th. Bacc. Coll. Rega∣lis Cantabr. Socius, Etonensis Collegii Praepo∣situs, Rector de Hambledon in Bucks: ex Cano∣nico installatus Decanus 22 Aug. 14 Eliz. 1572. Quamvis Scribae sive Actuarii nobilissimi Ordinis officium supplevit, non tamen juratus nec ad∣missus est, sed tantum hoc idem agere (sicut antea perageret) supremae nomine missus est in Vigiliis Georgianis, 26 Eliz. 1584. ad Episcopa∣tum Wintoniensem promotus 1595. Decanus per 24 ere Annos.

Ante tempus Decanatus ejus Lex ante dicta in Parliamento lata est, statuto etiam Fundatoris de non elocandis firmis ultra quinquennium pristimum suum robur obtinente. Attamen Fundatoris praescripto contemptui habito, & decreto Parliamenti subdole eluso, Manerium de Picton, in Com. Oxon. (cum Sylvis amplissi∣mis) quod solum ferè & solitarium in manibus Coll. relictum est, sub nomine Regio (nam alias valere non potuit dimissio) ad 99 Annos a tempore dimissionis conceditur.

Terrae vero Dominicales ejusdem Manerii pro totidem annis in reversione post 40 Annos de termino in aliis dimissionibus praeconcesso, tunc residuos, per Decanum hunc & Confra∣tres suos in malo dimittuntur, redditu etiam ve∣teri non paulum diminuto. Rectoria etiam de
South Molton, Com. Devon. Valde opima in foedi firma (quantum in ipsis) per 120 Annos conce∣ditur, & in proximo Parliamento, juxta illorum conventionem confirmanda. Sed haec concessio, Domino Benetto in Decanatu interim succedente, per Parliamentum non confirmatur: Ad termi∣num vero 120 Annorum dicta Rectoria ex de∣creto ejusdem locatur. Possessiones quoque re∣liquae fere omnes hujus Collegii, quae ad paucos tantum annos prius dimissae sunt, paulo ante promotionem hujus Decani ad Wintoniam, ad ter∣minum trium vitarum dimittuntur. Quarum dimissionem ad minus viginti adhuc (1618.) su∣persunt, quae quamvis, per 30 ab hinc Annos, aut circiter factae sunt, nullus tamen Firmari∣orum vult statum suum pro termino 21 Anno∣rum permutare. Denique Conventiones pro bono Collegii publico in locationibus ad 99 Annos duraturis contentae relaxantur. Et fru∣mentum in quibusdam ex iis prius reservatum pro minutilo pretio ad totum tempus venturum re∣mittitur.

Hinc est quod multo plus detrimenti sub ejus Decanatu Collegium caeperit, quam in quovis alio superiore saeculo: excepto saltem tempore ultimo Praedecessoris sui. Cui etiam dum in absentia sua Dayus iste locum tenens fuit, di∣missiones saltem quam plurimae ad 99 Annos factae sunt. Sicut ex Schedulis & actuum Ca∣pitularium fragmentis, quae forte fortuna super∣sunt, adhuc constat. Tam bene promeruit Decanus iste Elogium illud, quod Dominus de Ellesmere summus totius Angliae Cancellarius in ipsa Cancellaria publice pronuntiavit, viz. Deane Day had excellent Skill to creep out of the
Law. Quam male autem nomen Diei Lucisisve appellatio sibi competivit, nos, cum ringimur dolore, sentimus qui noctem tenebrosam nona∣ginta fere annorum, ex Dimissionibus, Relax∣ationibus, & Remissionibus praedictis huic Col∣legio illatam post se reliquit. Et ne scirent po∣steri quis tantarum tenebrarum author fuit, plusquam veri simile est impensè, si non impro∣bè in decessu suo curavit nam non solum di∣erum & Actuum Capitularium libri priores de toto tempore Decanatus ejus & proximi Praede∣cessoris sui desiderantur, sed folia etiam prima Actuum jam superstiti de ultima scena actûs sui tragici execta sunt, prout ex eorum reliquiis cuivis inspicienti liquido constabit.

ROBERTUS BENETT, Th. D. Coll. S. Trini∣tatis Cantabrig. Socius, Mr. Hospitalis S. Crucis prope Winton. installatus 24 Martii, 1595. Scri∣ba praenobilis Ordinis de Garter Constitutus & juratus in festo S. Georgii, 1596. Episcopus He∣reford. Consecratus 1602. Obiit 1617. Decanus per 7 Annos Iste omnium Decanorum primus fuit, qui per 150 Annos ultimò elapsos, juxta exi∣gentiam statutorum a fundatore editorum, & conscientia juramenti in admissione sua prae∣stiti, nullam omnino firmam dimissione fecit ul∣tra quinquennium toto tempore Decanatus sui.

AEGIDIUS TOMSON, S. T. P. Coll. Omn. Anim. Oxon. Socius, electus 1580. In Coll. Magd. Theologiac Praelector, Academiae Pro∣curator, Ecclesiae Cathedralis Herefordiensis Re∣sidentiarius, Capellanus Regius, Rector de Pembridge, in Com. Heref. installatus 2 Mar. 1602. ad Episcopatum Gloucestrensem promotus 1611. Decanatum cum Episcopatu per dispen∣sationem
Régiam ad annum unum obtinuit. Sed anno nondum pleno elapso, vir optimus & in∣tegerimus, Concionator valde insignis 14 Junii, moritur, & Windsorae sepelitur Ann. 1612. Deca∣nus per 9 Annos & 4 Menses. In iisdem vesti∣giis cum Praedecessore suo ultimo, quoad dimis∣siones firmarum, insistere perseveravit, donec Regia Majestas D. Jacobus supremus Patronus & Fundator, rationibus quibusdam in petitione Decani & Canonicorum explicatis, permotus, ex plenitudine Potestatis suae, vetus illud primi Fundatoris statutum abrogavit, novumque sub magno suo sigillo edidit, anno regni sui. 1. quod deinceps & in perpetuum Decanus & Canonici pro exigentia juramenti in admissione suâ su∣scepti, observare tenentur: quo cautum est, quod Domorum in Villis Mercatoriis dimissi∣ones ultra 40 Annos, aliorum vero, haeredita∣mentorum quorumcunque ultra viginti & unum Annos nullatenus fiant.

Sub ejus Decanatu & proximi Successoris, circa Campanas & Campanile, circa Organa & Organorum tabulatum, una cum aliis operibus intestinis infra ipsam Regiam Capellam, ac in reficiendo Bibliothecam publicam, & hujus∣modi operibus publicis non ex necessitate aliqua, sed tantum pro dignitate & honore loci per De∣canum & Canonicos susceptis & consummatis, plusquam octingentae librae erogatae sunt.

Eodem temporis intervallo dimissiones Rec∣toriarum S. Germani in Cornubia & de Aberguilly, in Com. Caermarthen. in quibus fere 60 Anni supererant ad terminum 2 Ann. curâ & sumpti∣bus Decani & Canonicorum revocatae sunt. Terrae quoque & tenementa vocatae Monklane
& Bellifants, in Com. Wigorn. & Bamfelds in Uttoxeter in Com. Staff. processu Legali in Cancellaria Domini Regis recuperatae sunt, postquam longo temporis tractu in aliorum pos∣sessione fuissent.

Lis etiam magna & per magnum temporis decursum, nec sine summis impensis agitata & continuata inter Decanum & Canonicos & Edw. Comitem Hertford. pro terris & possessi∣onibus plerisque novae Dotationis; tandem so∣pita & determinata est, ac haereditamenta Col∣legii universa stabilita sunt ex decreto Parlia∣menti secundo Jacobi.

Denique totus munus Castri exterior inter duas Turres Domui illi Canonicali contiguas, quae ad Aquilo-Zephyrum & Angularem Domum interioris Claustri sita est, & subito & funditus corruit, die Dominico A. D. 1603. Unde Lis orta est quis instauret, An Dominus Rex, An Decanus & Canonici? tandem vero post longam & matu∣ram in utramque partem deliberationem sub il∣lorum Juramento capta, & in Scaccarium re∣missa; ac etiam Regii Attornati & Sollicitatoris opinione concurrente, ex finali Baronum Scac∣carii sententia, Comitis de Dorset tunc sum∣mi totius Angliae Thesaurarii calculo comprobata, & ad mandatum dicti Thesaurarii praesatus munus olis fumptibus & expensis Domini Regis Jacobi re-edificatus est. Postquam Reverendus ille Praesul tunc Decanus, & Canonici per petiti∣ones suas humillimas Domino Regi exhibitas, & per rationes ac allegationes justissimas, a praefato Domino Thesaurario & aliis Officiariis Regiis approbatas, totam causae veritatem ex∣plicassent, nec destiterunt, donec ad debitum
finem perduxissent, quamvis per 4 fere Annos Lis interminata pendebat. Obiit Jun. 14. 1612. Vide page 14. & Windsorae sepultus est.

ANTONIUS MAXEY, Coll. S. Trinitatis Can∣tabrig. Alumnus, S. T. D. Rector Ecclesiaru de Winterton, in Norfolc. & de Horton, in Buck, & de West Ildesley, in Berks: Installatus 20 Junii 1612. Jacobi 10o. Obiit Lond. 30 Maii, 1618. & sepultus est in Ecclesia S. Martini juxta Charing Cross. Decanus per 5 fere Annos.

Per Testamentum suum Libros suos ad usum Bibliothecae nuper renovatae donavit, aut sal∣tem tot ex iis quot ad usum praedictum selegi merentur, unde circa octoginta volumina se∣lecta sunt, & in dicta communi Bibliothea collocata.

MARCUS ANTONIUS de DOMINIS, in Scho∣la Jesuitica enutritus, & side Italica imbutus, ad Episcopatum primo Segiensem promotus, deinde ad Archi-Episcopatum Spalatensem traslatus est, unde fugam capessit, & in Angliam se appulit Anno 1616. Ubi a Serenissimâ Regiâ Maje∣state summâ gratiâ exceptus, Hospitio de la Savoy Lond. necnon Decanatu isto donatus est: Installatus 18 Maii, 1618. Jacobi 16. Sed inge∣nitum illud virus quo a teneris in Societate prae∣dicta imbutus est, sicut in toto apud nos vitae suae cursu, vix aut ne vix quidem compescere potuit, neque enim tenuissima sanae conscientiae scin∣tillula in eo comparuit, qui in beneficiis Eccle∣siasticis perinde ac rebus temporalibus dispo∣nendis, omnia per fas & nefas ad se & suos ra∣pere,
luertimque sibi facere concupivit, ita toto demum mundo exhibere non erubuit, Homo etenim summe ambitiosus, nec minus avarus, qui in adventu suo summas & amplissimas in Ecclesia Anglicana dignitates & promotiones devorasse, statimque & sine mora adipiscendas sibi proposuisset, ubi Regiam Majestatem sen∣sim & per gradus quosdam procedere perspexis∣set, credulam ac umbratilem nescio quam de Salerniensi Archi-Episcopatu spem & promissi∣onem, subdole Pontificia Arte, hoc est, vetera∣toria Gundelmoriana fraude, aurribus suis insu∣surratum reali suae in Anglia promotioni prae∣tulit. Quamvis redditus ejus annuus cum De∣canali & Ordinis aureae Periscelidis Registrali dignitate conjunctis ad quingentarum librarum summam & amplus excrevit, ad vomitum igitur redire cupiens, desiderium illud suum Domino Regi scriptis explicavit, & ut bona sua cum ve∣nia Romam proficisceretur enixe petiit, cui Pe∣titioni, quamvis Rex clementissimus per omnia subscribere recusavit, attamen profectioni suae minime obstitit ut bannitum vero & nunquam in Dominio suo reversurum, eum de regno suo amandavit. Hoc tantum pro Colophòne adjiciens, Nebulo huc accessit, Nebulo illuc recedat.

Juxta quod mandatum circa festum Annunti∣ationis 1622. Bruxellas indeque Romam remea∣vit, ubi debitam simulationis & dissimulationis fuae mercedem reportavit, simulque ad exhi∣bendum innatae aftutiae, ac Tyrannidis Ponti∣ficiae specimen spectandum, ansam praebuit. Quamvis enim non inhumaniter a Papa & sectis suis primo exceptus, brevi tamen in Monasterio detentus est, & paulo post in Ergastulo detrusus,
per Inqutsitores Romanos, tum ad faciendum po∣pulum tum ad resiciendum, quantum in ipsis ex∣cidium illud, quod in Republica sua Anti-Chri∣stiana ipse Antonius per scripta sua eruditissima (nam & Balaam aliquando divinè prophetavit) in libris suis de Republica Christiana molitus est, tanquam apostata Haereticae pravitatis accu∣satus, tandemque sive morbo, sive inedia, sive veneno extinctus ejusdem criminis jam mortuus, condemnatus. Et sic demum pro Mausolaeo, quod fortasse in Phantasia post decessum suum ex hoc regno sibi sabricasset, in rogo, post de∣cessum suum ex hac vita, cadaver ejus com∣buritur.

Decanus per 4 fere Annos, cui in Decanatu successit D. Beaumont & in Canonicatu T. Some. Credo equidem quod inter mundanos sapientissimos qui Versipellem hunc optime norunt indecisum habebatur, an quisquam sui Ordinis & loci subtiliori ingenio, clariori judi∣cio, aut perspicaciori intellectu praeditus fuit? Nemo tatnen, existimo, tam insipidus unquam, qui leviori aut tam inani stropha deceptus pe∣riit: Sed hoc à Domino, ut ratum faceret quod per Prophetam suum pronuntiavit, Peribit sa∣pientia a sapientibus, & intellectus prudentibus abscondetur.

HENRICUS BEAUMONT, S. Th. P. ex pre∣nobili Vice-Comitum Beaumont familia stirpe paterna ortus, Coll. Omn. Anm. Oxon. socius electus 1571. Henrici Chichlei, quondam Archi∣Episcopi Cantuariensis praefati Collegii Fundato∣ris stirpe maternâ consanguineus: Academiae Oxon. Procurator, Ecclesiae de Long Ditton in Surreia Rector, ex Decano Peroburgenfi, & Ca∣nonico
hujus Liberae Capellae installatus De∣canus 18 Maii, 1622. Obiit Windsorae, 30 Junii, 1627. & sepultus est ad latus dextrum Thomae Daett Praedecessoris sui. Decanus per 5 Annos, & 6 Septimanas.

Idemque Scriba seu Registrarius nobilissimi Ordinis de Garter Diplomate Regio constitutus est, & stipendium quinquaginta librarum dicto officio antiquitus debitum, sed per 60 fere An∣nos retroactum, per expressum mandatum Do∣mini Regis, ad instantiam Commilitonum Or∣dinis & juxta Petitionem suam ex Fisco Regio ad duos anni terminos per aequales portiones sol. 2. vend. obtinuit, in festo S. Georgii, 20 Jacobi.

Sicut Praedecessor suus Dr. Maxey, ita etiam & iste ex Bibliotheca sua privata libros pleros∣que merito selegendos (numero circiter cum Praedecessore praedicto pares) ad Bibliothecam hujus Collegii publicam destinavit, eosque mo∣riens per Testamentum suum legavit.

DIV1.HEAD: Hactenus Tho. Fryth, istius Catalogi de Decanis Author; sequitur Conti∣nuatio per Dom. Geo. Evans.
DIV1.P: MATTHEUS WRENN, S. T. P. Ca∣pellanus Domini Regis, nec non a Sacris ejus secretioribus, Magi∣ster Coll. S. Petri in Academia Can∣tabrig. simulque Praebendarius Win∣toniensis & Westmonasteriensis, installatus est 24 Julii, 1628. & 23 Sept. seq. Scriba praenobilis Ordinis de Garterio constitutus est & juratus; tandem in Episcopatum Herefordensem consecra∣tus est, postea in Nordovicensem, denique in Eliensem. Capellae Regiae tunc temporis Decanus per 6 Annos, & circiter 9 Menses.

CHRISTOPHERUS WRENN, Matthoei frater natu minor, S. T. P. Regi Carolo 1mo. a sacris Rector de Knoyle, in Com. Wilts, olim alumnus & Socius Coll. Di. Jo. Bopt. Oxon. ejusdemque Aca∣demiae Procurator, installatus est in Decanatum hujus Liberae Capellae 4 Apr. 1635. & 22 ejus∣dem Mensis Scriba, insignis Ordinis de Periscelide constitutus & juratus est: 12 Nov. 1638. prae∣sentatus est ad Rectoratum Ecclesiae de Haseley, in Com. Oxon. mortem obiit Bleching doniae in Com. praedict. 29 Maii, 1658. Decanus per 23 Annos & 2 Menses.

EDWARDUS HYDE, S. T. Prof. Cantabrig. Rector Ecclesiae de Brightwell, in Com. Berks, Post mortem ultimi Decani Literas Patentes a Rege tunc temporibus in partibus transmarinis exulante, obtinuit pro hoc Decanatu, sed ante Regis restitutionem morte praereptus, in eum nunquam erat installatus.

BRUNO RYRES, S. T. P. è Coll. Magd. Oxon. Rector Ecclesiae S. Martini in Le Vintroy Lond. & Vicarius de Stanwell in Com. Middles. Car. I. & II a Sacris, Decanus Cicestresis, & Magister Hospitalis ibidem, resignato Cicestrensi, installa∣us est in Decanatum hujus Liberae Capellae Regiae Septemb. 1660. Postea Rectoriâ de Acton in Com. Middlesex donatus est. In Ca∣pitulo habito 14 Jun. 1660. Scriba nobiliss. Or∣dinis de Garterio electus, juratus & admissus est. Deinde Rector de Haseley in Com Oxon. Obiit 13 Julii, 1677. sepultus est WindsoraVide pag. 169..

JOHANNES DUREL, S. T. P. Praebendarius Dunelmensis & Saliburiensis, hujus Ecclesiae Ca∣nonicus, installatus est Decanus ejusdem 27 Julii, 1677. Obiit 6 Junii, 1682. & in Capella St•. Georgii sepultus estVide pag. 176..
FRANCISCUS TURNER, S. T. P. in Deca∣natum installatus 20 Julii, 1683. deinde Epis∣copus Roffensis, & Anno 1684. ad Eliensem se∣dem remotus.
GREGORIUS HASCARD, S. T. P. installatus 29 Septembris, 1684. & obiit Anno 1708.

THOMAS MANNINGHAM, S. T. P. Collegii Novi Oxoniensis quondam Socius, installatus
Februarii 16, 1708. & ad Episcopatum Cice∣strensem evectus. 1709.

JOHANNES ROBINSON, S. T. P. Collegii Orielensis Oxon. quondam Socius, postea ad Re∣gem Snecicum Legatus, installaus in huncce Decanatum 3o, Decembris, 1709, (Annd imperio potitâ) Episcopus Bristoliensis consecratus 19 Novembris, 1710. & in Episcopatu Londinensi confirmatus Martii 13, 1713.
GEORGIUS VERNEY, S. T. P. Baro Willough∣by de Broke, in Decanatum hunc admissus 24 Martii, 1713.

DIV1.HEAD: CANONICI Capellae Liberae de WINDSORE.
DIV1.P: ROBERTUS SHUTINGDON. JOHANNES de NORTHAMP∣TON obiit 1361.
RICH. ROTHELEE, Rector de Dunton Waylett in EssexNomen hujusce Viri, inter Rectores istius Ecclesiae a cele∣berrimo Newcourt recensitos, non occurrit..
HUGO WHITCHURCH, obiit 1374.

Isti quatuor una cum Custode Willielmo Mugg, in ipsis Statutis a fundatore editis Anno Regni sui 26o. Canonici nominantur. Fun∣datio autem instituta est & custos praedictus & octo alii Canonici (ex duodecim) in hac Li∣bera
Capella collocati anno dicti Fundatoris 22o. Dom. 1348. ut supra dictum est in W. Mugg Custode. Nomina quidem Canonicorum dicto Anno 22. collocatorum in Charta Regia reticentur, hos vero ex illorum numero fuisse minime dubitandum est. Quibus simul cum reliquis quatuor, superaddicti & per successiones suas installati sunt, hi qui sequuntur. Sed ab hoc Anno ad Ann. 1362. non constat de admis∣sionis tempore, quamvis de tunc admissorum nominibus & numero sequente satis liquet.
STEPHANUS SCALFORD, alias BRUNKTER, Benefactor, obiit 1377.
GULIELMUS de PALMORNA (Soc. Coll. Exon.) qui etiam fuit Cancellarius Universitatis Oxon. 1350. obiit 1362.

JOHANNES DEPDEN installatus 1429. Ca∣nonicus Ecclesiarum Sarum & Cicestrens. Re∣gistrarius Ordinis de Garter 1445. 23 Hen. 6. Henricus etiam Chichley Archi-Episcopus Cantuar. qui ad supervidendum computum pro solutione debitorum Regis Hen. 4. viz. 25000 Marcarum, per Regem Hen. 5. praeficitur post solutionem 6000 Marcarum de summa praedicta, dum ipse magnis & arduis Ecclesiae ac Rei-publicae ne∣gotiis intentus, praepeditus est, pro supervisione solutionis raesidui dictae summae scil. 19000 Mar∣carum;
huic John Depeden vices suas per Instru∣mentum suum quod adhuc extat, sigillo suo munitum demandavit 20 Hen. 6. 20 Octob.

THOMAS PASH, Art. Mr. Rector Ecclesia∣rum de Medley in Com. Ebor. & de Harbleston, & Sutton Courtney in Dioc. Sarum, & de Ake∣boll in Dioc. Norwych. & de Roby in Dioc. Lin∣coln. Rector etiam Liberarum Capellarum de Montelegthord in Com Cardigan; Praebendarius de Gnothall in Staff. Residentiarius in Eccl. Cath. Sarum, & possessor Liberae Cantariae de Agar∣ston in Dioc. Sarum, obiit 1479. Benefactor, cujus obitus celebratus 12 Nov.
JOHANNES HORE installatus 1451. & obiit 1472. (S. T. B. Coll. Regal. Cantabr. Soc. Rector de Stower, natus in Civ. Winton.)

RICHARDUS ANDREW installatus 1451.

—KERBY installatus 1453.
JOHANNES WYGRIM, Coll. Mert. Oxon. Soc. installatus 1458. Rector Ecclesiae de Devises in Wilts, obiit 1468. Benefactor, cujus obitus ce∣lebratus 5 Oct. cui successit R. Woodmaston de quo infra.

JACOBUS GOLDWELL, Coll. Omn. Anim. Oxon. Socius electus 1441. L. L. D. installatus 1458. Secretarius Regius; Decanus Sarum, Ordinis Garterii Registrarius constitutus 1460. ad Epis∣copatum Norwycensem promotus 1472.
RICHARDUS BOWYER installatus 1460. & obiit 1470.
LEYSANUS JEFFRY installatus 1465. & obiit 1474.—Marshall successit.

JOHANNES VAUGHAN installatus 1470. & obiit 1499. Benefactor, cujus obitus celebratus est 13 Junii
GULIELMUS DUDLEY installatus 1470. postea Decanus decimus 1473.

THOMAS PALLET, A. M. Coll. Omn. An. Soc. electus 1452. installatus 11 Maii 1473. loco Burghill, obitus ejus celebratus est 15 Julii.
JOHANNES MARSHALL, Coll. Mert. Oxon. Socius, deinde Etonensis S. T. D. installatus 1474. & resignavit 1477. consecr. Episcopus Landaff 1478.

JOHANNES COKKYS, Benefactor, cujus obiit cel. 21 Oct. installatus 1477.

RICHARDUS ARNOLD installatus 1479. & obiit 1490.
JOHANNES MORTON installatus 1481.

OLIVERUS KING, Coll. Regal. Cantab. Socius, L. L. D. Principalis Secretarius Edwardi primo∣geniti Regis Hen. 6. ac etiam Edwardi Regis 4. Edwardi 5. & Henrici. 7. installatus 1481. Ordi∣nis Garterii Registrarius, consecratus Episcopus Exon, 1492. ad Bathon. & Well. translatus 1495. Ecclesiam Bathon. veterem diruit, novamque re-aedificare caepit, sed imperfectam reliquit.
THOMAS HUTTON installatus 1484.
JOHANNES BAYLIE installatus 1484.

RICHARDUS SURLONDE installatus 1486. Sub-Decanus domesticus Capellae Regiae, obiit
20 Aug. 1509. & Windsorae sepultus est, Bene∣factor, cujus obitus celebratus 18 Aug.
GULIELMUS CRETING, Coll. Regalis Cantabr. Socius, installatus 1487.
OLIVERUS DINHAM installatus 1487.
THOMAS FRAUNCE installatus 1488.
