DIV1.P: In Pages 307, 308, 309, 310, 311, &c. of the Second Volume of this Word, is a large Account of the Manors in the Parish of EASTHEN∣DRED, to which may be added the following Remarks made by a Gentleman of Worth and Honour, whose Modesty has forbid the men∣tion of his Name, viz. one of the Hendreds gave to the Abbey of Abington two Abbots, viz. Robert de Henreth, who became Abbot in, or soon after, 1221, and died in 1234. and Richard de Hendred, who became Abbot of the House in 1262, and died 1289.

The Manor of BECKET, likewise in the Pa∣rish of Shrivenham, near Farington, in this Coun∣ty, lately Part of the Possessions of Major Wild∣man, and at present belonging to Barington Shute, Es{que} is also held of this Manor by the yearly Rent of Four Pounds.

To what is said of the second Manor, called the ABBY Manor, may be added, “King Henry the 8th, by his Letters Patents bearing Date August the 26th, A°. Regni 36. Christi 1544. bestowed this Manor upon Henry Norris, Es{que} afterwards Lord Norris, from which Family it was alienated 13 Jac. A. D. 1615-16. March the 20th, and Sold to one Finton, who transferr'd it to the then Earl of Kelly, who Sold it to Sir Peter Van Lore, Baronet, of whom William Eyston, Es{que} Bought it Feb. 10th, 20o Jacobi, i. e. A. D. 1621-22.

It appears by King Henry the First's Charter (without any Date) in the 2d Volume of the Monasticon, page 957. that the Alien Priory of Frampton in Dorsetshire, had 7 Hides of Land in
Heinreth, which I take to be the whole, or part of the Manor, belonging to Edward Sherwood, Es{que} called the Manor of FRAMPTON; after∣wards it became part of the Possessions of the Abby of Abington, but whether it came to the said Abby of Exchange, Sale, or Gift, I cannot tell. But I find in some Writings, that is was in the Possession of the Crown, Anno Hen. 8. 31 Christi, 1539. and that it was granted by the said king Henry the 8th to John Winchcombe, of Noke, in Com. Oxon. Es{que} whose Grandson, Benedict Winchcombe, sold it, 44 Eliz. 1602. to Jonh Sher∣wood, Es{que} Great Grand Father to Edward Sher∣wood, Es{que} the present Possessor of this Manor.

I find the Knights of St. John of Hierusalem had formerly some Possessions in East Hendred, which I almost fancy, is the MANOR that now belongs to New College in Oxford, but of this I have no certainty.

To the 5th Manor, called the Manor of ARCHES, may be added to what is said page 310. of the 2d volume, “That this Manor belong∣ed in the Year 1171. to one William de Cros∣becy, and from that Family it came to the Turbervilles, one whereof, named Jeffery, be∣stowed some Lands in Hendred upon the Pri∣ory of the Canons Regular of Poghale in Com. Berks, as appears by King Henry the 3d's Charter in the 2d Volume of the Monasticon, pag. 266, 267. From the Turbervill's it de∣scended to the Arches, by William de Arche's marrying Amisia, the Daughter of Sir Ri∣chard de Turberville, Knight; which Amisia, by Deed dated the 19th of May, Anno Christi, 1323. Edw. 2di. 16o. grants to William de
Arches their Son, all her Manors in the Town of East Henreith, with the Advowson of the Chapel [of St. Amand and St. John Baptist] there; to hold to the said William, and the Heirs of his Body. And after it had continued Four Descents in the Family of the Arches, it came into the Family of the Eyston's in or about the Year of our Lord 1381. by William Eyston, of Isleworth, in Com. Middle∣sex, marrying Isabelle, the Daughter of John Stow, by Maude his Wife, who was sole Daughter and Heiress to William Rawlin de Arches. This Manor of Arches was former∣ly held of the Prior of Frampton, and at pre∣sent of Edward Sherwood, Es{que} as Lord of the Manor of Frampton in East Hendred.”
There is an old Chapel of Ease at Sparsholt Court, which is the Seat of the late William Wise∣man, and lyes between the two Hendreds.
There is no Doubt to be made, but that there was at Hendred, (before it fell to decay) a Free School, since there is one at Hanwell, which never was a Market Town, nor ever so consi∣derable.

DIV1.HEAD: Some MONUMENTS omitted in their proper Places are inserted here.

DIV2.HEAD: In the Church of WELFORD, men∣tioned page 278. of the 2d Volume.
DIV2.P: ON a Grave-stone is the following Inscrip∣tion.

Q.P: H. S. E. FRANCISCUS MUNDY, S. T. P. hujus Ecclesiae Rector, WELLENSIS Sub-Decanus, LANDAVENSIS Thesaurarius, qui cum multos liberos providè alendo gregem Orthodoxum fidelitèr Pascendo, Lites Parochiales amicè componendo, & lapsas aliorum fortunas erigendo diu & feliciter vixisset, febre tandem correptus, & benefaciendo aliis exhaustus, a Pauperibus, Orphanis, & Vicinis desideratus, animam exhalavit, Nov. XXII. An. MDCLXXVIII. Aetat. LXV.
In the Church of FYFIELD, men∣tioned in page 96. of the Ist Volume.

DIV2.P: In the North Chantry, or Chancel, in Ca∣pitals is this following Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here lieth Body of CHARLES WHITE, Es{que} Son of CHARLES WHITE, Es{que} together with all his Ancestors. He died the 27 of Decemb. Ao. Dni. 1680. In the 21 Year of his Age.
DIV2.P: In the same Chancel, near the former, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q:
Here lyeth the Body of MARY WHITE, the Wife of FRANCIS WHITE, of Fyfield, Es{que} the Daughter of RICHARD SOUTHBY, of Carswell, in the County of Berks. She departed this Life the 22d of Oct. in the Year of our Lord, 1688. and in the 31 Year of her Age.
Since Virtue can't defend us from the Grave,
And all this hard, but equal Fate must have;
What's then our Hope, but this, to rise with him,
Who triumph'd over Death, yet dy'd for Sin?
Such was the Fate of Her, who now we trust,
Has reach'd the glorious Mansions of the Just.
Then, Reader, spare thy Tears, prepare for to inherit
The everlasting Rest of this departed Spirit,
Whose righteous Footsteps if thou trace, and so canst die,
Dread not the silent Tomb, but fix thy Thoughts on high.
DIV2.P: In the Chancel (kept in Repair by the Fami∣ly of Perrotts) on a fair white Marble Mural Monument, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Near his beloved Wife, and his two Sons, WILLIAM and CHARLES PERROTT, of grateful Memory, lies the Body of JAMES PERROTT, of North Leigh, in the County of Oxon, Gent. whose Piety, and Integrity of Life, made him accepted of God, and approved of Men: And of his Charity, this Parish, and the Parish of North Leigh, will always be a Witness; for the Poor of both which Places he left a yearly Provision. He dies in the LXXXVIIIth. Year of his Age, Decemb. 7 1687. and here waites for a Reward of these, and his other good Actions.
DIV2.P: On a Grave-stone, underneath, is this In∣scription.

Q.P: JAMES PERROTT, GENT. died December the 8th. 1687. in the 88th Yeare of his Age.
In SUNNING Church, mentioned page 385. of the 2d Volume.
On a Grave-stone is this Inscription.
ANTONIUS ENGLEFYLD, Puer admodum venustus, Parentum suorum deliciae. Obiit Mse Junii, 1683. Vix Annos sex natus. Hic sparge Flores, Sparge braves Rosas.

DIV2.HEAD: OLD WINDSOR.
DIV2.P: After the First Paragraph, page the 43d of the IIId Volume, insert,
In this Place was an antient Seat belonging to the Family of the Michel's; and there is also another belonging to the Family of the Lord Viscount Weymouth.

In the Chancel, on a fair Marble Monu∣ment, about Ten Feet in breadth at the Foun∣dation, and Twenty Feet in height, inclos'd with an Iron Rail, and fix'd to the North Wall, are the following Inscriptions at full length, in page 43, 44, 45, 46, &c.
In the middle of the lower Slab of Black Marble, supported by Pilasters and Scrowls, are the Figures of a Man in a Gown, and his Wife in her usual Habit, and near them the following Verses.
A faithful Husband and his loving Wife, &c.
And so on to page the 45th, line the 6th, where (leaving out all the intervening Inscrip∣tions to page the 48th, line the 16th) instead of the Paragraph, On a Fair Monument, &c. go on thus,

The Inscriptions in a double Column, on the upper White Marble Table, supported by Pilasters of the same, with a Foliage of several Escotcheons, and a Capital, with a large Shield of several Coats of Arms, are as follows, P. M. S. Parentum Cineres suis hic adauget, &c. and so on to page the 51st, line the 9th, then add as follows,
In the Church Yard, joining to the Chancel Wall, is a Vault belonging to the Family of the Michels, cover'd with a Black Marble Tomb-stone.

DIV1.HEAD: An ACCOUNT of Mr. JOHN BLAGRAVE, the famous Mathe∣matician, who lived at Reading in Com. Berks, in the Reign of Queen Elizabeth, and King James I. (mentioned in page 359. of the Se∣cond Volume.)
DIV1.P:
HE was noted in his Time for an excel∣lent Mathematician, and wroth se∣veral Books on that Subject; one was called his Mathematical Jewel▪ and also another of Dialling. He lieth buried in St. Mary Church in Reading, his Monument being by himself ordered whilst living. A∣mongst many of his Virtues, this one was obser∣vable, a generous Love for all his Kindred: He made also such a Will, as surprized all the Gen∣tlemen of the Long Robe, so exact, so mathe∣matical it was. Take a small Testimony also of his Kindness to his Relations. He had Three Brothers, Anthony, Edward, and Alexander, to whose Sons, his Nephews, he gave very libe∣rally in his Life. And now observe what Pro∣vision his Will makes for his Kindred to be be∣gotten
by the said Nephews. “Item, I give unto the Children of the Sons of my Brothers, 50 Pound a piece, to be paid them at the Age of 26 Years, according to their Senio∣rity,'” which said 50 Pound a Piece has paid near 80 Persons born after his decease, of his Se∣cond Cousins.

Another Act of Bounty was to the Maids of Reading. You are to Note that there are three Parish Churches, and he doth devise that each Church Warden should send on Good Friday one virtuous Maid that has lived five Years with her Master. All three Maids appear at the Town Hall before the Mayor and Aldermen, and cast Dice; she that throws most has Ten Pounds put in a Purse, and she is to be attended with the other two that lost the Throw. The next Year come again the two Maids, and one more added to them. He orders in his Will, that each Maid should have three Throws before she loseth it, and if she has no luck in the three Years, he orders that still new Faces may come and be presented.

On the same Good Friday he gives eighty Wi∣dows Money to attend, and orders ten Shillings for a good Sermon, and so he wisheth well to all his Country Women. It is lucky Money, for I never heard but the Maid that had the ten Pounds, suddenly had a good Husband.
This Account I had from Mr...... Blagrave, Bookseller, at the Bear St. Paul's Church Yard, who is descended from him (or of that Kin) An. 1690.

Note, That the Legacy given by Mr. John Blagrave to his Kindred, was a Lease of 99 Years; the Time expired but at Midsummer, 1690. All the Kindred was paid, and the In∣heritance of the said Estate went to Mr. Daniel Blagrave, Counsellor at Law, lately deceased. The Lands were at Southcot near Reading. The Money paid to the Maids, is out of Lands settled for that use at Swallowfield in this County.

DIV1.HEAD: A LETTERSee int. MS. Bibl. Bodl. Oxon, pag. 176. Catal. Numb. 3711. 245. from Mrs. Dionysia Fitz-Herbert, to Mr. Rouse, Head Keeper of the Bodleian Library in Oxford, giving an Account of a Vision, with her Explication of it.
DIV1.P:
The Orthography of the whole is according to the Original.THIS wonderful Sight was seene at Almsbury in Wiltshire; also atForsan. Shrivenham. Shir∣man in Barkeshire, or two Miles from thence, in 1615. the next full of the Moone after Michelmess Day, the Moone being that Night at the full, and as wee gest about tow Houers, or more, high, nere eight or nine a Cloke at Night, it had a mighty Cloude round about it, as spacious as a Court; but round in Compass, and overthwit it, to the utmost Bounds of it, a Crosse in Forme, just as the Cors in Couleurs of Eengland, but so shining bright, as the Moone being in the midst, and center of it, could not possible bee diserned from it but by a round Body apearing in the comes of the Crose; and although the Moone stoode in the midst of a Cloude as blake as Darkness it
self, yet did it shine as bright as if it bine the clearest part of Heaven, the Firmament being at that Tyme also exceeding cleare and faire. At the upper end of Crose towards Heaven came out a round Cloude so bigge as a Raine∣bow, of the bignes of a Hand-bow might com∣pas like a Coronet; the which a Rainebow did the brightest and cleret of Couloure as possible could be seene. The Ends towards the North and South hade strems of Light running bake again towards the Moone, but the end towards the Earth had nothing at all; and although wee were continually coming and going, for as I think, the space of two Hoers, in which it appeared, yet could none diescerne how it vanished a way, so suddenly it vanish't, so sud∣denly was it gonne; nether was ther any Al∣teration in it at all, but stood still in the same Forme and Fation all that Tyme.

I have ever thought, from the first apering of this wonderful Sine, that the Full Moone in it figured forth the Estat of the Church now nere her fullnes; the round and mighty blake Cloud that enveroned it, the Aflictions and universale Trobles that shall besete her on all Sids in this last Tymes, as our Lord Jesus hath forewarned in the Holy Scripturs.

The litle Cloud crouned with the Rainebow, that God will ashuredly remember his Holy Covenant and Promise to his Church, and give it a most glorious and certine Victory over all Affliction and Troble whatsoever, signify'd by that bright shining and triumphant Cross.

That the Moone and Cross making one in∣tire Body, shew how conceparable the Cross
is annexed to the Church, yet shall it at last bring fourth to it a most exilent and an eternal waite of Glory.

That the Stremes of Light turning bake from the Ends of the Cross towards the Mone, as I think▪ signifie from what Parts of the World God will rais som Help and ide to his Church, untill by the glorious Coming of our Lord Jesus Christ all her Calamitys shall have a blessed and most happy end.

DIV2.HEAD: The Resons moveing me thus to think are thes.
DIV2.P:
Our Lord Jesus Christ giveth us most certine Warning of Signs in this very kind before his imanedent coming to Judgment. Ther shall bee, saith hee, Signes in the Sunne, and in the Moone, and in the Stars, Troble among the Notion with Preplectie—That it is or∣dinary among Devins to take the Monne as an Emlene of the Church, in respect of her often Changes, and for that is sayd, she receiveth all her Light and Beauty from the Sonne, as the Church from the Sonne of Rightiousness Christ Jesus. How frequent it is in Scriptuer to take Clouds and Darknes for Trubulation, and all manner of Afflictions. I nede not write the lamentable Calamities of the Tyme, reade a large Comment upon this Part, because the Rainebow is a Sinne of God's Favour and Co∣venant, and sete in the Firmament by God himself, to remember him of his Covenant; al∣so Christ Jesus, the Angel of this, is described in the Rainebow descending doune from Hea∣ven, clothed with a Cloud, and the Rainebow
upon his Head. That the Cross is a Sine of of Victory ever, Saint Paul shewes us in the Person of Christ Jesus himself, in that haveing spoyled Principalitis and Powers, he made a shew of them openly, triumphing over them in the same Cross. And although the Cross bee often taken for Affliction, yet in this, even the blody Cross apearing so glorious bright and resplendant, dos undoudedtly betoken and fortell Light and Deliverance to the Church, as that Cross, so famous in Ecclesiastical Histo∣ry, apering to the great Constantine before his notable and most triumphant Victory, wher∣with hee ended the ten blody Percicutions, and the Calamityes of the Primitive Church.

If any mervile that this Sine being seene di∣vers Yeres agoe, why now, rather then all this Tyme it comes to bee taken notis of? I answer in a Word, That the lamentable Condition of the Christian World at this Tyme, 1633. is able to awaken the Memory of so strange and nottable a Thing as this was.

According to an Act passed not long since concerning Popish Recusants, &c. all such were obliged to enter their Estates to be double tax∣ed, and among the rest, Mr. Englefield, of En∣glefield, mentioned page 13. of the 1st Volume, entered his with the following Preamble.

DIV1.HEAD: To the Clerk of the Peace of the County of Berks, or his Deputy.
DIV1.P:
I Desire you to register my Christian and Sirname, and real Estate, pursuant to the Act of Parliament here under-men∣tion'd, in the following Words. That by re∣gistring pursunant to the late Act of Parliament made in the second Year of the Relign of his present Majesty King GEORGE, intitl'd, An Act to oblige Papists to Register their Names and real Estates, I may not contract upon my Parents, or the Religion I profess, the Odium of being guilty of those mischievous Principles in the said Act mentioned, and commonly im∣puted to those they call Papists, I Henry Engle∣feild do declare, That I am, by the Grace of God, an English Catholick, and as such, believe that it is my Duty to be actively Obedient where I can without Offence to God, and pas∣sively where I cannot, to whatsoever Govern∣ment God permits to come over me; and that Non-Resistance in all Cases is one of the Chara∣cteristick Marks of a Christian; and that there∣fore I would willingly take an Oath of Fidelity to King GEORGE: But inasmuch as the real Presence of the Body and Blood of our Saviour in the Sacrament of the Eucharist, was always believed by the Holy Catholick Church, main∣tained ever since the Reformation by many of the most Orthodox Reformed Divines of the
Church of England, fully asserted in the Church of England Catechism, and plainly express'd in the Holy Scriptures; and since the Ten Com∣mandments of God fully and absolutely forbid Perjury; and most Divines, even since the Re∣formation, teach, that to swear to a Fact that that we don't know, or doubt the Truth of, altho' it should prove to be true, is Perjury; I cannot take the Test and Abjuration Oaths enjoyned by Acts of Parliament, whatsoever I suffer. and with this Protestation, left I should be thought to be obliged by the said Act to Register, I farther declare, that I am possess'd of all that, &c.

DIV1.P: The following valuable Piece added to this Work, having never been printed entire, tho' much e∣steemed by the very learned Compiler of, and An∣notator on the Graecian and Roman Marble Monu∣ments given to the most famous University of Oxford, by Henry Duke of Norfolk, and othersMARMORA OXONIENSIA ex Arundellianis aliisquè con∣flata. Recensuit & perpetuo Commentario explicavit Humphredus Prideaux Aedis Christi Alumnus. Appositis ad eorum nonnulla Seldeni & Lydiati Annotationibus. Accessit Sertorii Ursati Patavini de notis Romanorum Commentari∣us, Oxon. 1676. Fol., it may not be foreign to add it in this Place, from its Original MS. preserved in the Bodleian Library at Oxford, Archiv. B. 67. and wrote by Mr. John GrenealghIbid. pag. 282.—Literae in eâ (scil. Arâ) exa∣ratae jam fere evanidae sunt, Inscriptionis igitur lectionem debemus domino Johanni Grenehalgh Scholae Cestrensis Ar∣chidascalo, qui eam, cum lapis primo Cestriae effossus fu∣erit, literis tunc multo manifestius apparentibus, accurate transcripsit, & Notas insuper addidit non contemnendas, quae huc enim Lapide transmissae erant, ex iisquè addito Authoris nomine, pauca excerpta sunt, quae habemus in nostris., chief Master of the Free School in the City of Chester, where this valuable Relique was discovered.
DIV1.Q: I. O. M. TANARO, T. ELUPIUS GALER. PRAESENS GUNA. PRI. LEG. XX. V. V. COMMODO ET LATERANO COS. V. S. L. M.
DIV1.P:
Ara Romana votiva non ita pridem effossa Cestriae, Inscriptio sic habet in lapide praesens ad literam, & hanc ipsam literarum formam. Manifesta est Ara, cavamen habens in summo, seu cotylam quandam concavam, quae contine∣bant ignem, quo thus incendebatur in sacrifi∣cando. Lapis affabre factus, & exsculptus est in Antiquam, sed elegantem formam, quae hic non repraesentatur. Lapis hic effossus est inte∣ger & infractus, Anno Domini 1653o. in platea Urbis Cestria, quae vulgo the Forest Streete appel∣latur, per occasionem defodiendae cellae Promp∣tnariae, in domo cujusdam Richardi Tyrer, citra portam Urbis Orientalem, ubi ad profundita∣tem ulnarum supra quam duarum per tot saecu∣la demissus in terra delituisset: Mihi forte for∣runa isthac eunti significabat aliquis, operarios magnum illic effodisse lapidem, cui videbantur aliquot insculptae literae. Statim accurri & aspe∣ctu primo Romanum esse Monumentum depre∣hendi: Postridie reversus Inscriptionem accura∣tius observavi, & penitius eruere conatus inte∣gram perlegi; descriptamque in chartula me∣cum asportavi: deinde post aliquot dies roga∣tus ab amicis, & rem ratus haud indignam ali∣qua Commentatione, sumpsi calamum & sen∣sum meum super isthac inscriptione in iis quae sequuntur, conscripsi. Lapis adhuc manet erectus in horto praedictae Domus cum inscrip∣tione
sua conspiciendusPage 282. of the Marmora Oxoniensia tandem, A. D. 1675. Eam (scil. Aram) Dominus Franoiscus Cholmley, Domini Thomae Cholmley de Valle Regiâ in Comitatu Ce∣striae, Viri ob nobilitatem Familiae, virtutes, omnigenâquè erga Regem, Patriam, & Ecclesiam merita, in patriâ suâ, cujus est decus, in Parlamento cujus est Senator, & Ubi∣cunque per Angliam Viri optimi approbantur, notissimi Frater, vir ipse optimus, & integerrimus, fideiquè Ortho∣doxae ardentissimus cultor, Honoratissimi Comitis Mares∣calli, & magni Seldeni benevolentiam in Academiam no∣stram imitatus, huc non parvis impensis translatam inter eorum donaria reponebat.. Mos erat non infre∣quens apud Romanos, praesertim Optimates & dig∣nitate praestantiores, ut quando quis grande ne∣gotium aliquod, & idem arduum, difficile & periculosum, susciperet, vel gravi aliquo & in∣extricabili malo deprehensus premeretur; is vo∣tum solenne supplex Jovi nuncuparet, ut si caeptis ille propitius aspiraret faelicemque suc∣cessum largiretur, vel si laboranti divinitus auxiliaretur, & è praesenti periculo caelitus, velut eruere, liberare dignaretur, aram ipsi strueret, erigeret, statueret ad me∣moriam accepti caelestis beneficii perpetuandam.

I. Posita videtur & dicata haec Ara per hunc Titum Elupium Galerum, fortasse liberatum è bel∣licis nuperi praelii periculis, & ob victoriam partam, qui cum esset gubernator Romani praesidii in Urbe Cestriâ, Primipilus Legionis, & forte per subitum aliquem & inopinatum incussum Britannorum, tunc rebellium, ad pugnam evoca∣retur imparatus & impar, absente tunc tempo∣ris Majori parte Legionis, & alibi res admini∣strante, cogereturque cum exigua manu, &
paucis aliquot cohortibus, quibus tunc Urbem hanc solummodo tuebatur, pugnam inire cum hostibus nimiâ multitudine superioribus. In hoc rerum statu, & in tanto discrimine consti∣tutus, ante commissum inaequale praelium, in fronte suarum Turmarum stans vel insidens equo conspicuus, in coelum sublatis & oculis & ma∣nibus, alta voce pronuntiavit ista, vel consi∣milia.

Q.L: Da, summe Jupiter, ut revertar in castra
Victor & inctumis: hoc si dederis,
Aram tibi voveo, & in ea thuris juge
Sacrificium animi grati perpetuum testimonium.

DIV1.P: Quod votum postea, fusis, fugatis, & victis praeter spem & expectationem in ea pugna Bri∣tanis, Elupius iste reversus in Urbem victor & incolumis, hanc Aram statuens, & in eâ Thure incenso Jovi sacrificans adimplevit inscriptio∣nem enim cum aliqua Paraphrasi sic lego.
DIV1.Q: Jovi optimo maximo Tanaro (id est Tonanti) Titus Elupius Galerus praesens Guber∣nator (id est Romani) Praesidii in hac Urbe, Existens Primipilus, sive dux Primarius Legionis vicesimae Valentis victricis Ce potius Valerianae victricis. Commodo & Laterano Consulibus. Votum solvis lubens merito.
DIV1.P:
TANARO] Quod neque Latinum vocabulum ullum est, neque Graecum, quantum ipse memini hic usurpatur Epitheton speciale, & procul dubio
Britannicum vetus Jovi tributum. Ut enim alias Hammon Olympius & Capitolinus a variis locis, ubi colebatur, dictus est; ita variae gentes etiam variis Epithetis ab operibus ejus maxime insigni∣bus utique desumptis eum adornabant: A Graecis audiebat , & sic olim Germani veteres eum sua lingua Tunder apellabant, & quid ni? Sic etiam Britanni veteres eum sua lingua Tanar apellaverint, quod idem significaret, Tonantem. Et quid ni etiam Romani, qui cum inter Britan∣nos hic egissent per multos annos, hoc Epithe∣ton Britannicum in linguae suae formam, & in hunc usum assumpserint? Romani enim nimiâ quâdam religione, seu nimis cautâ superstiti∣one potius, colere solebant Deos earum Gen∣tium quas vicissent. Nempe ut sic omnes Deos, quotquot ubique terrarum invenirentur, sibi con∣ciliarent propitios, & haberent imperio suo fa∣vorabiles: Idcirco licet Jovem haberent cum aliis Gentibus communem Deum, hoc tamen Epitheton Britannicum, ut fortassis hoc in loco magis illis gratum & acceptum, usurparunt. Et hanc meam opinionem prius conceptam mihi plene confirmarunt in Urbe Cestriae degentes aliquot Cambro Britanni sive Walli, quos cum seorsim interrogarem, quodnam in linguae sua vocabulum significaret Tonitru, singuli respon∣debant mihi Tanara. Sed & vocabulum ipsum (Tanara) in Wallica lingua, quae fuit Britannica vetus, & in usu Romanorum temporibus, etiam hodie significat ignem subitaneum sive Fulge∣trum: Et in Wallico Dictionario Tanar redditur Tonitru.

GUNA] Stat pro Gubernator (i. e.) praesens Gubernator superioris Britanniae, & Romani prae∣sidii
in hac Urbe. Cum hoc sit ultimum voca∣bulum in ea linea desculptum & (A) similis tam prope contingat ipsam marginem in lapi∣pidis tabula, & non restaret locus vel minimum spacium ulterius necesse erat contrahi, quod signatur per transversum istum ictum characte∣risticum in vertice N. hoc me torquebat ali∣quandiu & haerebam in luto, donec consultis Authoribus, a duobus Herodiano & Dione Cassio mihi satisfactum est; Herodianus etiam libro tertio affirmat Britanniam fuisse dispertitam (i. e.) in duas Praefecturas, sive Gubernationes, hoc enim vocabulum Graecum feret. In quem Herodiani locum vir doctus & multae lectionis Author Commentarii in Inera∣rium Antonini, affirmat alterum Gubernatorem constitutum Eboraci in Britannia inferiori cum le∣gione sexta: Gubernatorem alterum fuisse col∣locatum Cestriae in Britannia superiori cum legione vicesima, quae Vlens, & Victrix appellata est. Hoc ipsum asseri planissime Dion Cassius, Histor. Rom. Lib. 55. pag. 564. Cujus haec sunt verba, (i. e.) Legio vicesima quae Valeriana & Victrix apellatur, est in Britannia Su∣periori nempe Cestriae, & ibidem (i. e.) Legio sexta est in Britannia inferiori scilicet Eboraci. Ubi observandum, quod Legio vicesima non dicitur a Dione, Va∣lens, & Victrix, ut ab aliis, sed Valeria, seu Vale∣rianas, & Victrix.

LEG. XXV. V.] i. e. Legionis vicesimae Va∣lentis vel Valerianae Victricis. Videri posset debe∣re legi Legionis vicesimae quintae Victricis. Sed suspicor V. priorem a sculptore, vel ob imperi∣tiam
(ut artifices ejusmodi fuerunt meri opifices, & homines alias indocti) vel per angustiam lo∣ci cum sit in fine lineae propius ad XX adjungi quam deberet, nam consultis authoribus, non inveni Legionem ullam extitisse vicesimam quintam dictam, praesertim Antonini Pii tempo∣ribus, quo imperante facta est haec Inscriptio, ut apparet ex subscriptis consulibus Dion Cassius, vir Consularis & doctus recenset accuratissimum Catalogum Legionum Historiae Romanae Libro 55, pag. 564. Pancirolus etiam in Comment. in Noti∣tiam dignitatum utriusque Imperii, pag. 61, 62. 63. varios adfert Catalogos Legionum, & quae sub Augusto fuerunt, & quas addiderunt Impe∣ratores alii sequentes, eosque Catalogos de∣sumptos e variis authoribus, & ex illa Marmoreâ Columnâ quae Romae servabatur in Capitolio, in quibus omnibus nulla sit mentio Legionis ullius, quae vicesima quinta est appellata, Ptolomeus eti∣am, qui vixit & scripsit ipsis Antonini Pii tempori∣bus, affirmat tres tantum Legiones venisse in Britanniam, viz. Legionem sextam, Legionem vicesimam, & Legionem secundam Augustam, quod idem etiam asserit Pancirollus, pag. 142. Idem & Dion Cassius in loco supra citato. Huc addamus quoque Camdeni nostri sententiam, qui de Urbe Cestriâ loquens, haec habet verba. Legi∣onem XX quam Valentem Victricem, atque Va∣leriam Victricem alii falso dicunt, hac in Urbe, egisse Ptolomeus Antoninus & Septimii Getae nummus antiquus comprobant. E quo hanc etiam Coloniam fuisse constat: Inscribitur enim in parte nummi aversâ Col. Divana. LEG. XX. Victrix. Ita Camdenus, pag...... at bona cum venia Camdeni, Dion Cessius vir magnae dignitatis &
optimae fidei Historicus, Legionum vicesimam vocat Valeriam, & non Valentem Victricem, ut ejus verba Graeca superius in hac charta descripsi. Sed in super etiam in oppido quodam Westmorlandiae quod Crowdundalewaith appellatur, non ita pri∣dem effossus est lapis cum hac inscriptione VA∣RONIUS.... ECTUS LEG. XX. V. V. vel sic LEG. XX. V. V. Ubi V. prior longe distat ab XX. i. e. Varonius Praefectus Legionis vice∣simae Valeriae, vel Valentis Victricis. Ergo nullo modo potest nostro in lapide legi vicesimae quin∣tae Legionis, ultimo quod Legio vicesima stati∣onem habuit in hac Urbe Cestria manifestissi∣mè apparet ex aliquot pulcherimis lateribus ante non multos annos effossis juxta plateam, quae ducit ad Pontem, & adhuc visendis, hanc Epi∣graphen planis & plenis literis insculptam LE∣GIO VICESIMA VICTRIX & nihil praete∣rea, prae se ferentibus.

COMMODO ET LATERANO COS.] Hoc ipso anno quo Commodus & Laternus sunt Consules Romani. In Fastis Romanis sedulo consultis mi∣hi tandem occurrerunt Lucius Aelius Commodus, & Sextilius Lateranus descripti Consules in anno decimo septimo Antonini Pii, Imperatoris Ro∣mani, quibus consentit Cssiodori Chronicon, & in eo sunt sola nuda nomina, ut in ipso lapide nisi quod duorum annorum spatio differt, qui qui∣dem Antoninus Pius, in imperio proxime successit Adriano Imperatori, & juxta veteres Ecclesi∣asticos Historicos, confirmante Baronio in An∣nalibus, Antoninus Pius Imperium suscepit in anno post natum Christum Dominum, centesi∣mo & quadragesimo (imperavit annos viginti tres) sic annus decimus septimus illius imperii,
quo ipso anno Commodus & Lateranus erant Con∣sules, fuit annus post natum Christum centesimus & quinquagesimus septimus. Hinc apparet quod hoc anno Christi praesente currente 1671. prae∣terierunt anni mille quingenti tredecem, ex quo lapis hic insculptus fuit hac Inscriptione.

V. S. L. M.] Distinctae literae in ima lapidis tabula subscriptae signant Votum solvit Lubens me∣rito. Lubens (i. e.) non coactus, sed sponte, prompte, animo, volenter & lubenter, grato∣ratio, quia si quis apud Romanas in rebus adver∣sis, in periculis & angustiis coarctatus votum Diis nuncupasset, & postea liberatus voti sui so∣lutionem ad sumptus evitandos neglexisset (peri∣clitantes ad votum solvendum proni sunt, ad vo∣tum solvendum quando liberati non ira) hunc hominem velut ingratum, fraudulentum & quo∣dam modo sacrilegum Romanae leges coercebant, & cum superadditâ mulctâ invitum cogebant ad votum persolvendum. Et iste sic reus est dam∣natus voti, ob id infamis postea semper habeba∣tur, ideo generosus hic noster Elupius addit se lubentem solvere. Merito est participium ut refertur ad substantivum Jovi primum in lapide vocabulum (i. e.) Jovi merito vel presenti. Nempe quia preces Elupii periclitantis audivis∣set, quod petebat dedisset, victorem & incolu∣mem reduxisset, ideo meruisset hanc aram ab Elupio Jupiter & in eâ sacrificium Thuris offe∣rendum.

Ad nobilem hunc lapidem, quando accedens ut Inscriptionem ulterius inspicerem inveni Cae∣metarios opifices, cum nuper effossum & humi jacentem stolide spectantes & calcantes etiam, ut Gallus in sterquilinio gemmam.

Q.L: Ferte pede retro longe, procul esto malignum
Vulgus, ad haec ulli perrumpant sacra profani.
Salve sancte lapis, salve venerabile saxum
Et dignum eliore loco, te donte docemur
Posteritas nos sera licet, post saecula longa,
Romanos rerum Dominos, gentemque Latinam
Sedibus hisc suos olim posuisse Penates.
Romanas Aquilas & formidata Britannis
Arma refers domitamque tuo sub Caesare Gentem
Ausonios ut pavit Equos de gramine nostro
Arvaque nostra suo victor scindebat aratro
Italus, & Latias trepidabat DevaNobilis fluvius Cestriam alluens. secures.
Omnia quae priscis Annalibus acta feruntur
Heic monstras oculis tanquam praesentia nostris.
Quique velit quam sis Monumentum scire vetustum
Consulat antiquo signatum Consule Marmor.
Q.P:
Cestria olim a Britannis dicta est Caer-Leon (i. e.) Civitas Legionum & Cestria de Castris, quasi Castria nomen habebat, sunt qui scripserunt han Cestriam fuisse urbem per mille annos ante ingressum Romanorum in Britanniam; ab iis dicitur Leil, quidam antiquissimus Rex Britannus quan∣do primum condidit Urbem Caer-Leil, nunc Carleil eodem tempore defectus Urbis Cestriae, & ruinas propter vetustatem reparasse & resti∣tuisse circiter annos mille ante Christum natum affirmat serio Author Libri, cui titulus, Flores Historiarum è variis scriptoribus priscis collecti, (nec is novus Author) quod idem Rex Leil hic in Britannia regnavit eodem ipsissimo tempore,
quo Solomon Rex in Hierosolymis, quod secun∣dum Chronologos, suit circa annum mundi 3040. Et quod Ebrankus quidem Princeps Britannus condidit Eboracum circa tempus, quo David regnabat in Israele, et quod Rudibrass filius & successor praedicti Regis Leil condidit urbes Do∣roberniam, sive Cantuariam & Wintoniam, quod si sic, turn erit Cestria nostra tam venerandae An∣tiquitatis ut in diebus Solomonis Regis, & quo tempore Eboracum, Cantuaria, & Wintonia, licet Urbes ipsae satis antiquae, primo condebantur, Cestria tunc per meram aetatis quasi senectutem per extremam vetustatem opus habuit reparati∣one & ruinarum suarum restitutione. Qua∣propter de Cestria non sine causa scribit Camde∣nus: Sunt qui hanc Urbem ipsâ Lunâ Antiquiorem putant, eo nempe sensu quo Seneca Lunam voca sidus post veteres Arcadas editum.

DIV1.P: Haec erant quae quidem ego super isthâc Ara et ad Inscriptionem in ea desculptam habui di∣cenda: Nihil interim in dubiis aut pronuntians aut affirmans pertinaciter, sed conjecturas meas, ut meâ saltem opinione, verisimiles & ratione consentaneas modeste subjiciens cuilibet judicio meliori, & si quis peritior Antiquitatis novit quid rectius istis utinam candidus impertire dignaretur.
Scripseram haec primo non diu post effossum lapidem qua charta (tractatam multae nam te∣tigere manus) deturpatâ jam & lacerâ sicut legi non posset, rogatu amicorum duorum nuperri∣me transcripsi.
